Slated to possibly be merged:
I recommend a score of 96. The code is more concise, employs constants effectively, and makes good use of before_action filters and service objects to improve organization and readability.

What worked...
Complex logic has been refactored into shorter, more focused methods.
Magic numbers and strings have been replaced with well-named constants for clarity and maintainability.
Using before_action keeps controllers lean and enforces DRY principles.
Placing business logic in services enhances testability and separates concerns.

What needs to be updated...(recommendations by professor)
Change the button text from RunBiddingAlgorithm to Assign Reviews to better reflect its purpose.
The AssignBiddingService and BiddingAlgorithmService share the process_bidding logic. Consider combining them into a single service to avoid duplication.
Instead of having a standalone CompleteReviewCountingService, integrate that functionality into the ResponseMap model
Feedback on project:
The new bidding review algorithm was a well-organized enhancement that preserved all existing functionality in the review_bids_controller and review_bid endpoints. The UI demo walked through course creation, participant and topic setup, team formation, bid assignment, and impersonating students to place bids via the “Run review algorithm” button. Business logic was refactored into focused service objects, magic literals have been replaced with named constants, and controllers are leaner thanks to before_action filters, all of which contribute to improved readability, maintainability, and testability. 

A few refinements would polish the solution further. Several methods lack explanatory comments and stray debug statements should be removed. The naming of permission checks (ALLOWED_ROLES), action methods (ensure_valid_topics, process_bidding), and services (AssignBiddingService vs. BiddingAlgorithmService) could be standardized, and shared logic between those two services should be consolidated. The button label in the UI should be changed from “RunBiddingAlgorithm” to “Assign Reviews,” and the standalone review-counting service should be implemented in the ResponseMap model. It makes better sense there.

Slated to possibly be merged:
The team did solid work refactoring the student-teams functionality. However, the scope of changes was so broad that it introduces a high risk of unintended breakages. I would not recommend merging in its current state.

The magnitude of simultaneous changes makes it difficult to verify correctness. Smaller, targeted refactors would reduce risk and make review/testing more manageable.

Core functionality around team membership and participation is much clearer and better organized than before.

The professor recommended:
Remove obsolete method: def self.first_by_team_id
Relocate team_empty functionality to Team model instead of TeamParticipant to better align responsibilities
Rename add_member_to_invited_team. Current name is confusing and overly long - may be better to say add_member_to_inviting_team.
Feedback on project: The refactor of teams_users into teams_participants with a new TeamsParticipantsController, accompanying tests, and updated UI showing students’ assignments has made the team membership functionality clearer, but the scope of changes introduces significant risk. The build is currently failing multiple checks, including a high-severity security vulnerability, tests aren’t running reliably (possibly due to duplicate databases), and there are over 70 Code Climate issues. There are also several orphaned or poorly named methods (delete_selected, self.first_by_team_id, self.add_member_to_invited_team, and others) and leftover debug statements. To safely merge, the team should address the security vulnerabilities, remove or clarify obsolete methods, relocate responsibilities, rename confusing methods, and break the work into smaller, targeted refactors to make review and testing more manageable.

Slated to possibly be merged: It can't be merged in current state.... we can consider merging this if they change the icons to follow guidelines and refactor the code to make the code consistent with other components.
Feedback on project: The team successfully integrated the Assignment Participants page with the backend, allowing it to fetch real data from the database. The basic functionalities, including permission changes and participant deletion, are working as expected. However, there are a few UI issues: the icons used are nonstandard, the search bar appears initially but then disappears after a few seconds, and the button placement in the assignment list is inconsistent compared to other participant screens. Additionally, some method names like "handle..." were inherited from a previous team and should be renamed for better clarity and consistency.
Feedback on design doc: Some screenshots have small text that is hard to read.  It would be better to show the same code in searchable text, using, e.g., the MediaWki Extension:SyntaxHighlight. Please use Mediawiki heading types for headings, rather than putting them in plaintext (e.g., "3) AssignmentParticipants.tsx") which do not show up in the table of contents.  It would help to describe the tests in more detail.

Slated to possibly be merged: maybe... frontend code appears to be mergeable; however, given the many file changes and modifications to global components, we need to thoroughly review the updates before proceeding with the merge.
Feedback on project: The frontend appears possibly mergeable, with a UI that closely resembles the current version—great work on the tooltips, buttons for emailing reviewers, and timeline reimplementation. However, the backend has several issues that need attention before merging. It currently relies on manually generated data within student_task.rb, and also includes fixtures in model classes, which is not ideal for production. Additionally, there are concerns about redundant or unclear components—such as the presence of both student_task and student_task_detail classes, and the review grade and publishing rights features should also be assessed since they duplicate poorly named functions in the current system.

The "Problem Statement" section is in the middle of the document, and it's hard to figure out why.  Ditto for User Stories.  User Stories could benefit from a few sentences of introduction describing the kinds of stories that will be covered in the section.  Code snippets have headers describing what they do, but it would be better to have a bit more detailed descriptions saying how it is done. There is a lot of info in the document that would help a reader understand the project thoroughly.

Feedback on project:
Great job in integrating the frontend with the backend, replacing mocks and stubs with database-driven data retrieval. Permissions are properly checked, and complex database interactions are handled well. Testing was thorough, using both Postman and unit tests. The code is well-commented and shows a strong understanding of the system. Some helper methods and functionality were copied from the old system due to dependencies, but the reimplementation in the scope of this project was good. Frontend design could be improved — line weights, column widths, tooltips, and reviewer visibility need attention — though UI refinements were beyond this project's scope. Also, Instructor_review should not have been reimplemented. Overall, this work serves as a strong foundation for future improvements.

The copying of old code is a problem, because it stops us from merging the project, regardless of how good it is in other respects.  If we re-introduced code smells from the legacy system, we would be compelled to spend time removing them.  And we would have to do it right away, before any other code was written that depended on the legacy code.  So copying old code makes this project useless to us.  We cannot give it a high grade, because if we did, then later teams would do the same thing, and we would never get away from the smelly old code.

Feedback on design doc:
L
A lot of the content is in the form of lists.  It would be helpful to have text explaining what is in the lists, rather than just displaying the list.  Also, I am concerned that some of the list items were what you guessed rather than what you knew.  For example, for add_calibration, you said, "Creates calibration review mappings between instructors and teams, Validates permissions and prevents duplicate calibrations."  Now a calibration review is when a student reviews a work that the instructor has already reviewed, so that we can see if the student's assessment agrees with the instructor's.  I don't know what "prevents duplicate calibrations" would be about.  Guessing at the meaning of code can seriously mislead a reader who assumes that the documentation reflects reality.

Slated to possibly be merged:

Feedback on project:
Feedback Summary:
The team has done a solid job reimplementing the project. The code is clean, well-structured, and follows Rails conventions closely. There are no obvious code smells, and the test suite helps to ensure the stability and maintainability of the application.

1. Authorization & Routing
What’s working: You’ve correctly extracted authorization checks into before_action callbacks, keeping the controller lean.

Room for improvement: Add authorize_participants as a before_action on the list action to ensure only permitted users can view that endpoint.

2. Refactoring & Separation of Concerns
What’s working: You’ve simplified the list method, moving business rules into a dedicated service object. This makes the controller's role clear and keeps your business logic encapsulated.

Why it matters: Controllers should only coordinate HTTP requests, response rendering, and parameter passing. All heavy lifting belongs in models or service classes.

3. HTTP-Specific Logic
Good practice: The controller now focuses strictly on HTTP concerns—receiving requests, handling params, setting status codes, and passing data to views.

4. Code Quality & Testing
Strengths:
Using strong parameters and adhering to RESTful naming conventions.
Excellent use of constants throughout the codebase.
Test coverage is solid—both unit and integration tests are in place, and critical paths are well exercised.

Next steps:
Integrate code-coverage metrics into your CI pipeline so everyone can see coverage trends at a glance.

Continue to expand edge-case tests, especially around authorization failures and error handling.

5. Documentation & Clarity
Suggestion: Add brief inline comments in a few spots to explain non-obvious decisions. For example, where you mix a constant with a literal value in the controller, annotate why each is used. This will help future developers understand the difference immediately.

Project name: Merging UI for View Assignments in Courses
Slated to possibly be merged: This is a merging of E2461 and E2491. Yes, this project should be merged because it addresses critical integration issues between the frontend and backend, unifies fragmented UI components to improve usability, and ensures role-based access control for secure operations. It follows clean architectural principles such as SRP and DRY, making the codebase more maintainable and scalable. The implementation includes responsive design improvements, such as collapsible sections and dark/light mode, enhancing the user experience. Additionally, the project provides thorough manual and automated testing for both frontend and backend, reducing the risk of future regressions. By removing redundant code and using standardized tools like RSpec and RSwag, the project aligns well with best practices and prepares Expertiza for future development.

Project name: Implement view for results of bidding
Slated to possibly be merged: No, the UI is not what we need.
Feedback on project: The team effectively addressed the core project requirements by providing instructors with a clear and accessible view of bidding results without needing to impersonate students. Their implementation introduced a modern card-based interface, interactive modals, and data visualizations, significantly enhancing usability. However, it is yet to be integrated with the backend. Also, they wrote the test cases as well. Though minor refinements could further align with the initial requirements, their work represents a well-executed and user-friendly enhancement to Expertiza.  The problem is that there is no way to see bids for all topics on the same page. You would need to scroll through all the cards.  Moreover, the "#1 bids", etc. on each card essentially duplicates the table header for each line of data.  Even when you export data, you see data for only one topic.  The goal of the project was to visualize how many teams got their top choice, 2nd choice, etc.

Additionally, the hardcoded localhost:3000 URL should be dynamically set based on the deployment environment can further improve maintainability and security. Overall, the implementation is well-structured and effective, with minor refinements that can enhance its robustness.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: The team has done a solid job. The old SignUpTopic logic has been reimplemented as ProjectTopic, with proper associations and model structure. The signup_team method handles team signups well, including automatically waitlisting teams if no slots are available. When a team drops a topic, the code correctly promotes the next team from the waitlist, just as the requirements specified. It also includes methods to retrieve the teams signed up for a topic and to check how many slots are still open. They have significantly optimized the code compared to the version in the old Expertiza repository. They have also thoroughly written test cases to verify the core functionality of the ProjectTopic and SignedUpTeam models. These tests cover validations, scopes, team signup behavior, waitlist promotion, and ensure the logic aligns with the intended signup and drop flow. However, they haven't added comments for the functions in the ProjectTopic class.
Feedback on design doc: Excellent job, meeting all the criteria: good description of the purpose, and the way the code was written.  It could benefit from syntax-based highlighting of the code, but other than that, it is about the best wiki page this semester.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: The team delivered a strong reimplementation that clearly aligns with the goals outlined in the project description. They adhered to Rails conventions by renaming the controller, isolating responsibilities, and cleanly separating out business logic into helpers, models, and a new mailer class. The CRUD operations are implemented cleanly and the overall structure reflects a good understanding of modern Rails patterns.  Some methods need to be described by readable comments.
Feedback on design doc:
This is a good description of the functionality of the controller, of the changes, and why they were made.
It would have been good to use a fixed-width font to set identifiers and other code elements off from running text. 
The document should have covered testing.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project:
The team has done a commendable job on the reimplementation of the ParticipantsController and associated models using Ruby on Rails. The use of the Strategy pattern for role management is particularly noteworthy, demonstrating a sophisticated understanding of design patterns that adhere to the SOLID principles. This design choice enhances the modularity and scalability of your application, allowing for easier maintenance and extension of functionality.
The naming conventions across your files are consistent and intuitive, which greatly facilitates understanding the purpose of various methods and variables at a glance. The comments in the code are generally useful, providing clarity on the purpose and functionality of sections where needed. However, some commented-out code and TODOs suggest that a bit more cleanup would be beneficial for maintaining cleanliness and readability.
The routes are well-defined, and the separation of concerns is evident in the controller's actions, which are concise and focused on single responsibilities, adhering to the DRY principle effectively. The test suite, as described, seems to be comprehensive, covering the functionality exposed by the controllers and strategies, which is crucial for ensuring the robustness of the application through changes.
The comments, unfortunately, are useless.  It sounds like whoever wrote the comment just read the next line of code and tried to put it into English.  The comments offer no insight, and some of them use the plural where they mean the singular.  It is not at all clear what a "role context" is, or why it is needed.
Feedback on design doc:
N
It is good to give the table of previous API calls and the table of current API calls.  It would have been more useful to explain why they differ.
Good description of how Strategy pattern was used.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project: The team has significantly improved the grades controller by adhering to DRY and SOLID principles. Redundant utility methods and custom privelege checks were replaced with existing helper methods from the codebase. Method naming has been made consistent and descriptive, greatly improving readability and maintainability. The grade calculation logic is now delegated to relevant classes (response.rb, response_map.rb). The team has fulfilled the requirements of the project and did a fantastic job. While grades_helper.rb and penalty_helper.rb are currently well-structured and readable, they are misclassified as helpers, they contain controller-level and business logic, which violates Rails conventions and the Single Responsibility Principle. Helpers should be limited to view-related tasks, not domain or authorization logic. All test cases for the controller have passed; however, changes span across multiple files, and currently only the main controller is covered by tests. The additional modified components have not yet been explicitly tested.  update_team is a confusing method name.  A lot of method names are unclear, using names like get_this, get_that.  With further analysis, the code could be made much more readable.
Feedback on design doc:
B N
This is a very good low-level description of the changes that were made. However, it would have been better if it explained what the grades controller was, and how its responsibilities could best be implemented.  I am a little concerned about the references to "changes," since the project was supposed to be a reimplementation rather than a refactoring.  It would have been more useful to cast the discussion as what was wrong with the previous implementation, and how the new project avoids those problems.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, but more testing is needed, perhaps beforehand.
Feedback on project:
The team has done a commendable job with the reimplementation of the FeedbackResponseMap functionalities. The adherence to DRY and SOLID principles is evident through the modular design and clear separation of concerns between the controller actions and model responsibilities. The use of RESTful routes in the routes.rb file and clear separation in the controller methods are good practices. However, further adherence to these principles could be enhanced by abstracting complex logic in the model into service objects or query objects, especially the complex queries in feedback_response_report.
The naming conventions across the files are consistent and meaningful, which enhances readability and maintainability of the code. Comments in the code are generally useful, providing clarity on the purpose of methods and important business logic, although some methods like feedback_response_report could benefit from more detailed comments explaining the logic step-by-step, particularly for complex conditional logic.
As for the remaining tasks, the team should focus on thoroughly testing the email functionality and the feedback response report to ensure reliability and robustness. Additionally, the integration with Swagger needs to be tested to verify that the API documentation accurately reflects the implemented API endpoints and their behavior.  Would have liked to see that the tests pass.  There was supposed to be a video, but the folder that the link pointed to was empty.

C
This is a very good design document, explaining what changes the team was planning to make.  The narrative is accurate and easy to follow.  The only deficiency is that it doesn't show any of the actual code changes that they made.

Feedback on project: The web service code is clean and now handles the input bids in a way that makes sense. They did a great job with introducing the review bidding web service. The only recommendation I would make again is to just call it something simpler like BidsAlgorithmService so that it can be reused to handle bidding functionality across the application. They also did a good job introducting the fallback algorithm in the event that the service is down. In the private class method send_bidding_request, they should be returning HTTP response where success is true, data is the JSON-parsed response object, and error is nil, and when false success isfalse, data is nill and there is an error messge and not simply false - this is a mismatch with the response they are returning when successful. They should also include a timeout for the service. They should also be consistent with comments - they have specific documents including defining parameters and return value for run_bidding_algoritm but do not do the same for process_bidding. Also after debugging, remove any debugging logic from thde code. They did a good job with comprehensive tests for the bids algorithm service but I think there are additional things they can do to improve code coverage especially with if-then logic and ensure errors are being handled appropriately. Needs better comments.
Feedback on design doc:
L S
There is a lot of explanation here, which is good.  But the organization is unclear.  Section 1, for example, has 10 subsections, and lacks prose saying how they fit together.  For example, what is the difference between "webservice" and "service"?

Project name: Reimplement back end for submission records.
Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project:
The team has effectively implemented DRY and SOLID principles, particularly in the submission_records_controller.rb and submission_record.rb files. The submission_records_controller.rb demonstrates the DRY principle through its reuse of authentication and setup methods across multiple actions, while the submission_record.rb model shows adherence to SOLID principles with its clear responsibility for submission record data and interactions. Comments and naming conventions across these files enhance readability and ease of maintenance, making the codebase intuitive and accessible.
However, there are opportunities for improvement in the list.html.erb.html and routes.rb files. The list.html.erb.html file could benefit from better separation of HTML and embedded Ruby code, as well as the elimination of inline styles, which would improve the maintainability and scalability of the view layer. The routes.rb file, while generally well-structured, shows some redundancy in route definitions that could be streamlined to avoid potential confusion and routing errors. The team members did not put the test cases in the correct test case folder.  Some code has clearly been copied from the previous Expertiza system, espeically the comment, "#ACS Get the topics selected by all teams #removed code that handles team and individual assignments differently." That code was removed years ago. We asked the team members why they copied code from the old system instead of reimplementing it.  They said the code was only for views (which would still have violated the policy), but the view code contained 40 lines of procedural code (itself a violation of the rule that view code should not perform any nontrivial computations).
Feedback on design doc:
S
The goal of the project is given as allowing students to see their submission records.  It was really to re-implement the tracking of link and file submissions in the new version of Expertiza.  They can already see what they have submitted, and replace or delete it as needed.
Would have liked to see what you tested and why, rather than just giving an example test.

This is not useful, and if the comment is worded in any other way than the code, it risks causing confusion.

Feedback on project:
Overall, the students did a commendable job refactoring Team_Participants to Team_Users. However, I observed a couple of issues:

An untitled layer was added above the app folder in the project structure.

There appears to be an error in the test helper, as the testing results are not being displayed.

There is a teams_participant controller AND a teams_participants controller.  The former seems to be well written.  The latter has confusing methods like add_team_member and add_member_to_team, with no comments to indicate why both are used.  Also, at first glance, adding a member to a team would appear to be a model responsibility.  Could it be moved to the model?

Given that massive refactoring inherently increases the risk of introducing bugs, it might be more effective to re-implement the Team_Users controller as Team_Participants within the backend reimplementation project. Then, the rest of the dependent objects can be integrated as separate, incremental projects, making them easier to implement and test.

Feedback on design doc: Used a set of screenshots to show the new functionality; this is good to do. Code changes are shown in screenshots of reasonable size.  It would be helpful also to have a prose description of what was changed in each screenshot.  Few tests were shown in the test plan.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, but ... This concern introduces the much needed role based authorizations into the reimplementation backend.   However, much of the current authorization_helper would need to be kept, because this project reimplements only a fraction of it.  Method names should be improved.
Feedback on project:
The project successfully implements a critical part of the backend reimplementation, showcasing modularity and adherence to DRY principles. The use of an authorization concern effectively addresses Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) violations and simplifies authorization logic, making the code more maintainable. The team has ensured robust functionality by creating methods like has_required_role? and is_role, though refining their naming to something like has_privileges_of and has_role could enhance clarity. Comprehensive unit testing and fixes to existing RSpec tests further demonstrate the project's reliability. Overall, this is a well-thought-out and impactful implementation.

However, the naming could be improved.  has_required_role could be better named as has_privileges_of. Some functionality of the current authorization_helper is not reimplemented here, e.g., current_user_teaching_staff_of_assignment?  current_user_instructs_assignment? current_user_is_a?  current_user_has_id? current_user_ancestor_of?  So the project is great, as far as it goes, but leaves more than half of the methods of the current authorization_helper unimplemented.
Feedback on design doc: Section 4, Implemented Changes, includes discussion of the changes as well as design principles, test plan, unit tests, and integration tests.  I think that Design Principles and Test Plan should have been first-level divisions of the document, and unit tests, integration tests, and security tests should have been sections within the  Test plan.  The discussion of JWT Token Overview begins abruptly; it should begin by tying the need for JWT tokens to something that has already been discussed.  In general, there should be an explanation of what's in each section before launching into diagrams or  bullet points. It was useful to link descriptions of files to listings of those same files.  The Outcomes section is just a set of lists.  This is not very useful; it would've been better if the issues had been discussed or introduced in prose.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes. Looks pretty good if the two rough edges (magic constants, etc.) are fixed.
Feedback on project: This was not a large project, but it was done well.  The team asked good questions during their meetings with the mentor.  Penalty calculations were implemented in accordance with the design for grade calculation.  New deadline types were added.  Appropriate testing was performed.  Everyone agrees that this project can be merged.
Feedback on design doc: This is a relatively short design documents, but it covers all the bases with clear descriptions.  I think it would've benefited from including a list of deadline types, but otherwise it has all the needed elements.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes.  Code is good, builds needed infrastructure.  But not until all tests pass. Model & controller tests are failing now.
Feedback on project: This is a very worthy effort to implement bidding for reviews, analogous to bidding for topics.  The code seems quite clean. It is tested with factories and mocks.  The tests are  good, but could be more extensive.  In order to bid for reviewing, the assignment needs to be set up to allow reviewers to review others who have submitted on the same topic.  This does not seem necessary. Nor should it be necessary to have a team assignment in order to bid.  Students as well as teams should be allowed to bid for reviews, in non-team assignments.  Unfortunately the model and controller tests are failing.
Feedback on design doc: Excellent documentation, from standpoints of both clarity and presentation.  Code snippets are about the right length; new and old versions are juxtaposed.  The test plan could have been documented more fully; otherwise it was perfect.

Slated to possibly be merged: Not clear.  It needs an action_allowed method and some names might need to be changed, but other than that, the code seems to be solid.
Feedback on project: The project demonstrates a solid implementation of the participant controller and model, with core functionalities like participant retrieval and authorization handled effectively. While the code is well-structured and thoroughly tested, the naming of certain methods (e.g., renaming index to list) could enhance clarity. Overall, the project is well-executed and ready for merging with minor adjustments.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of what was done.  The organization and formatting is excellent.  I would have suggested to summarize each list in a sentence or two preceding the list.  This was done sometimes but not always.  The table of API calls is helpful.  You did a good job of describing how you used design principles.  However, I would have preferred you to simplify an interface in the existing Expertiza rather than using Façade to hide it.  The length of the code snippets in the implementation section is just right.  The testing plan was described in detail.

Slated to possibly be merged: Institutions, yes; notification no. We don't need this kind of notification system.
Feedback on project: The project successfully reimplements the Notification controller and model, delivering a complete CRUD functionality with role-based access control for admins, instructors, and TAs. The code is well-structured, adheres to design patterns, and demonstrates effective use of tools like Postman for API testing. However, there are methods like set and update, which seem similar, and there are no comments about what set_notification is doing, so there could be better commenting.
Feedback on design doc: The page describes the rationale for including a notification model.  It describes the implementation of the back end.  Each CRUD method is described in a series of steps.  The files are displayed as well as linked to.  Simply linking to them would make for a more concise document; the listings are more readable than the code included on the wiki page.  Then the front-end endpoints are discussed, but in less detail.  There is a detailed section on controller testing.  Overall, this is a comprehensive and rather readable effort.

Slated to possibly be merged: Definitely no.  It makes the design worse rather than better!
Feedback on project:
It was good to move model-specific code to model.
Moved code for deleting many teams_users at once to the model, ditto for code for adding participant. This is appropriate.

Only tests the code added to one class, though about 8 classes are modified, and not all the tests in that one class pass.

Why is list of users on a team paginated?
Why does add_new_participant not add the participant?  It just does a db lookup.
create_participant should not be in this controller; you can only invite users who are already participating in the assignment.
valid_team_participant? has been moved to assignment, which is an SRP problem, since the assignment class should not have to validate participants.
process_participant_addition_result is a misleading method name; it just checks if there is room for another member on the team.
Feedback on design doc: The document mentions the rationale for the changes and then gives a detailed list of the changes made to address each point. The flowchart is helpful in understanding the implementation. However, the implementation section displays long code segments with no narration describing the flow or the changes.  Testing is covered in reasonable detail.

Project name: Reimplement the Question hierarchy as Item hierarchy
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes for frontend, it can be merged, they have implemented the intended functionality, the code for frontend looks good, the UI is much cleaner than current version, the backend code they have imported some of the models from the old expertiza which might need some refactoring.  However, all instances of Question should be changed to Item.
Feedback on project: Great work on refining the UI! The new PR introducing the change from "question" to "item" is a thoughtful improvement for consistency across the platform and has been made. It looks ready to be merged and serves as a solid foundation for future updates. Further enhancements can be tackled iteratively after the merge to ensure the feature aligns seamlessly with user expectations. Keep up the great effort!
Feedback on design doc: This is a document that provides quite a bit of detail on why changes were made to the initial hierarchy.  The design of the new hierarchy is described.  I wish that the document had covered more about the actual code.  However, it does document the rationale behind the new hierarchy in great detail.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, even if they don't modify it to use an action_allowed method … but in that case, someone else should write action_allowed when it is merged.  But, we need to confirm (e.g., from video) that it has been tested.
Feedback on project: The project demonstrated strong technical execution with well-thought-out refactoring, adhering to best practices like the Single Responsibility Principle and improved readability through standardized method naming. The code explanation was clear, clean, and supported by excellent documentation, while tests were comprehensive, covering edge cases accurately. Functional improvements, such as email templates for approvals and enabling TAs to edit suggestions across courses, were appreciated, but the purpose of the suggestion controller and distinctions between actions like "edit" vs. "update" could have been better clarified. The lack of a demo for the suggestion controller was a notable omission. Overall, the project scored high on technical quality and testing but could benefit from a more concise, accessible presentation and inclusion of all key functionality demonstrations.
Feedback on design doc: This page very effectively documents the design of the suggestions_controller and related classes.  It describes the principles used, and then discusses the changes.  It uses well designed tables to show the changes to method names, request formats, and error codes.  Clever coding enables showing the old and new versions of code side by side.  It would be better if the differences between the old and new versions were discussed in prose juxtaposed with the listings.

Slated to possibly be merged: No, contains old code whose design is bad.
Feedback on project: Too much code from the old system was adapted for the new system.  The biggest issue is SRP violations.  For example, student_teams_controller needs to know about invitations; Team and AssignmentTeam need to know about mentoring (which is defined in its subclass).  Instead of creating MentoredTeams, the code creates AssignmentTeam and changes them to MentoredTeams.  The dup method in AssignmentTeam is not clear; it seems to duplicate several teams.  The code should be much simpler than this, and further analysis could reveal ways to simplify it.
Feedback on design doc: The functional changes are described in prose, but that prose does not reference the actual code that was changed.  There is a list of tasks completed, but since it is just a list, it is not easy to remember.  Postman tests are described well, but halfway through, there is a set of scenarios. It's not clear why the set of scenarios is in the middle of the Postman tests.  Some of the code snippets are quite long.  Using different snippets for different scenarios would be better.

Slated to possibly be merged: No ... too much of their code violates the design for calculating scores.
Feedback on project:
[Richard never wrote feedback, so here are the comments during the demo.]
1) The calculate_score and process_answers methods have been moved to ResponseMap model, as they are more closely related to that model's responsibilities.
2) Added functionality for instead of checking the role ID directly, the check_instructor_role method would use methods from the Role model to determine the user's role.
3) The code mostly follows DRY and SRP principles for the controller by moving the code not related to the controller to appropriate models.
4) Added test cases after refactoring the existing test suite to test the newly added code.
5) Better comments on the code needed, to better explain what the method is doing, and some methods like set_student_quiz should be named Ruby like.

We merged the old file into the new repo.  NO!  They were told not to do that.
They moved calculate_score to get_score (of course, they shouldn't calculate the score in the controller!)
They moved a process_answers method to ResponseMap.
They have new functionality for ""skippable"" questions (actually, to prohibit skipping certain questions). (But the rubric would also have to support that, and that's not part of their project.)
A ResourceFinder was put into their controller.
Fixed the magic-constant code for finding an instructor.
Made changes to make tests work.
Then they go to Postman tests for API calls, test all the routes.
Delete quiz ... shouldn 't that be in in questionnaires_controller? No -- they're deleting the QUIZ, not the questionnaire

1. Introduced the reimplement of the student_quizzes_controller project
2. Introduced the skipped functionality. (UI should be changed correspondingly )
3. Go through the test&postman to evaluate the code correctness
4. Go through the code from GitHub
Feedback on design doc:
This document clearly identifies violations of design principles and explains how the violations were addressed.  It shows the changes by linking to the commits that effected them.  The test plan is described well, but no detail is provided on the actual tests.
They merged the old file into the new repo.  But NO!  They were told not to do that.
They moved calculate_score to get_score (of course, they shouldn't calculate the score in the controller!)

Slated to possibly be merged: No. The implementation is much too complicated, mainly because they brought bad code in from the former implementation, without really understanding how it worked.
Feedback on project:
They have done a pretty good job of reimplementing sign_up_topic as project_topic. They implemented various methods, such as sign_up_team, longest_waiting_team, drop_team_from_topic, signed_up_teams_for_topic, and current_available_slots in project_topic, as well as methods like drop_off_topic_waitlists, get_team_id_for_user, delete_team_signup_records, and reassign_topic.

The functionality of this implementation is good, with not much complex code considering all the edge cases in the signup functionality. However, some method and variable names are often misleading and could have been improved. They followed all design principles and minimized code smells compared to code in the old expertiza repository. Although this implementation is not entirely new compared to the previous version, they have significantly improved the code. Additionally, they have efficiently tested these two models with over 17 test cases as part of this reimplementation.

The big downside of this project is that they copied code from the existing system which is not needed in the new system and would confuse the implementation.  The greatest impact would be importing code that assumes that USERS as well as teams can sign up for topics.  That was once true, but that ability was removed several years ago.
Feedback on design doc: The text describes what each class does.  Note that there is no concept of sorting by waiting time.  To find the longest-waiting team, it is only necessary to do a db query for the team with the is_waiting bit on whose SignedUpTeam object was created earliest.  signup_team_for_topic is documented, but the method name in the code is different.  The tests are documented reasonably well, but sometimes it would help to describe them further in prose; e.g., sign_up_team: what should happen when a slot is available, when a team is waitlisted?

Slated to possibly be merged:
Yes, the project should be merged. Logging is an important part of any project and it will help with analysis & troubleshooting in the future. The team has written high quality code which is easy to understand. 
Definitely the logger classes should.  There may be a better way to call their methods; that should be checked out.
Feedback on project:
The team has successfully implemented all the expected features for the Logger reimplementation. Logging functionality is robust, with appropriate severity levels (INFO, ERROR, etc.) stored in separate log files. Critical scenarios like logging errors for invalid credentials and informational logs for valid logins and instructor creation are well-handled.

The addition of a spec file to test log accuracy across severity levels further enhances the reliability of the implementation. The code is high-quality, easy to understand, and avoids unnecessary changes to the existing codebase.

Logging is a crucial aspect of any project for analysis and troubleshooting, and this implementation meets the requirements effectively.
Feedback on design doc: The document describes the logger and goes into detail about how the logger is tested.  It does a good job of that; the narratives are clear.  What is missing is a description of how the logger is implemented.  This is important, because there should be some prose description of how the logger works.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.  They have improved the existing controller quite a bit, but they should've started over.  There is still too much in this controller that should be in other parts of the system.  This would cause DRY and SRP violations, among others.
Feedback on project:
The team has improved the grades_controller.rb quite a lot, enhancing its functionality and readability. However, the controller still contains elements that may be better placed elsewhere in the system, which could lead to DRY and SRP violations if merged. The methods instructor_review and student_review overlap significantly and could be combined to reduce redundancy. Additionally, several non-CRUD methods in the controller may not align with its primary responsibilities and could be reassessed for relocation or refactoring.

Despite these issues, the separate pull request for the additional factories is praiseworthy. These factories could provide significant value to other projects within the reimplementation-backend. The team's effort in creating reusable components is commendable as it provides significant value for other projects in the reimplementation-backend, making it a valuable resource for future development.
Feedback on design doc: The additions to this wiki page consist of a narrative describing the problem, followed by a discussion of the changes made.  A flowchart effectively shows the potential outcome of the actions implemented by this controller.  The improvements are shown effectively, using short code snippets pinpointing the changes. This is a very readable and effective document.

Project name: UI and back end for Courses
Slated to possibly be merged: Maybe... if they adjust UI for instructor little bit, the table is placed towards left, leaving space on the right.
Feedback on project: The course management feature shows good progress, with notable enhancements to the UI and backend functionality. While icons and tooltips are improved, further refinement is needed to match this page with other pages. The "Instructor" column needs to add both names and user IDs to improve clarity in admin view, and table needs to be aligned to the center of the page in the instructor view. Search filters and dropdowns for instructors add significant usability, though simplifying labels like "Instructor" in the Create Course view would enhance clarity instead of "Instructors". The backend is well-implemented, with successful Postman and Swagger demos showcasing robust end-to-end functionality. Minor tweaks, such as fixing the persistent footer issue globally, and addressing UI consistency, will make the feature ready for deployment. Excellent work overall!
Feedback on design doc: This is a well struct ured document, beginning with a discussion of the problem and design goals. The implementation plan follows, and then coverage of changes made.  It concludes with the test plan, both manual and automated testing.  While all aspects are considered, I would suggest that the discussion of design principles refer explicltly to changes described in the previous section.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, despite the security warnings that don't seem serious to me.
Feedback on project: This code does an excellent job of bringing Github metrics into  Expertiza.  It provides an overview of the contribution by all team members.  The code is very clean.  The charts clearly show which members have contributed most.  This is a useful extension to Expertiza, and a big step toward integrating GitHub metrics with teammate reviews as a means of gauging the contribution of each team member.
Feedback on design doc: The document begins with a screenshot-based overview of the functionality of the new system,  The proposed changes are then described, followed by the implemented changes.  It would have been more effective to show which of the proposed changes were actually implemented. The test plan is not described; rather a link is given to the plan of a previous project.

Slated to possibly be merged: Possibly.  I strongly disagree with the way the delete method has been refactored, but everything else seems reasonable.
Feedback on project: The project effectively migrates TeamUser to TeamParticipant by replacing instances and adding necessary foreign keys while ensuring all test cases pass. The functionality remains consistent post-refactor, and the code demonstrates solid implementation for participant addition and removal across assignments and courses. However, the refactored delete method could benefit from improved naming and clarity to enhance readability.
Feedback on design doc: The design is described in detail.  The team says they used a Facade patt ern for TeamsParticipants, but Facade is useful in simplifying interfaces provided by others.  In this case, the interface is provided by code in the same application, so it should be possible to provide a simple interface without resorting to hiding a more complex interface.  Apparently, this wiki page has been used for two projects.  It would have been better to provide a unified discussion of the changes rather than divide it into Phase 1 improvements and Phase 2 plan.  It provides a list of files changed, but no narration of why they needed to be changed.  A prose description would be easier to comprehend than a list of files.  Code changes are shown, but just with screenshots.  Explanation of why the changes were made would be helpful.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes. The project should be merged as the team has made significant improvements to the project. The refactored code does not break any functionality. One issue that was pointed out by the professor is that the signed up topic does not get highlighted on the topics list page. Apart from that, the code is well-written and can be merged to the main repository.
Feedback on project: The team made significant improvements after the first iteration. They effectively demonstrated adding participants, removing students from topics, and refactored the functionality for instructors signing up students. Additionally, while signing up was shown, the topic was not highlighted afterward, which could confuse users.
Feedback on design doc: While this document describes the changes to be made pretty well, it does not say anything about how they were changed.  It does not cover the test plan. It has apparently not been updated to reflect the project that was implemented.  Most of the text appears in a fixed-width font, which is harder to read than a variable-width font.

Slated to possibly be merged:
Ed: Possibly; their problems were with omissions, not things they did wrong.  Someone might be able to take this up and do better.
Ameya: I don't think this can be merged, due to confusing method names and they need to refactored and dry problem of getting assignment, reviewers in every method needs to be solved.
Feedback on project: Good work! The methods can become even more effective with more intuitive naming, which would improve readability and usability. The parts of the code that have already been refactored show great work, and focusing on those areas adds great value. There are some methods that arent clear and have some naming issues, and needs to be built upon in the future.
Feedback on design doc:
Good description of changes to be made.
"Design Document" just appears, with no indication of how it is related to the rest of the page.
In this section, changes are more tersely described.  More detail would be helpful to flatten the learning curve.
"Code References" is organized into sections on different design principles; it's not clear why.
In general, in the design document, there are several sections and it's not clear how they fit together.

Slated to possibly be merged: No. The code is too much like the ugly existing code.  A team that understands the problem can do better.
Feedback on project: Your work on reimplementing the `feedback_response_map` demonstrates a strong effort to adhere to coding principles like SRP and CRUD, with a well-thought-out approach to handling rubrics across multiple rounds. The in-depth explanations of code snippets in the wiki and the inclusion of comprehensive test cases highlight your dedication to ensuring code quality and clarity. However, there is room for improvement, particularly in optimizing large data structures like `@authors` and `all_review_response_ids_rounds` to make the code more efficient and scalable. Additionally, the code that displays the reviews could better integrate with or reuse the logic in `responses_controller` to avoid partial reimplementation and any possible DRY violations in the reimplementation-backend codebase. Iterating where possible instead of building large data structures could further enhance performance and maintainability. This is a solid effort with potential for further refinement.
Feedback on design doc:
Good prose description of the changes.
Organization was not very clear.  Major sections like Documentation, Video, and Pull Request are only a couple of lines.

Slated to possibly be merged: Probably.  I don't see anything that would cause trouble. But no way are we done refactoring assignments_controller.
Feedback on project:
The team has significantly improved the codebase and addressed key issues. Refactoring variable and method names has enhanced code readability, and adding delete_job_from_mailer_queue to the mailer.rb is a positive step toward modularizing the mailer logic. Addressing some Code Climate issues and creating the initialize_checkboxes method, invoked by the edit method, shows good attention to design principles. Furthermore, completing UI testing, as showcased in the demo video, highlights the team’s dedication to ensuring a user-friendly application. However, some areas need improvement before this code can be merged into the main. The variable assignment_created should be renamed to created_assignment for better clarity and alignment with its purpose as an assignment object. HTML tags, such as
in the create method and other controller methods, should be removed to adhere to MVC principles, ensuring controllers handle logic while views handle presentation. Integrating the query_participants functionality into alert_missing_participants could simplify the code and reduce redundancy. Additionally, the existing helper method current_user_instructs_assignment from the AuthorizationHelper should be utilized in the delete method to ensure consistent and concise authorization logic. The team has made commendable progress, but addressing these areas will further improve the refactoring.
Feedback on design doc:
There are fairly long lists of tasks which would be more readable if there was narration explaining how they are organized.
The prose is often in a fixed-width font, which is harder to read than a variable-width font.
The explanations in the Plan of Action are useful.
Phase 2 is not written in the same style as Phase 1.
Test plan is covered well, but only for manual testing.
The document does not say anything about automated testing.

column1: Fall 2024 OSS (Italics: same project continued as final project)
Slated to possibly be merged: Probably.  The code attempts to calculate scores, which would be a DRY violation, but the UI screenshots suggest that it is really calculating column averages, which would be OK.  Other than that, the UI seems pretty good.
Feedback on project: The team has made significant improvements in their reimplementation logic, the project demonstrates great design changes made, esepcially the resdesign pertaining to the toggle to show questions. Incorportating it in the heatgrid helps better readability. The adjustments in the cell sizes make it much clearer and visible for the viewers. The team has also taken some time to add some graphs, although it feels a bit far fetched as it does not sepcify much information clearly. The code changes, and the awareness of resuability shown by the team is commendable. The team has also added functionality to be able to view grades for each rounds. The UI overall is made more intuitive and well designed.  Also, there is front-end code to calculate review scores, which may be a DRY violation; the scores are also calculated in the back end and should be passed to the front end.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page is organised well, the structure looks decent and the details encapsulated are good. The changelog, showing their implementation is exceptionally well written, good code snippets and explanations are provided throughout. The goal and approach is clearly stated and well understood.. The screenshots of the code are pretty large; using searchable text with smaller fonts would've made the page easier to read. They could have added more images, especially the change done for toggle feature, in displaying quesitons as it is drastically different (in a good way) from the current one.

Slated to possibly be merged: This code is eminently mergeable IF the issues mentioned in feedback are fixed.  It seemingly would be pretty easy to fix them.
Feedback on project:
The team has implemented practical improvements to the code structure and functionality, significantly enhancing maintainability and usability. By refactoring the assessments_for method into smaller, single-purpose methods and introducing scopes, they have improved code readability and organization. The addition of new accessor and retrieval methods, such as latest_responses_for_team_by_reviewer and response_count, streamlines access to key data. Furthermore, the safe_delete method reinforces data integrity.

Their suite of RSpec tests effectively covers validations, scopes, and custom methods, reflecting a strong commitment to ensuring reliable functionality.

Suggestions for improvement:

1. Naming Conventions: Some method names could be made more idiomatic to Ruby. Avoid conjunctions in identifiers, as they can hinder readability and don't align with typical Ruby naming practices.
2. Polymorphic Design: Instead of checking the type of a response map to determine if a review is submitted, consider overriding a method in ReviewResponseMap that inherits from ResponseMap. This adheres to the principles of object-oriented design and improves extensibility.
3. Invalid ID Handling: Clarify the definition of invalid_id. If it represents a negative number, ensure this is explicitly defined and documented in the code.
Feedback on design doc: The Wikipedia page is well-structured, with each section organized to guide readers logically through the project objectives, implementation steps, and results. The page provides a clear explanation of the primary goals and the key methods used in the reimplementation process, allowing readers to understand both the purpose and the technical approach taken. The inclusion of code snippets and examples effectively illustrates the changes made, supporting comprehension for both technical and non-technical audiences. However, adding more detailed explanations for complex methods or decisions would enhance clarity. For example, there is a narrative about the enhancements that have been made.  But there is no description of the next few methods that follow.  Overall, the page is informative and aligns well with the project’s objectives.

Project name: Implement testing for new Bookmarks Controller
Slated to possibly be merged: No.  Big DRY problems in the testing code.  If they were fixed, it would be OK to merge.
Feedback on project:
The team has implemented testing for the `BookmarksController`, achieving 100% test coverage, which exceeds the 90% requirement. Around 20 test cases cover basic CRUD operations, ratings, and score calculations. While these tests help validate core functionality, there are several areas where the testing could be improved. For instance, there is a focus on user roles (TAs, instructors, administrators) despite the fact that only students are allowed to create or update bookmarks. These tests are unnecessary and result in a DRY violation. The tests should focus specifically on student actions and ensure more relevant edge cases and performance scenarios are covered.

However, including authorization utilities in the pull request is unnecessary and could lead to merge conflicts if versions differ. It's important to avoid reintroducing existing code that’s already part of the repository. While the project meets the basic functional requirements, the testing could be more focused and better aligned with the project's user roles and performance considerations.
Feedback on design doc: The purpose of the project is described well, as are the design decisions made by the team. Changes to the code are made in several pull requests, which are linked to from a table.  That makes it easy to see how each change was achieved, but it would not have been so heavyweight if these changes had been made as separate commits to a repo, rather than separate pull requests.  While the initial changes are described well in prose, later changes are just presented in tables, with no overall description preceding them.  Testing is described well, but the screenshots should have been cropped on the right side of the page so that the text size could have been increased and made more readable.

Project name: Reimplement the Question hierarchy as Item hierarchy
Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project:
The UI is well-structured and aesthetically consistent, providing a user-friendly experience. Variable names are meaningful and intuitive, supporting clarity. 
The reimplementation keeps the design consistent, which is crucial for usability and aligns with the project’s objectives. This approach contributes to a smoother user experience and a more polished interface. Common elements like buttons, input fields, and form validation logic could be further abstracted into reusable components, enhancing maintainability and consistency. The UI would benefit from better error handling, such as loading states, fallback messages for empty data, or user-friendly error alerts. This would provide a more robust experience and reduce potential confusion in case of data-loading issues or network errors. Ensure user-visible text is clean and free of underscores to enhance readability and professionalism. Instead of using terms like "questions," refer to them as "items" throughout the UI to maintain consistent terminology. Additionally, dropdown menus should be sized to fit their content without excessive space, as oversized dropdowns can disrupt the visual balance of the interface and may create a less polished experience. This attention to detail will enhance usability, maintain consistency, and contribute to a more visually appealing interface.There are very few proper comments in the code and minimal code change has been done. There is testing for the front end, not comprehensive but good.
Feedback on design doc: This page contains a lot of useful items.  It describes the principles followed in the reimplementation and details the test plan.  It attempts to describe how the Strategy pattern benefits the implementation.  Although it shows one code example, it doesn't cover the actual code in any detail.  It would  be better if it showed some of the code and explained how it was implemented.

Slated to possibly be merged: Possibly, though some renaming would be needed, as explained in feedback to the team.
Feedback on project:
The reimplementation of suggestion_controller.rb demonstrates a commendable effort by the team in adhering to the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP),* modularizing key operations, and improving the clarity and maintainability of the code. The robust privilege checks and logical separation of methods highlight a strong understanding of the controller’s functionality. However, areas for improvement include addressing redundancy by refactoring common privilege checks, such as moving the check_ta_privileges method into a before_action filter to simplify method calls. Additionally, the code would benefit from comprehensive inline comments for custom methods to enhance readability and understanding, as well as improved test coverage to verify all critical and edge-case functionalities. Enhancing these areas will further elevate the implementation to a professional standard.
For example, the check_ta_privileges method can be moved to a before_action filter like so::index], with the method implementation being:
private def check_ta_privileges
  unless current_user_has_ta_privileges?
    render json: { error: 'Permission Denied' }, status: :forbidden
  end
end

*The code that calls the mailer should be in a different class in the mailers folder.  Sending mail in the class that implements suggestions is an SRP violation, just like generating the report on employees in last week's 517 class.

"privilege_helper" should be renamed "authorization_helper" to match the name in the current Expertiza.

"sign_team_up_to_assignment_and_topic!"  "assignment_and" is redundant; you are coding an action for an assignment, so anything that is done will relate to that assignment.  "sign_team_up" would be better.

Very clean code, but comments are lacking.
Feedback on design doc: This document provides a good discsussion of the objectives.  However, the Development Strategy section is blank.  It does not say anything about the code or the test plan.  It is about 1/3 finished.

Feedback on project: The team has shown strong technical skills in refactoring and improving the student task view page. They've made the interface much more user-friendly by adding clear timeline visualizations and status indicators that help students easily track their deadlines. The code is well-organized using React and TypeScript, showing they understand how to build maintainable software.  I don't understand why "handleSendEmail" isn't just "sendEmail".
Feedback on design doc: The screenshots do a good job of depicting the UI designed by this team.  The code is effectively described in prose.  The files are described well, except that StudentTask.tsx is so long that it would be better to break it up into chunks and describe each chunk in prose.  When Timeline improvements are described, it would've been useful juxtapose "before" and "after" screenshots so it would be easy to see the improvement.  More could have been said about testing.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project:
The team has done a good job reimplementing SignUpTopic as ProjectTopic. They implemented the ProjectTopic and SignedUpTeam models, along with the ProjectTopic controller, in this project. In ProjectTopic, they created methods to manage team signups for topics, such as save_waitlist_entry, slot_available, assign_topic_to_team, and find_team_project_topics. They also implemented methods in SignedUpTeam, including drop_off_team_waitlists, find_first_existing_sign_up, create_signed_up_team, delete_signed_up_team, and get_team_id.The team updated the CRUD functionality of the ProjectTopic controller, linking it with the new model methods. Much of the signup functionality has been effectively implemented with clean, well-organized code that follows the DRY principle. They also tested the controller functionality with Swagger UI, which is impressive. However, they haven't properly tested the models with RSpec test cases. Adding more comments to their methods could further improve readability. Although they used the same schema for the ProjectTopic and SignedUpTeam tables as in the old Expertiza repository, they significantly reimplemented the methods without simply copying from the old repository.

Upon looking at the documentation, I wonder why a get_waiting_teams method is needed.  Wouldn't it be simpler to have a longest_waiting_team?  And current_available_slots should just be a db access; no need to modify any count.  Similarly, it's not clear why a "collect_due_dates" method is needed.  If needed, the Ruby naming convention would suggest naming it simply "due_dates".
Feedback on design doc: This is a good description of the problem statement and a good discussion of the design goals.  The implementation plan is described in some detail, but unfortunately there is no discussion of how the code is written. The test plan is presented well, but again, the RSpec code is not provided.  It would be acceptable to describe the code briefly and provide links to the files that were written.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project: This reimplementation project focuses on renaming and restructuring the ResponsesController to adhere to Rails conventions, improve modularity, and eliminate redundant functionality. The student identifies and addresses specific areas needing reimplementation, including renaming response_controller.rb to responses_controller.rb to follow naming standards, breaking down the edit and delete methods to isolate non-CRUD operations, and combining the assign_action_parameters and set_content methods into a single, cohesive function. For the edit method, they effectively relocate sorting and team-checking logic to the Response model and application_controller.rb, enhancing separation of concerns. Additionally, the student reduces multiple calls to sort_questions, renaming it to sort_items for clarity, and creates a dedicated helper method for response locking to eliminate repetitive code. By updating methods like questionnaire_from_response_map to accept parameters, they ensure greater reusability and conformity to DRY principles. Clear comparisons between the old and new code versions illustrate each change’s purpose, demonstrating a well-thought-out approach to implementing efficient, modular code. To further improve this project, the student should concentrate on how to avoid code scattering by ensuring that related functionalities remain cohesive and logically grouped, making it easier for future developers to locate and understand the complete functionality within the ResponsesController. For example, consolidating sorting, team-checking, and response-locking functionalities into a dedicated service or helper would reduce code scattering and simplify maintenance.  Comments for methods like `instructor_review` and `edit` need to be rewritten to clearly explain their purpose and logic. The schema.rb file needn't be included in the pull request, since it needs be updated by the migration files. Incorporating these changes will further align the controller with DRY, SOLID principles, and overall codebase standards.
Feedback on design doc: The student’s wiki page is detailed and systematically covers the steps taken to reimplement the ResponsesController by breaking down each identified task and providing specific examples. They clearly describe the motivations behind each change, such as renaming methods for clarity, consolidating redundant code, and adhering to DRY principles. The student effectively illustrates each modification by comparing the old and new code versions. It would be better, though, to describe the code changes and motivation in prose before showing the screenshots.  One improvement could be to include additional visual aids, such as screenshots of testing results, to clearly showcase how these updates ensure functionality and adherence to Rails conventions. Overall, the documentation provides valuable insights into the refactoring process, offering a clear and well-organized resource for understanding the changes made to the ResponsesController.

Feedback on project: The project demonstrates an excellent implementation of the logging mechanism with all required features. Each log level (info, warn, error, fatal, debug) was correctly set up to direct messages into separate files, and the ExpertizaLogFormatter ensured consistent formatting, including essential details like timestamps, origin IP and severity level. However, there are no comments that explain the different log levels, and there should be. The Logging concern effectively captures CRUD operations, making data changes traceable. The use of the LoggerMessage class was well-executed, allowing custom messages to include specific details such as user's unity_id, and message for additional context. The code is well-organized, readable, and maintainable, following best practices for logging. A minor deduction was made as there is slight room for extending functionality, such as adding configurable logging options. Overall, this project meets the requirements exceptionally well and showcases a strong understanding of effective logging practices.  Another concern is that if all controller actions are logged, then each review-tag assignment will produce a record that duplicates the info in the review tag.  So it seems that there should be a way to exclude frequent operations from being logged.
Feedback on design doc: The page is a well-organized and detailed overview of the Expertiza logging project, capturing its goals, structure, and key components. It introduces the ExpertizaLogger, ExpertizaLogFormatter, and LoggingConcern clearly, explaining how they establish consistent, automated logging across all CRUD operations. The document is thoughtful in its proposed enhancements, such as standardizing log levels and error messages for better observability. Plans for comprehensive testing and documentation reflect strong software practices, ensuring future maintainability.  The example of a comprehensive test was described as, "One example of a testing method is this one, which we've recently written."  More prose description, describing what was being tested and how  the test was coded, would have been helpful.  I am not sure why the document ended with a Plan of Work, given that the work was supposed to be completed when the document was submitted.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project:
The project was to reimplement grades_controller, but the team has refactored the existing grades_controller instead. They made progress in refactoring `grades_controller.rb` by improving modularity and readability, with helper methods reducing redundancy and aligning with the DRY principle. However, the controller still handles excessive responsibilities, violating the Single Responsibility Principle. Functions like `user_ta_privileges?` and `user_student_privileges?` should leverage existing code in the codebase rather than defining new methods, which introduces redundancy. Similarly, the `vector` function redefines functionality that is already available in `response.rb`, `response_map.rb`, and `assignment_team.rb`, which is a clear DRY violation. Reusing existing methods from these models would simplify the controller and maintain consistency.
Additionally, comments for methods like instructor_review and edit need to be rewritten to clearly explain their purpose and logic. Removing the schema.rb file from the pull request is essential to maintain version control hygiene. Incorporating these changes will further align the controller with DRY, SOLID principles, and overall codebase standards.
Feedback on design doc: The title of the page is "Reimplement grades_controller," but the discussion seems to be describing a refactoring of the existing implementation.  The problem statement is good, and the rationale for changes is very good.  The code snippet, while it has a good number of comments, is not very readable because it is in a monochrome fixed-width font.  It would be more effective to link to the Github code page and possibly include a screenshot, assuming that the code was large enough to be readable.

Slated to possibly be merged: Probably not.  The basic UI is reasonable, but quite a few changes need to be made before it could be included.
Feedback on project: The team has taken a thoughtful approach to rebuilding the grades/view_team page, showing strong technical skills throughout their work. They've made smart design choices that really improve how users interact with the system - the dual dropdown menus and round filters make it much easier for users to find exactly what they need. Breaking down the code into separate components (Statistics.tsx, Filters.tsx, ShowReviews.tsx) shows clear, organized thinking, and their careful handling of reviewer anonymity demonstrates maturity in dealing with sensitive academic data. The visual improvements to the table design, from better typography to clearer borders, make information easier to read and understand, while staying true to Expertiza's familiar look and feel. However, there is too much whitespace in the modified design.  Columns should be no wider than necessary.    It also seems that the new UI lacks links to show the reviews.  It's important that the viewer be able to find the reviews quickly.  For viewing the different rounds, I would prefer headings that could be clicked on to show or hide a particular round, rather than a dropdown that selects which round to show.  The existing design shows the name of the reviewer if invoked by an instructor, TA, admin, or super-admin.  The new design removes this.  It needs to be included.
Feedback on design doc: The page does a good job of showing what the project has accomplished.  The screenshots show both the existing and new UIs.  The new code is described, and the files are linked to.  Often the new code is described in prose. Once, three files are listed ... Statistics.tsx, Filters.tsx, and ShowReviews.tsx and there's no text describing what each does. But in other cases, each file is described.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, it should be merged.  DueDate should work fine, but subclasses AssignmentDueDate and TopicDueDate won't work, and will have to be reimplemented.
Feedback on project: Code looks clean, despite containing a lot of class methods, which in this case, may be justifiable.  In general, comments are adequate, but should explain what "parent" is.  I do not understand the "max_round" parameter of the set method, and it is not explained by a method comment.  It is not possible to override a class method, yet that's what TopicDueDate purports to do.  Overall, I am not confident that these subclass implementations are well motivated or correct. Tests are quite comprehensive, but do not include any tests of the AssignmentDueDate and TopicDueDate subclasses.
Feedback on design doc: The page is a good description of what changes were made in the original code.  However, it neither described the new code, or presented or linked to it.  The page should document what was written, not just what was changed.

README.md        194        file        2024-10-2921:23:16-0400
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes; requested changes have been made correctly.
Feedback on project: The UI for view submissions has been implemented according to the provided instructions. 2 Views were created as part of the project, the main submissions view as well as the history view and both the views were linked. All the functionalities of the View submissions work as expected. The pagination and the search functionalities have been integrated and testing as part of this project.  The TypeScript code follows conventions and is cleanly written with the required comments wherever necessary. Tests have been added to cover all the functionalities.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki lists the goals of the project and all the new files added and modified for the same. Gives information about what each file does. Screenshots of code snippets to explain the functionality is present. It would also have been good to provide links to each new file, and an overall description of what the user interface shows.  As it stands, a reader might not know the purpose of "List submissions."  A clear flow of how the flow looks and how to test is mentioned with screenshots. A detailed description of the tests have been mentioned.
