Slated to possibly be merged: Maybe.  The Impersonation window in the nav bar is much too big, though.  This would not be hard to change.  Also, the current UI has an impersonation window in the top nav bar, and it would be good to duplicate this functionality in the new version.
Feedback on project: The project demonstrates a well-designed user interface for the impersonation feature in the Expertiza application. The team has implemented efficient user search functionality with debouncing and autocomplete, as well as secure JWT token management to ensure a seamless impersonation experience. The addition of the impersonation banner in the navbar is a helpful visual cue for users; however, it is too wide.  It only needs to say, "Impersonating" and then give the username. One area for potential improvement is the width of the autocomplete suggestions, which could be adjusted to better match the input box.  Another is to provide a field in the top navigation bar to impersonate a user as in the current system, assuming that the window is wide enough to display it.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page for the UI for Impersonate User feature is comprehensive, well-structured, and offers clear explanations of the implementation process. The detailed component breakdown and design patterns (such as Command and Facade) provide valuable insights into the code structure and design decisions. The Facade pattern is used in the code, but I don't think the Command pattern is, because the action (e.g., impersonating a user) is carried out immediately after the command is seen.  The page launches into a list of components without an overall explanation of what is being implemented or how the pieces fit together.  It would be better to put that first, and list the components and files later.  The walkthrough of the impersonation UI is effective in showcasing how the feature works, including the success and failure scenarios. However, it would be helpful to include code snippets for key functionalities, especially around JWT token management, to offer a deeper understanding of the logic behind the implementation.

Slated to possibly be merged: Institutions UI looks good, though there's not much to it. It could probably be merged.  I don't understand how the notifications UI is intended to be used.  Why would someone want to send out notifications about class cancellations and exams through Expertiza?  This seems like an attempt to make Expertiza into a full LMS, which is not something we have the desire or resources to do.  Therefore, only the Institutions UI should be merged.
Feedback on project: The institution and notification UI is streamlined and intuitive, with well-organized create/update boxes capturing essential details. A prompt on the delete action prevents accidental clicks, and authentication checks ensure only higher roles access the page. They’ve also added a notification badge on the student menu, highlighting new notifications to catch students’ attention and direct them to their notification page. However, it's not clear why one would want to provide notifications through Expertiza of events such as exams and class cancellations.  This seems to be an attempt to build full LMS functionality into Expertiza, which is not in the scope of the Expertiza project.  Similarly, it's not clear why authorization for institutions would be managed in the front end.  Back-end code (specifically, the action_allowed method) is responsible for authorizing all other operations in Expertiza controllers.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page is well-organized, covering essential sections like design goals, implementation details, and design patterns. Each crucial change is linked to its commit, making it easy to track the impact of individual updates. Additionally, the inclusion of a test video helps illustrate the UI workflows and enhances understanding of the functionality. However, prose descriptions of the changes or additions to code would enhance clarity and facilitate a deeper understanding of the implementation.

Slated to possibly be merged: No way!  The UI makes poorly thought out changes to the current scheme, and contains much too much whitespace.
Feedback on project: The UI implemented is well-designed and keeps the essence of the original structure. There are subtle changes like the start mark for students to identify their own topic. Both the views students and instructors are clean and cohesive to their purposes. Rather than the star marker, I prefer highighting the whole line, as is done in the current UI.  The current UI also displays the selected topic at the top of the page, which serves the same purpose as providing a legend. Along with it, the addition of the Topics button in navigation bar is understood given the backend was not set, still needs to reverted as it violates the design for other pages, which do not have a way to select a different assignment at the top of a page. There is too much whitespace in all columns of the admin view.  It is not clear what the meaning of the checkmarks is in the Topic Name(s) column. The current instructor UI has a red "x" that will drop the team from the topic if it is clicked.  The new UI has a check mark after the topic and after the teams signed up for the topic.  The meaning of these check marks is not clear.  There is a large amount of whitespace in every column, which should be removed to make the UI easier to read, especially when resized.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page is structured well, the details about the goals, objectives and the procedure is clear. The images included comparing the previous and new state of the UI is a good touch to help users understand the implementation better. The approach and rationale for the design has been specified. Instead of just listing files that were changed or created, it would be better to describe the changes in each, and provide links to the code.

Slated to possibly be merged: No. The UI is unreadable and not well thought out.
Feedback on project: The UI is well structured, but the components, as illustrated on the wiki page, are too small to be seen clearly. It would require an uncomfortably large window to display all of the columns.  It contains a listing of "revisions" whose meaning is unclear.  The page is structured with modular components that ensure consistent design, reusability, and easy organization. Data filtering works well for all columns, but the UI for the filter could be improved. The code is well-structured and leverages React’s component architecture effectively, though additional inline documentation and prop validation would enhance maintainability. The project also includes fallback messages for scenarios like an empty task list, though edge cases like handling corrupted or partially loaded data could be improved. Adding unit tests for these cases would help cover all scenarios. Finally, small UI enhancements like hover effects or subtle animations could further improve interactivity and user engagement.
Feedback on design doc: It was helpful to see screenshots of the UI, but the first one is too small to be readable. The code snippets are quite long, with minimal explanation, but the links to the code are helpful. These are the only two weaknesses; otherwise, the page explains the project well.

Slated to possibly be merged: Very doubtful.  This team has made unilateral decisions on organization and functionality that should be made for the app as a whole.  Their UI does not seem to be well designed.  If that could be fixed, the code itself is OK.  But if it's going to be fixed, why not redo it from the start?
Feedback on project: The Questionnaire UI has been implemented well according to the provided instructions. The expand and collapse functionality for the questionnaire component works smoothly, and both pagination and search features have been correctly included. The TypeScript code follows conventions and is cleanly written. However, the pagination component should be modified so that it remains hidden when there are fewer than 10 questionnaires. This change will improve the interface by removing unnecessary elements when pagination isn’t needed. Additionally, they don't have necessary comments for the code.
Feedback on design doc: This is a detailed prose explanation of the UI.  The "Expandable Sections" paragraph says that THIS PROJECT categorizes questionnaires into types.  That is not correct; the types are defined in the Expertiza code and their names must be used exactly in the UI.  Pagination should be common across all UI components.  It's probably not good design to introduce it specially for this project.  I do not think that there should be "Expand all" and "Collapse all" buttons, but rather the same button should toggle between expanding and collapsing all.  It also should be smaller, not taking up a lot of screen space.  The screenshots are helpful, but it would be even better if the text were searchable.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.  The UI is not well thought out.  The Instructor column is unnecessary, since in most cases, an instructor will be listing his/her own courses.  Same for the Institution.  It is not at all clear to me why there need to be search boxes for every field.  The current Manage Courses UI allows a course to be clicked on to display the assignments below it.  This UI does not allow for that and it would be more difficult to retrofit it than it would be to start over.  This project is simply not useful.
Feedback on project: The UI implementation is well-organized, and the code follows TypeScript conventions effectively. The search functionality and pagination make it easy to find and manage courses, which adds to the overall usability. The confirmation modals for copying and deleting courses, along with the action icons and tooltips, enhance clarity and help prevent user errors.  However, the "Add Courses" button should be updated to red or blue color to maintain consistency, and the text "Add Courses" on the button can be removed to avoid redundancy. Additionally, copyHandler method contain more comments than necessary, which could be streamlined for improved readability.  The Select an Instructor functionality is unlikely to be useful, as instructors always create their own courses. In the case that they can't, an administrator could impersonate them to create the course.  The implementors seem to have designed their own icons.  I'd rather reuse the current icons. If new icons are created, there would need to be a way to insure that they were used across the system
Feedback on design doc: The documentation shows the new UI and explains its functionality.  It contains links to code at appopriate places.  The page explains the design patterns that were used.  This is good, but the reference to Composite is incorrect; if it were Composite, a course could be nested inside a course, which is not possible.  I'm also not sure that the Tooltip is an instance of Decorator.  It is Decorator only if the same actions can be performed on an object with or without the tooltip. Similarly, I don't believe the descriptions of Template Method or Factory are accurate.  But other than the icons and design patterns, the documentation is excellent.

Feedback on project: The Mentor-Meeting Management feature is thoughtfully structured, leveraging helper methods to keep controller actions clean and focused, which improves readability and modularity. They have added emails at appropriate times. The inclusion of clear, descriptive method names aids in understanding the logic flow, and DRY principles are followed by reusing code blocks effectively. The implementation also demonstrates good use of validation checks, ensuring data integrity across the system. Some controller methods handle multiple responsibilities, which could be moved to service classes for a clearer separation of concerns. The test coverage should be increased to ensure robustness across edge cases and maintain the reliability of the new features. And the pull request is not to the correct repo. Other than that, the project looks great!
Feedback on design doc: The rationale for the changes is described quite well.  It is good to illustrate them with screenshots, though in this case, the text is so small that it is hard to read it.  I would suggest using a different font (perhaps typewriter font) to set off identifier names that appear in prose descriptions.  When you describe _team.html.erb, you allude to what a "previous group did."  This should be explained in more detail, since most readers won't want to look at documentation from a previous project.  I would prefer searchable text snippets. One way would be to link to the commit that made the change you are describing.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project:
The code appears to be pretty clean.  There are good method comments for most methods.  Commenting within methods is of varying usefulness.  The testing seems to be deficient, though, because it only checks that the appropriate users can run the code and that the right methods are called; it doesn't check that the displayed results are correct.

I have tried the deployment on several assignments, some of which involved bidding, and some that didn't.  I can't get it to work on any of them.  The "Show bids by priority" button is there, regardless of whether bidding was ever used.  If I click on it (whether or not the assignment involved bidding), I either get a walkback or a badly formatted list of topics and number of teams signed up.  If I click the button a second time, I get "NoMethodError in Bidding#bidding_summary".
Feedback on design doc: The page describes the changes with a table and links to commits.  That is a very clear way of presenting the changes, though in the first table, the links to the first and third changes go to exactly the same commit.  The table also contains prose justifications for the changes.  Tests are described well.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, after fixing the column spacing and weird footer text.
Feedback on project: This project addresses a persistent source of confusion within Expertiza, that the "name" field for an account actually holds its username, not the actual name of the user.   This is the legacy of a gem that was used when the code was started in 2007.  It has finally been fixed.  Merging it will be a little scary, because the changes affect 244 files, but the changes are largely pro forma, so if they pass--and reviewers indicate they do--the right choice seems to merge.  The only file changed in any other way is users_controller, which adds the ability to paginate a list of users or not.  This code seems clean.  However, in the display, there is no space between columns, unlike the current implementation.  The footer also has the text "Previous Label  1 2 3 Page Gap 179 180 Next Label", which doesn't make much sense, but is inherited from the current implementation.
Feedback on design doc: This page does a very good job of explaining the changes made.  Changes are clearly described in prose.  There are links to commits that made them. Code snippets are provided in a way that is searchable, rather than pasting in image.  Testing should have been described in more detail, however.

Feedback on project: The migration from "users" to "participants" in the model has been successfully completed with proper updates to associations and migrations. Methods have been effectively refactored and follow SOLID and DRY principles, while extensive tests have been written for some files. However, several issues need attention: the delete method name lacks clarity about what's being deleted, some comments still reference "users" instead of "participants", and teams_participant.rb contains multiple confusing methods related to node removal that need design improvement for better transparency. The method self.first_participant_for_team appears unused and can be removed, while documentation/comments explaining the necessity of add_accepted_invitee_to_team and find_team_id in TeamParticipant needs to be included.
Feedback on design doc: The documentation on the refactoring of teams_user.rb is very good and provides a clear overview of the rationale, objectives, and specific changes made during the refactor. It effectively explains the main goal of changing users to participants in the model, highlighting the need for consistency across the application. Additionally, the documentation outlines improvements in code readability, adherence to SOLID and DRY principles, and details on method renaming for clarity.  It shows changes via a table and links to commits, which provides great clarity. Code coverage is covered in great detail, but test cases are described in a total of two lines.  It should explain what tests are used and why they are important.

Feedback on project: The team’s refactoring demonstrates clear improvements, though there are still areas for polish. Some inconsistencies remain, such as varying usage of "sign up" and "Signup." Comments should be refined to explain complex logic rather than restate what’s already evident in the code. Additionally, avoid creating a new `assignment` object; instead, rely on existing references to improve code efficiency. Since this project continues into Program 4, focusing on these aspects will enhance clarity and maintainability for future progress.
Feedback on design doc: The document provides a thorough and detailed explanation of the refactoring task, addressing all the necessary aspects outlined in the project description. It highlights the issues with naming consistency, instance variables, method improvements, and adherence to DRY principles. However, the code snippets are too long, and in a single color (black), which makes them hard to read.  It would be better to link to individual commits that make the changes.  The test cases could have been described in more detail, and links to the code could have been provided.  For manual testing, it would have been helpful to include screenshots.

Slated to possibly be merged: Code can be merged.  Someone should still look over the comments and make them more insightful, perhaps with the aid of an LLM.
Feedback on project:
The project successfully addressed several objectives, particularly in improving code readability by breaking down long methods, and moving some utility methods out of StudentTask to improve modularity. The method renaming in this project shows a clear effort to improve the clarity and expressiveness of the code. Renaming methods like get_due_date_data to retrieve_due_dates is a good step, as it removes vague terms like "data" and makes the method’s purpose more explicit. However, there are still a few method names that could be further refined to ensure consistency and clarity.  Also, a lot of comments just repeat what the method name + parameters tell us, rather than giving further information on the purpose of the method.
The refactored class is more organized, follows object-oriented principles, and is easier to work with, especially for future updates or debugging. Adding unit tests has also ensured that the new structure remains functional and reliable.
Feedback on design doc: The documentation for the refactoring project is comprehensive and well-organized, providing a clear overview of the changes made to the StudentTask class. It effectively explains the rationale behind breaking down the large, static methods into smaller, more manageable ones, adhering to object-oriented principles like SRP and DRY. The documentation shows before and after snippets for each change.  However, it doesn't explain why the changes were made.  Additionally, it covers improvements in code organization, such as moving utility methods to relevant modules, and updating test cases to ensure the new functionality works as expected. Although the documentation mentions updating test cases, more detail on the types of tests added or modified (unit, integration, etc.) and how test coverage was expanded would strengthen the explanation. It would also be beneficial to show results from testing or code coverage reports to emphasize the robustness of the changes. The explanation of the tests is in a fixed-width font, whereas identifier names in the running text are in the regular sans-serif font.  It would be better if it were vice versa (it's good to set off identifier names from surrounding text).  Overall, the documentation serves as a helpful guide to the refactoring process, ensuring the project’s objectives and outcomes are easy to understand and follow.

Feedback on project: This refactoring project focuses on reducing method length and cyclomatic complexity, enhancing readability, and ensuring functionality through thorough testing. The student effectively addresses specific methods needing refactoring, including get_team_color, check_submission_state, list_hyperlink_submission, and sort_reviewer_by_review_volume_desc, by breaking down complex code into simpler, modular methods and renaming variables (e.g., rspan to row_number) to improve clarity. Consistent formatting updates and alignment of test files with refactored methods further strengthen code quality. Additional improvements could be made by adding descriptive comments for key variables, such as clarifying what color represents, and renaming response_count to response_round_count for accuracy. Expanding the comment for update_since_last_submission would also provide clearer context for complex logic, aiding future maintainability.
Feedback on design doc: The documentation for this project is thorough and well-organized, providing a clear comparison between the old and new versions of the code. It effectively highlights the redundancy and complexity issues present in the original code, illustrating the need for refactoring with specific examples. The student includes detailed explanations for each refactored method, describing not only the changes made but also the rationale behind them, which greatly enhances the documentation’s clarity. I would suggest, though, that the explanation of the change come before the code snippets rather than afterwards. Additionally, the documentation covers renaming efforts, code formatting improvements, and testing updates, demonstrating a comprehensive approach to maintaining functionality and readability. One area for improvement would be to include more examples of renamed variables and methods, as well as prose descriptions of what the tests do, to provide clearer insight into how naming conventions and test coverage were enhanced during the refactoring process. Overall, the wiki page serves as a valuable guide to the refactoring process, making it easy for others to understand the project’s impact and benefits.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project: This refactoring effectively breaks down long, complex methods into concise functions, enhancing code readability and maintainability. The modularization improves Single Responsibility adherence, making each method focused and reducing redundancy, which reflects good OODD practice. The code now follows a cleaner structure, which aids future debugging and testing. This refactor increases the ease of collaboration and demonstrates attention to clarity and reuse, a strong improvement over the original structure. However, further improvements could involve encapsulating related data and behavior within dedicated classes or modules, reducing controller responsibilities. Additionally, error handling could be made more robust, potentially with custom error classes. Testing coverage should be expanded to ensure the new modular methods perform as expected, supporting further maintenance and scalability of the code.
Feedback on design doc: This document gives a fairly detailed description of the changes that have been made in the code.  However, it is missing code excerpts, or links to commits, that actually make those changes.  It would be better if code snippets were included, ideally by linking to commits where each change was made.  This would avoid requiring the reader to have one window open on the code while reading the document.  Another issue is that code snippets and filenames are in the regular sans-serif font, whereas it would be better if they were in a different font, perhaps a typewriter font.  The test plan says what is covered, but it would be more instructive if it described the actual conditions being tested.  Rather than having a single "screenshots" section, I suggest that the screenshots be included at relevant points in the overall discussion.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project:
The team has worked on refactoring assignment methods such as create, edit, update, delete, etc. However, some parts of the functionlity could be moved to the assignment model. They have fixed test cases to align with the updated code in assignments_controller.rb. assignment_created is not the best variable name because it suggests a state or boolean (e.g., "Has the assignment been created?") rather than an instance of the Assignment object itself. A more precise name here would reflect that it holds an assignment object, not just a creation state (e.g., "created_assignment"). They have simplified Assignment and due date assignment logic. The method name query_participants does not clearly convey its purpose. "Query" implies data retrieval, but this method checks for missing participants and triggers an alert if any are missing. Consider adding this functionality to the method you created, alert_missing_participants. All courrences of the word "check" in a method name have been removed. It should be Verified that removing the path method does not impact any other parts of the application.
There is no evidence that the team understands the code they are refactoring.  All refactorings are very local, e.g., changing variable names used in the immediate vicinity of their definition.  Some of the names are an improvement.  But further improvement is possible, e.g., "exist_assignment" has been changed to "assignment_created", but "new_assignment" would be a better name.  Some of the edits are in particularly unclear sections of the code.  It would be very helpful to have comments that explain what the code is doing, at a high level.  Running the code through an LLM might be helpful in figuring out what it is really doing.
Feedback on design doc: This is a mainly textual description of what the team has done on the project.  It does a good job of explaining the rationale for the changes.  It would be better if code snippets were included, ideally by linking to commits where each change was made.  This would avoid requiring the reader to have one window open on the code while reading the document.  Another issue is that code snippets and filenames are in the regular sans-serif font, while "current issues" and "plans" are in a fixed-width font.  It should be the other way around. In the test plan, it just says that the tests pass, and does not mention what is being tested.  If previous tests were used without change, it would be acceptable to copy the wiki pages that described them.

Feedback on project: The implementation from the team in terms of understanding was done correctly. There was a communication gap in which the project went on the lines of refactoring than reimplementation. The ideas, especially the changes made to make the code DRY were nicely done and the code passes all the tests. The team asked doubts and constantly provided updates on the progress. The work was equally divided amongst all the members, this was taken as a feedback after program 3.
Feedback on design doc: At the outset, I think the document should explain what advice in Expertiza is, and why it is used.  The method names, invalid_advice?, etc., are not clear.  What renders advice invalid? Without knowing this, I can't understand code that uses this method.  In the refactored edit_advice method, it's not clear what "the advice size if the advice size is <,> number of advices" might mean, nor is it clear why "advices" need to be sorted.  Instead of listing long strings of tests, it would be better to split them up with descriptions of each test.

Project name: Implement Front End for Student Task List
Feedback on project: [Feedback for this project has not yet been entered by the mentor and will be emailed later.]
Feedback on design doc: This is a good description of the code that was written.  The organization could be clearer if each point in the Design and Test Plan was treated as a separate MediaWiki section; then you would see the points in the Table of Contents.  Also, some code snippets are so long that they should have explanations interspersed.

Feedback on project: [Feedback for this project has not yet been entered by the mentor and will be emailed later.]
Feedback on design doc: Good overall description.  Function names beginning with "fetch" are not Ruby-like, but I think I have already mentioned this.  Good coverage of testing, except that the Postman screenshots are not legible.

Project name: Implement Frontend for the Review page
Feedback on project:
Yes, the enhanced UI has been a good example for this particular page, currently uses a seeded database but it should be good to merge once the functionalities are integrated with the backend.
Their color scheme assumes exactly 5 levels (1-5), whereas the min and max score can be set to arbitrary values by whoever creates the rubric, instead of that divide the number line between 0 and 1 into 5 segments of 0.2 each and used that to choose a color.
Feedback on design doc: The document begins abruptly, without explaining what the review front end does.  A number of principles are listed, but their impact on the project is unclear.  Patterns are listed, but their relevance to the refactorings done here is unclear.  In the Design section, the prose is good, but you should have used a numbered list instead of consecutive paragraphs.

Feedback on project: The routes have been created and effectively tested using both Postman and Swagger UI, ensuring their reliability. However, there seems to be some ambiguity surrounding the functionality of a few methods within the grades_controller. Nonetheless, the project correctly implements the intended functionality of the class.
Feedback on design doc: The prose is well written, but I wonder why Swagger has its own section and Postman testing is integrated into the Breakdown of Routes section.  I think treating the different kinds of tests the same way and describing how they relate to each other would have made the page easier to follow.

Feedback on project: The team did an excellent job on the reimplemented student_task_controller. The routes have been thoroughly tested using both Postman and Swagger UI, demonstrating seamless functionality. The codebase is clean and well-organized, with descriptive comments and comprehensive tests. The wiki page provides a thorough overview of the project's functionality. Overall, it's a commendable effort from the team.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the code to be written.  The outline is well thought out and the code snippets are of reasonable length.  Sometimes the rationale for the change is not clearly stated; e.g., for Controller, you start out by saying what you wrote, but not why you wrote it that way.

Feedback on project: The reimplemented page, along with its UI, looks polished, especially with the addition the buttons for viewing reviews for individual rounds. The team's effort in writing numerous tests showcases a commitment to quality assurance. While there are areas for improvement, the project successfully fulfills its expected functionality.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing code and linking to files in the repo.  Sometimes you pasted the file into the wiki page, which did not seem helpful.  I thought you could have done a better job indicating why code was needed. E.g. RoundSelectorCode section could start by saying why it is needed. And ditto for helper functions. The Phase 2 sections on the end seem like an afterthought.  Either they should have been integrated into the rest of the document, or a separate Phase 2 document should have been written.

Feedback on project: Each team member contributed equally. All tests have been successfully passed. The questionnaire_helper has a coverage of 78%, while the review_bids_helper has a coverage of 94%. However, additional tests should be added to ensure all units and edge cases are adequately covered. The build has passed on Github. Comments on the code would be helpful.
Feedback on design doc: The design document is well organized. As I mentioned at the demo, adjust_advice_size needs to be renamed, as its name is very confusing. Ditto for get_intelligent_topic_row_review_bids, which is even more obscure. When you mention expectations, it would be very good to give an example. I don't understand how a topic can be waitlisted. A team can be waitlisted for a topic, yes, but the topic itself is not waitlisted. So, while it is quite easy to understand how the document fits together, many of the items it covers could be better described

Feedback on project: The team made sure to ask all the questions they had about the progress, ensuring everyone understood the methods and how everything works. They divided the work evenly among all members. They covered all the methods and potential scenarios with thorough tests, which all succeeded. Coverage is increased to %100. The code comments are sensible. They also considered unit tests, even though the model isn't currently being called anywhere, but might be in the future.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very readable description of the changes made.  I think, though, that some of the screenshots are long, and would benefit by having line numbers so that the descriptions could refer to them.  IMO, too many methods start with "process_"  The problem is that the name does not tell you what the method is accomplishing; "process" is simply too vague.  Use of a method name like "process_" may even hide the fact that the method is doing two things, in which case it should be divided into two methods.

Feedback on project: The team implemented useful features like checkboxes for selecting columns, excluding unreviewed assignments from average calculations, displaying peer scores, and separating student names and IDs; however, there are still separate views for teammate/metareviews and project scores, excessive decimal precision in averages, and the name column could be wider than the username column. The code could benefit from more comments, and averages could potentially be calculated in mixins instead of controllers/models. The use of the bullet gem for efficient database queries, addition of diagrams on the wiki, and replacement of hyphens with en-dashes demonstrate attention to detail. This is one the best implemntation of this project.
Feedback on design doc: The document starts with a good overview.  However, the issues should be divided into categories for ease of understanding. The links to individual commits are very helfpul.  In some cases, I am surprised that so many files are involved and would appreciate an explanation of why that is the case.  The UI changes are well described.  I think that you could have come up with a more descriptive header than "Code Snippets".  Manual testing is well described, but is there an automated test plan?

Feedback on project:
I think the frontend was fairly simple to implement and was implemented properly with DRY principles.
The project can be merged.
Feedback on design doc: It would be helpful to have a prose description of what's on the user profile page, and also an indication early on of what needs to be changed.  The "Reimplementation Details" is a long list, and it would be helpful to have some organization, some reason to progress from one item to the next.  It would also be helpful to say specifically how the different design principles were used in this project.  The screenshots of the .tsx files are too long, relative to the descriptions.  The descriptions could refer to particular lines in the code files; that would make the prose easier to follow.  The testing section should be expanded.

Feedback on project:
Before merging there are a few changes to be made: The Heat map should be calculated in the backend.
Apart from that the project should be good to merge, the frontend is homogeneous and synchronised with the current reimplementation pages for expertiza.
Feedback on design doc: Overall, a very good job. The first several sections are very readable.  There was no need to paste in long code sequences, especially because you linked to them.  I would have liked to see you explain why dummy data is needed.  The test plan should be more detailed, saying how you tested, rather than just what you tested.

Feedback on project: Team implemented all the aspects except the pending invitations. The only thing i suggest is to finish the pending invitations part. But we can merge this code.
Feedback on design doc: Great job of describing the changes in prose, and linking to the commits that made them.  Similarly good coverage of manual testing, but the automated test plan is missing.

Feedback on project:
Implemented UI for participants page in React.

Implemented the page same as the current implementation with some robust changes.

CSS alignment could have been better.

Could have kept input instead of dropdown.

Could have added edit functionality
Feedback on design doc: Great job of describing the changes in prose, and linking to the commits that made them.  Similarly good coverage of manual testing, but the automated test plan is missing.

Feedback on project: The team was proactive and was thorough when working the implementation of the bookmarks controller. The code written is clear and very is easy to read with method comments to explain what the methods are doing. Test cases for the code are extensive and the swagger.yaml for the project has been generated successfully. Documentation was good but could have been more detailed. Overall, the team has done an excellent job.
Feedback on design doc: The problem statement is quite readable, but is missing one important thing: It does not say what bookmarks are in Expertiza, or how or why they are used.  Good use of SyntaxHighlight to display the code!  The Postman discussion is helpful, but should identify what behavior is expected when the token is pasted in, etc.

Feedback on project: The code is very clean and comprehensive.  The only thing that we would've suggested is move instructor_for(student) and teaching_assistant_for(student) to the authorization utilites, but that can be done in the future.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the changes to be made, and the rationale for them.  In most places, the level of detail is about right, but in the User section, there is too much code for such a short description; it would've been better to have prose describe individual methods.  It is good to cover Postman testing, but the code was too small and blurry to be readable.

Feedback on project: This is good code, but it is a small refactoring of the existing system, not a reimplementation for the new system. At only 35 lines, it is quite small for a first OSS + final project.
Feedback on design doc: The document describes very well the rationale for code changes in the reimplementation.  However, I would have liked to see it, and the project, focus more on the design of the code you were writing, since it is important to write the code cleanly and not be distracted by code smells in the current implementation.  That said, the document is very readable.  I would have liked to see more detail on testing; you just described what your focus was, without describing what your tests actually tested.

Feedback on project: The team demonstrated thorough testing using Swagger UI, covering various scenarios like login, uploading/removing hyperlinks and files, directory operations, and appropriate HTTP response codes. The code structure seems reasonable, with controller methods being concise and delegating to model methods. They have worked on the feedback given and converted file_helper class methods to instance methods, they also changed method names that had a conjuntion "and_create" to a suitable names. Test cases on the wiki could benefit from including their expected outcomes. Overall, the team showed good understanding of their code and testing approach, with a few areas for potential improvement.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes that were made. The code snippets are well organized, but the prose is not. You could have, for example, separated discussion of handling hyperlinks from discussion of handling files.  The test plan is well organized, but would benefit from more detail, e.g., what condition is tested to assure, e.g., that the user is a participant of this assignment?  It would probably also help to have some screenshots of the newly implemented functionality.

Feedback on project: The team has written code for all the questions types which now returns json data for the frontend to consume. They have  also extensively tested it out and the test cases are passing. However, there were a few methods that were reimplemented from the old system that the team could not answer questions about, demonstrating a lack of understanding. The code was missing comments for the methods and the documentation had a UML diagram which was incorrect.
Feedback on design doc: Very good introduction to the problem of implementing the hierarchy.  In the Enhancements section, though, it's not clear why the 6 issues are covered in the order that they are.  The "Screenshots for implementation in Phase 1" are described quite well, but were there any screenshots for Phase 2?  Overall, a very readable and informative document.

Feedback on project: There is a confusion with the Pull request. There are unnecessary files in the Pull Request that needs to be removed from the PR. The code is clean and the wiki page has documentation fr every method and patterns added. There is a DRY problem with create and update methods. Swagger UI tests were not shown in the UI, instead postman was used to test the controller methods.
Feedback on design doc: The description of the problem is well written.  It's not clear why all the design patterns were listed.  If they are going to be used in this project, it would be good to specify where and how.  It would also help to give a machine-readable version of the code changes, e.g., by linking to the individual commits in Github.  However, the prose description of changes made is useful.

Feedback on project: The project is not large, but it markedly improves the way that histories are recorded and presented in Expertiza.  The code is clean, but unfortunately, the build is not passing.
Feedback on design doc: This is one of the best-explained design documents I have seen.  The prose is easy to read and descriptive.  However, the overall organization is not clear, and seems to be an effort to graft Phase-2 changes onto a document written for Phase 1.  It would also help to give a machine-readable version of the code changes, e.g., by linking to the individual commits in Github.

Project name: Fix 'Back' link on 'New Late Policy' page
Feedback on project: Team did a good job on the project despite the issues faced. The functionality of saving a new late policy while creating an assignment is working without errors, which is commendable. However, there are a few areas that need attention. The navigation from the “New Late Policy” page to the correct assignment page needs to be corrected in the code and test cases. Currently, it redirects to the student’s assignment page instead of the instructor’s assignment page. Additionally, the capitalization on the Late Policy page could be regularized for better readability.
Feedback on design doc: Good introduction, explaining the importance of the project.  In Issue 3, the second screenshot seems to be unrelated to the issue at hand.  The first few changes are well described, although the screenshots are too small to be easily readable.  Variable renaming should be described in more detail.  Later changes, Fig. F and later, should be desribed in more detail.  The test plan for the second phase is described better than for the first phase, since it explicitly says what is tested.  I'm surprised that Design is down at the bottom of the page; it seems like it should be one of the first elements.

Feedback on project: The team did a good job with the project, they have redone this project after program 3 as there were issues with the code written. The method names ‘calculate_this’ and ‘calculate_that’ do not align with Ruby conventions, and renaming them to more descriptive and Ruby-like names would improve the readability and maintainability of your code. The table layout provides a clear overview of the project bidding statistics, but could benefit from narrower columns and info buttons for additional context. The well-structured and comprehensive test cases are a crucial strength of your software project. They have been redone after program 3 due to issues with the previously written code, which shows the team’s commitment to quality and continuous improvement. Additionally, adding comments to the test cases would provide a clear explanation and further enhance the understandability of the code.
Feedback on design doc: The document is quite readable, and the screenshots are well organized. Very helpful to describe code changes and link to the commits that made them.  The tests are described in reasonable detail. But the test plan is not described in any way.

Feedback on project: The team made a good effort in reducing the number of lines in the code to adhere to the DRY principle, which shows thoughtfulness in making the code more efficient. However, this seems to have led to some complexity in the code. For instance, the use of instance_variable_get might be difficult for others to understand. The renaming of methods to more descriptive names like action_allowed_for_students and user_participating_in_assignment? improves code readability, but the removal of tests and lack of new tests for the changes made is a concern. Despite the increase in test coverage, it’s important to ensure comprehensive functionality checks. Spotting a bug shows a keen eye for detail. However, the removal of log messages raised another bug. Furthermore, there are useless comments in the log_message method that need to be removed to maintain code cleanliness. Lastly, while it’s important to follow the DRY principle, it’s crucial to ensure that this doesn’t compromise the clarity of the code. The comments in the code could be more detailed to better explain the logic and decisions made. This would greatly help others understand and maintain the code in the future.
Feedback on design doc: Generally good descriptions. However, in Solutions, the "After refactoring" snippet is too much code without any explanations interspersed.  It is helpful to link directly to the commits that made changes you described.  The RSpec tests section is too short.  But overall, a very reaadable and helpful document.

Feedback on project: Expertiza is functional and tests pass, indicating a stable state. The team focused on refactoring long methods like add_reviewer and peer_review_strategy, removing hardcoded parameters, and renaming variables for clarity. But the code changes appear to be localized and lack clarity. The code is not intuitive and is hard to follow - comments explaining the context of methods would have helped. Despite the build passing, there are concerns about understanding the refactored methods, which could hinder code comprehension and maintenance.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the deficiencies in the existing code and how they were attacked by the project.  Some of what you wrote about how reviews are assigned, though, is not completely true; the algorithm doesn't take into account diversity of perspectives, for example.  But still, your page is much more readable than most. The presentation could have benefited from screenshots to show the working of the code, and a test plan is missing.

Slated to possibly be merged:
rmshah3 (Romil Shah)
 rvegada (Rushil Vegada)
 schangl (Sahil Kamlesh Changlani)
Feedback on project: The team generalized sort_reviewer_by_review_volume_desc for sorting by various metrics, extracted chart-generating methods into a new module, and renamed methods to follow ruby conventions but didn't really improve readability. The code that calculates a histogram of tagging intervals is cut off at 30 s. intervals, & there's no reason why. A lot of commented-out code has been left in. There wasn't any manual testing done, and the code wasn't runnable. About 5 times as many tests have been commented out as new tests inserted (only one). Only new test case was added using the test skeleton.
Feedback on design doc: The overall organization is unclear; it seems that there is documentation for two projects, but the description of the two projects is structured quite differently. It would have been helpful to describe what was illustrated by the Implementation screenshots, instead of just putting out a half-line title for each.  Phase 2 has a list of changes that begins at change #4, and it's not clear why.  The screenshots here have adequate descriptions prefixed.  The test plan is not described in enough detail.

Feedback on project: The code was not running and the team did not really describe the code in demo, long methods were broken down into smaller ones but there were no comments added on most of these changes. Manual testing was not done (source of issues unclear), PR tests failed, prior RSpec tests were not updated, and schema was changed without migration file creation.
Feedback on design doc: The functionality of review_mapping_controller has a list of 10 items. To make it easier to comprehend, they could be divided into categories, e.g., UI related and calculation related.  The implementation section has a good description of the changes that were made.  They could have been structured as itemized lists. The test plan is well organized, but it would have been much better to say what was tested, and what result was expected.

Feedback on project: The team refactored code by breaking down large methods and showcased functionalities like inviting and retracting invitations, and accepting invitations, while transitioning from TeamsUsers to TeamsParticipants. The substantial changes and the sheer scale of the project PR raise concerns about thorough testing. The code's readability remains a challenge. Although not all changes may be merged immediately, improvements like partials, SQL to ActiveRecord method conversion, addressing DRY violations, and method refactoring contribute positively.
Feedback on design doc: The document is quite readable. It starts out with good rationale for the schema changes, but when it gets into refactoring, it has just a sentence of description for each file.  Phase 2 refactoring changes are described better than Phase 1.  The listing of files changed is not very helpful without a description of why the files needed to be changed.  The test plan is described reasonably well, but the test code is too small to be read.

Feedback on project: This project is an important addition to mentor management in Expertiza.  The features were implemented as requested and the functionality seems to work well.  However, 8 of the test cases are failing.  Also, the code is not the cleanest; some methods, such as add_user_to_course, are misplaced (in signup_sheet_controller).  Many comments have been added, but more still are needed.  If they are provided, the team's grade will be increased by one point.
Feedback on design doc: The descriptions in the Mailer Changes section are unclear, e.g., "The add member function must be altered such that the call to mail a user is better named, and that it calls directly to the mailer rather than the mailer helper."  This could be written much more clearly.  I also think references to Phase I changes should have a hyperlink to the appropriate section of that Phase I documentation.  The flow could be clearer; several screenshots are juxtaposed and the rationale for the ordering is not clear.  When you describe changes that were made to particular classes, instead of just saying what changes were made, you should explain first why a change was needed.

Project name: Implementing and testing import & export controllers
Feedback on project: This team did a very good job on a project that had been unsuccessfully attempted several times before.  They wrote all of the obviously needed import and export routines.  I am a little concerned that the video did not demonstrate using all of them, so manual checking would still need to be performed.  Also many automated tests for AssignmentParticipant and CourseParticipant are duplicated, and really should be located in Participant.  Ditto for AssignmentTeam and CourseTeam.  However, this problem was pre-existing; the team added to it instead of fixing it.  The team addressed security issues after the demo. Overall, very good job that should be merged, & the rough edges fixed later.
Feedback on design doc: This is a good description of the changes made, and the rationale for them. I am glad you moved away from using eval, but there are still several security errors reported, which there should be a fix for.  As to the ExportAssignment class, a class should be named after an entity in the system, not a process.  Method names like generate_data and participant also aren't very clear; it's not obvious from the name what the method does (what data does it generate, does it return a participant object, etc.).  It would be useful to have screenshots of the various import and export options.

Project name: Allow reviewers to bid on what to review
Feedback on project: Thank you for attempting to imporove the code for this function.  However, I do not believe the code is clear enough to be merged into the system  One should be able to look at the names of classes and methods and get an idea of what they do, but names like topic_ids_with_team and existing_topics are confusing.  Distinguishing the purpose of assign_bid_review and run_bidding_algorithm is very difficult and likely to confuse developers who follow on.  Also, bids are shown after reviews are assigned, with no indication that the bids are no longer operative.  Because of these factors, the project does not improve the code as it should.
Feedback on design doc: The screenshots provide a good overview of the bidding process; however, there are some typos, e.g., "Students are can see how “hot” each topic is by the color it has on their topic list allowed to bid on several topics, ranking them by priority." and "Gale-Shapely" instead of "Gale-Shapley".  I am also confused by, "After the deadline, if a student fails to bid the topics to review, the run bid algorithm allocated topics to the student after the instructor runs the run bidding algorithm," because if a student DOES bid, the bidding algorithm allocates them topics too. In the design, it seems that students are not allowed to bid on their own topic.  Actually, this should be allowed if the instructor wants to allow it.  Discussion of the authorization methods is quite good, but it is covered in much more detail than the rest of the changes.

Feedback on project: The team was exceptionally proactive and engaged in pair programming. They have really done a good job in reimplementing the participants page according to the backend. They also changed URLs, which makes sense and connects to the backend. They changed the add participant form according to Participants.rb, which was having only assignment_id and user_id, hence they made the form have the user dropdown and removed edit functionality in action since it's a dropdown that would allow the instructor/admin to select from a list of all 10000+ users. This is a good idea, but it requires sending a lot of data to the front end, so its performance should be tested with all 10000+ users to make sure it does not slow down the menu by too much.  Email preferences are listed for participants.  While that might be done in the current system, it does not make sense to reimplement it, because email preferences relate to the user's account overall, and not to the user's participation in this assignment.  These columns should be removed to avoid cluttering the display. (BTW, there's potential confusion on the word "Role".  Each account has a role (Student, etc.), but the participant also has a role in this assignment, as a submitter, a reviewer, a "participant" (submit AND review) or a "reader" (just take the quiz on the artifact).  It's even more important to show the participant's role in the assignment than it is to show what kind of account they have.  Please be thinking of a way that it can be shown without confusion.  A potential drawback is that the table UI is not good when it comes to the search filter and could have added information hover for the email preferences. Since searching will rarely be necessary, the search bars should be hidden by default, until the user clicks on a "spyglass" icon to show them.  However, they reused the table component, which was already in the repo implemented previously. The team will rework on the table UI and fix issues suggested by the professor.
Feedback on design doc: The team had extensive narration on the changes they have done. The team extensively explained all the use cases they implemented with the screenshots of UI. The code snippets were clearly explained linking with the commits of respective changes where particular implementation changes have been made. However, I don't understand why particpants can't be edited.  The only way I can think of to edit them is to change their role.  But it makes perfect sense to change someone from a Participant to a Reviewer, for example. The team also had extensive discussion on test cases as well.

Feedback on project: The team did well on coming up with new ideas and their implementations. The code follows good coding practices. The UI contains a lot of components and they faced some issues at the start and so they will be continuing the same project and further improving the UI.   It is inappropriate to calculate averages in UI code.  That should be done in model code in the back end.  With regard to using buttons for rounds, I don't think there's a danger of having a long list of rounds.  Most assignments have only one round, and of those that have more, almost all of them have two rounds.  It is OK to have a button to hide one of the rounds, but I think that all rounds should be displayed by default when the page is brought up.
Feedback on design doc: The page begins with a listing of the patterns used.  It is not easy to remember these, because they are not related to particular places in the code.  I think it would be more effective to mention the patterns in descriptions of how the code has been written.  In the Files Added section, it would have been good to begin with a discussion of the project overall, indicating why each kind of files are important to it. I also think that where code snapshots are shown, it would be good to have a sentence or two giving a high-level description of the code.  The "dummy data" should be explained, rather than just displayed.  It is not the reader's job to figure out what it means.  Testing id not discussed.

Feedback on project: The implementation meets the assignment requirements, but there are opportunities for improvement in code quality, documentation, and specially the UI/UX design.
Feedback on design doc: The documentation begins with an explanation of what is being implemented.  However, large amounts of initializations are listed without any explanation of what they do or why they are being shown.  The "Current implementation" looks to me like the new implementation, rather than the current implementation.  There is no discussion of testing.

Feedback on project: The team proactively participated in the discussions and the development. All team members contributed and gave valuable inputs. The page overall looks good with all the required components. While the code structure adheres to React best practices, there is room for improvement in terms of code reuse and readability. Comments should be more descriptive, explaining the purpose and functionality of each method clearly. The UI/UX could benefit from more user-friendly design elements and have a common filter button which allows for the search boxes to show up. The video is very good and helps the users know what is happening in the UI.
Feedback on design doc: The project's wiki documentation is clear and thorough, offering insights into the authors' refactor approach with well-documented snippets and detailed descriptions of each change. However, a more comprehensive introduction to the project is needed.  The existing text starts out by referring to "the interfaces," without any indication of what they are and why they are used. and explicit mention of design principles could enhance understanding. The JSON file is displayed, without any explanation of what it is doing, or how it acheives its objectives.  Then there is a section called "Changes," which does not seem appropriate to a reimplementation. (You could say, Differences from the previous version".)  Screenshots are pretty large for the document, and also, there is no explanation of what they show.  The reader would have to switch back and forth between this document and the code in order to understand what is being described.  There is a good amount of prose describing the project, but unfortunately it is not readable unless the reader is already pretty familiar with the particular Expertiza functionality that is being reimplemented.  Also, there is no explicit section about testing, even though there are several mentions of tests.

Project name: Replicate Roles and Institution UIs in ReactJS
Feedback on project: The entire team actively participated in all the discussions. There was a good amount of effort by all eam members. Their code exhibited all the necessary principles for object oriented programming. They worked and improved the UI a lot and paid attention to minute nuances for perfection.  Although roles can be created dynamically in the current Expertiza system, we have never created a role that way, and to simplify the new system, I think it would be better not to provide this facility.  Then if it is every necessary to create a new role (which I doubt), code would have to be written for it.  It does, however, make sense to manage institutions dynamically, since new ones are added regularly.
Feedback on design doc: The page starts out with an overview of the project.  However, I'm confused about the mention of the Questionnaire UI when they are working on roles and institutions, which don't have anything to do with questionnaires.  The rest of the prose is relevant, although much of it would apply to any front-end project, and is not specific to this one.  The screenshots are quite useful.  The description of testing is quite terse.

Feedback on project: The team effectively updated UI_for_questionnaire.rb, enhancing the user interface and aligning the code with Ruby standards, including adherence to DRY and SRP principles. Variable and method names were clarified for better readability. The UI was made more intuitive, improving user interaction. Although the refactor maintained existing functionality, the team identified the potential to transition class methods to instance methods for better code structure.Overall, their efforts have resulted in a cleaner, more user-friendly interface.  However, I question whether it is a good idea to use popups in the UI.  The current UI uses tabs instead.  It is easier to switch between tabs than to bring up different popups. Moreover, in the Assignment popup, the meaning of several terms is unclear.  What is "Submitter count"?  Is the "Number of reviews" the amount that a student is required to do, the maximum amount that the student is allowed to do, or the number of reviews that need to be done for each submission?  The "Number of reviews of reviews" (metareviews) is used so rarely that it should not even be shown by default.  Similarly, the search bar is so unlikely to be used frequently that it should not be shown be default.  Perhaps it could be brought up by clicking on a spyglass icon in the corner of the list.
Feedback on design doc: This team has extensively documented their UI, providing detailed explanations and showing many screenshots.  This is all good, but to improve readability, the screenshots should be shrunk so that one does not need an excessively wide column to view them, and in the many cases where multiple screenshots are juxtaposed, there should be narration in between them to tell what the next screenshot illustrates.  The table of test cases is great, but ideally it would tell where in the code each test case is implemented.

Project name: Create a UI for Assignment Edit page Etc" tab in ReactJS"
Feedback on project: The team was exceptionally proactive and engaged in pair programming. They successfully implemented the ETC feature on the Edit page assignment. The team demonstrated proficiency in integrating the ETC tab, and they efficiently created the corresponding pages for the ETC tab buttons. However, one notable disadvantage is the absence of some comments in the new code.  I think that the search bar in managing assignments is going to be used very rarely, because in almost all cases, the list of assignments will fit on a single screen.  It may be good to have this functionality, but I wouldn't show the search bar by default.  Perhaps there could be a little spyglass search icon in the corner of the view that would open the search bar if clicked upon.
Feedback on design doc: The team had extensive narration on the changes they have done. The team extensively explained all the use cases they implemented with the screenshots of UI. The code snippets are shown mainly in screenshots, which was clear but will be not clear on all displays. The best way I have found for showing changes is to link to individual commits in Github, where particular implementation changes have been made. The team had very good discussion on the test cases which was clearly explained in the tabular form.

Project name: Create a Courses user interface in ReactJS
Feedback on project: Ideally, the icons from the current system should be used in the new UI.  What is the purpose of  "course details"?  What's in a Course object vs. a "Course Details" object?  Can you use a more specific term than "details" to indicate this?  Why are Name, Institution, and Instructor searchable, while Creation and Updated Date are not?  I wonder if the list of courses ever gets long enough so there would be a need to search it.  Also, I prefer the current Expertiza widgets to the ones used here for Actions, which are too light to be clear at a glance.  In "Improved User Dropdown Selection", could you restrict the instructors shown to those who have taught courses at the Institution selected above?  That would simplify the search.  But, on second thought, only Administrators would ever need to choose an instructor.  Instructors can create courses only for themselves.  I don't think, in the history of Expertiza, that an administrator ever HAS created a course.  So the functionality of selecting an instructor is niche functionality that would rarely if ever be used.  Better to remove it from the system.  I suggest that you discuss subsequent design decisions with your mentor so that she can offer an opinion on how useful they are likely to be.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the motivation for the code. It explains the rationale for the changes, and the rationale behind the code changes. It would have been better if it had described how the code was rewritten. The code in the code snippets is too small to be read easily.  It would be better to link to individual commits than to attempt to show code through .png files.  The test plan needs to be described in considerably more detail.

Feedback on project: The team was really proactive, and set up meetings whenever they faced a problem. They made sure to ask the right questions and fully grasp what needed to be done. The code written was good, and they stuck to the guidelines for implementing controller methods. However, the team has not added tests yet, since they could not run the tests on their system. This needs to be worked on in the next program and tests cases but must be written for the controller. More comments in the code are needed and this was missed by the team. At a few places code has been commented out and these lines should be removed from the code along with unnecessary files such as the gemfile.lock and the empty bookmark_controller file.
Feedback on design doc: At the outset, it would be good to explain what a bookmark is, and how it is used in Expertiza.  The page does not attempt to do this.  To show changes, it is clearer if the old and new versions of each method are juxtaposed, rather than showing all the old code and then the new code.  The purpose of the methods are well explained, but the flow of the methods is not.  There should be a description of how each method works and/or internal comments that say how.  The testing screenshots are too small for text to be legible. The test plan should have described how the tests were carried out, rather than just showing the code.

Feedback on project: The team has done a good job in the re-implementation with a focus on ensuring that the code is simpler to read and understand. To allow the Single responsibilty principle the team created a separate private method to look up the symbol.The model had a few changes and there has been a good attempt to ensure each function follows the single responsibility principle. This is even done for the validations. In terms of improvement there could be more pair programming sessions. The team failed to remove an unnecessary method from the existing model code added by the team working on the controller last spring (2023) . A little more caution on those ends could help. There could be more comments in the code. Apart from that the ideas that have been put into every method are very impressive.
Feedback on design doc: The page is entitled, "Refactor Advice Controller" when it should actually be "Reimplement Advice Controller."  The distinction is an important one, because bad design decisions in the old system should not be carried over into the new system until mitigated by refactoring.  In the invalid_advice? method, the prose should explain why advice might be invalid.  However, it does not, and the reader must look through the code to figure out what invalid advice might mean.  Also, I think the naming should stay away from "advices", which is not good English.  Refactored code for save_advice and edit_advice is missing from the wiki page.   And the testing section merely displays the current tests, without saying how the tests will be modified.

Feedback on project: The team has done a good job in the re-implementation with a focus on ensuring that the code is simpler to read and understand. To allow the Single responsibilty principle the team created a separate private method to look up the symbol.The model had a few changes and there has been a good attempt to ensure each function follows the single responsibility principle. This is even done for the validations. In terms of improvement there could be more pair programming sessions. The team failed to remove an unnecessary method from the existing model code added by the team working on the controller last spring (2023) . A little more caution on those ends could help. There could be more comments in the code. Apart from that the ideas that have been put into every method are very impressive.
Feedback on design doc: Overall, the page has a number of prose descriptions, which is a good start.  However, many of them are not particularly clear; please rewrite them so that one does not have to pore over the code to see what they mean.  They should be an introduction to looking at the code, not just a way to try to resolve confusion after reading it.  When you discuss methods that have been reimplemented, it would be very helpful to give a prose description of the changes and the reasons for them, rather than make the reader ponder the code to figure out what has been changed.  In particular, what is a "questionnaire symbol"?  There is no indication of what it means.  Please do not paste in large sequences of code without explanation, as you have done with the test skeleton.  And importantly, Questionnaire should not be computing scores at all!  Scores cannot be computed for a Questionnaire, only for a filled-out Questionnaire (i.e., a Response).  All code for score calculation in the system needs to be in Response.rb, ResponseMap.rb, and AssignmentTeam.rb, along with their mixins or helpers.  Putting score calculation anywhere else will create a DRY problem.  For "true_false_questions?" if it is testing whether there are any checkbox items, then why not call it "checkbox_questions?" (or, better, "checkbox_items?" since they may not be questions)?  This avoids potential confusion about whether a checkbox is "true-false".  The sentence starting with "There was no reason to do an each" is rather confusing; can you be more specific?  The method name "self.copy_questionnaire_details" must be changed.  As usual with names that include "details", it's not clear what is being referred to.  Why could it not be "self.copy_questionnaire"?  Overall, this wiki page shows a lot of work.  But to get value out of the work you have put in, the explanations need to be more numerous and clearer.

Feedback on project: The team has done a great job in reimplementing the impersonate_users.controller. The team has implemented methods to impersonate a selected user by generating a new JWT token with the necessary user information. In the user.rb file, they have implemented can_impersonate method which was great to decide who has the authority to impersonate. The team has thoroughly  tested all the API and the functionality using Postman and has created a detailed video for all the tests that they had used. They have reimplemented a great deal, but there seems to have been an issue where there is no TA -> student mapping in the previous implementation which is not allowing them to access a particular course for the student who impersonated as a TA. For now, they are allowing all the TA to access all the courses. So the team can work on this in the final project. A name like check_if_user_impersonateable? should be is_user_impersonatable? Overall the team did a good job.  Make sure that functionality is not duplicated from authentication utilities, E1915.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of what was done, and how it was done. The Role Hierarchy diagram is a bit misleading, in that the super_admin is allowed to impersonate anyone, but other roles are allowed to impersonate only those that they created (or in the case of TAs, are in classes that they TA).  The flow between the 5 sections under Implementation is not clear; it should be explained why the 5 topics are being covered in that order.  It would have been helpful to have more detail on the tests, e.g., what conditions were tested for. The code in the screenshots is tiny, and essentially illegible, even when blown up.

Feedback on project: The team has done pair programming , the team has reimplemented the student quizzes controller. The team has rewritten the code for the calculate_score method and create_questionnaire method and assign_quiz_to_student method. The team has also adhered to using the DRY principle . The team has refactored the method names to be relevant and meaningful. The team has improved the HTTP code response handling as well to receive relevant responses codes upon certain CRUD operations.  The team has implemented the testing plan and performed a manual testing of the API’s. There are comments missing in the code which specify the functionality performed. There are some redundant code and apis in the code which could be reused.  The rspec seems to be a problem in running them.  Too much code in student_quizzes_controller is really manipulating the model, and is not CRUD functionality.  Score calculation should not be performed in this class.  Moreover, the "process_answers" method is performing 4 barely related functions, and is thus a violation of the SRP.  Methods that manipulate, e.g., response_map, belong in model classes, not in student_quizzes_controller.
Feedback on design doc: This page does quite a good job in describing the motivation for all of the changes that have been made.  All parts of the code are described in appropriate detail.  The only weakness is that the screenshots are hard to read.  Either they are so wide that you have to widen the text column so far that it is hard to read, or (in the testing section) the text is so small that it is hard to read.

Project name: Reimplement duties controller.rb and badges controller.rb
Feedback on project: The team has done pair programming; the team has reimplemented duties  controller method with simple, clean code. Methods follow the ruby style guide and DRY Principle. Comments are only added for some methods, and they fail to provide insight. Comments are not detailed. The team has made relevant changes to the method names.  The team has thoroughly tested all the required RESTful API’s using Postman and Swagger. Seems like one of the Api’s for update a Badge is not performing as expected and updating the id’s that match in the database. The team also has less commits by the team members and were done within two days as the team has spent a lot of time in setting up the project. The rspec seems to be a problem running them. Overall, the team did a good job in reimplementing the duties and badges controller as it covers all the basic functionality needed adhering to good coding practices.
Feedback on design doc:
In the overview, it would have been good to describe the purpose of the classes: duties_controller manages the roles, or "duties" of team members, such as Scrum Master, Tester, or Documenter; badges_controller manages badges that can automatically or manually be awarded to participants in the assignment who achieve some goal, such as getting sufficiently high peer scores, on, e.g., their contribution to the project.  There is a description of these classes, but it does not help the reader to understand their purpose.  In fact, while the code is described in admirable detail, the documentation reveals no hint of the actual purpose of these classes.  It is especially important to include this for future readers, who will want to know what the classes are for.
