Finally, the setup instructions include 11 steps.  Not all of them are setup steps; some are phrased as tests.  There are no other tests specified in this page, so I'd ask that the page be rewritten to separate setup steps from tests, and describe how to run the tests.

Feedback on project: The team did a good job reimplementing due_date.rb; they simplified the code and renamed methods and variables to more accurately describe their responsibilities. They refactored each method to comply with DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself), SRP (Single Responsibility Principle), and other Ruby conventions. They also overrode the comparator operator for the DueDate class and replaced the deadline_sort class method. They fixed the test cases and make them work the changes they have done.  Additionally, they ensured the checks passed. The major concern is that the class methods need be converted to instance methods. This project should have been a reimplementation from the start, rather than taking the existing code with all its smells and making incremental improvements. The team will rework on the same project, aiming to convert class methods to instance methods and to add more test cases. Not many new test cases were added. This team has done pair programming.
Feedback on design doc:
This is a very good description of the existing code. The team talked a lot about the pieces of code they wrote. They explained why they made changes to the code on a wiki page. They talked about the problems they faced, like the code being too complicated and not having enough comments. The description of the changes is also good, although the changes are described in a sentence or so, and it is not pointed out exactly where in the code the change is made. Only one test is really described, and there should have been more.

Also, 9 characteristics of existing code is a bit much.  Could they be divided into categories so the list wouldn't be so long?

Feedback on project: The team has done pair programming; the team has created different controller methods with simple, clean code. Methods follow the ruby style guide. Various models were added through migrations. Comments are only added for some methods. It seems that the method move_file has more than one responsibility. The method clean_path has not been implemented yet, but a call has been made to this method. They have added a required gemfile, but omitted the gemfile in the PR. They have removed some already existing methods and associations, please add them in the next phase, as we need to keep the schema the same as the current implementation.
Feedback on design doc: The page provides comprehensive and well-structured documentation of the reimplementation efforts for the SubmittedContentController. The page covers all relevant aspects, including the problem description, objectives, implementation details, testing approach, and future scope. Additionally, including code snippets, future scope, deployment link, and specific test cases further enhances the page's overall quality.  It described methods very well, but its descriptions of what classes do were frequently missing or wrong (I corrected a couple of them).  The ToC lists 15 "improvements in new code."  That's too long a list; it should have been broken into pieces somehow.

Feedback on project: The team did a good job implementing the question types. They have implemented three types of questions with the others slated to be done in Program 4. They have also done a good job with the code and followed the guidelines to implement the models. The test cases have also been written using the test skeleton which is good. There are two methods that have been left empty and the reason should have been mentioned as a comment for developers working on the system later. More comments are needed in the code and this was missed by the team. There are also some variables that are being passed in but not being used (TextResponse::edit)
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes made to the project. It explains the rationale for the changes, and the rationale behind them. However, the screenshots are not particularly readable, and have portions of the navigation pane shown at the left, which is irrelevant to the code being shown.  The page also explains how the tests work, and how they are tested. But again, several screenshots are juxtaposed without any explanation of what they are.  What I would like to see is a more detailed description of how the test cases work, e.g., how they verify the correctness of methods defined within the model class.

Feedback on project: In the team, only one member was active, and other members did not actively contribute. The only active member worked on the suggested changes after a code review. The PR has numerous files, EOL changes, and Gemlock files not related to the responses controller. Rescue is being used without the begin-end block. A method named create_response_maps has hardcoded attributes for the response objects, which is not a good practice. The newly created method validate_params can be refactored as currently it is more than 48 lines long. They have created a method to serialize the response object to pass all the attributes, which is good. The team has tested CRUD operations on the response object.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes that were made, and the rationale for them. It is good to juxtapose new and old code.  While you had a one-sentence statement of the changes in the new version, it would have been helpful to have more detail on how the various methods were implemented, e.g., how they were changed, and why. That is provided for the controllers, but oddly, not for the models.  The text in some of the screenshots is too small and grainy, making it hard to read.  Fixing this would go a long way toward improving the documentation.

Feedback on project: In the team, only one member was active, and other members did not actively contribute. The only active member worked on the suggested changes after a code review. The PR has numerous files, EOL changes, and Gemlock files not related to the responses controller. Rescue is being used without the begin-end block. A method named create_response_maps has hardcoded attributes for the response objects, which is not a good practice. The newly created method validate_params can be refactored as currently it is more than 48 lines long. They have created a method to serialize the response object to pass all the attributes, which is good. The team has tested CRUD operations on the response object.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes that were made, and the rationale for them. It is good to juxtapose new and old code.  While you had a one-sentence statement of the changes in the new version, it would have been helpful to have more detail on how the various methods were implemented, e.g., how they were changed, and why. That is provided for the controllers, but oddly, not for the models.  The text in some of the screenshots is too small and grainy, making it hard to read.  Fixing this would go a long way toward improving the documentation.

Feedback on project: This was a fairly small project, but the code looks clean, and the functionality works.  The display of grading history needlessly uses the entire width of the page.  Columns should be adjusted to remove the large whitespace between them.  Please see the Github review for additional comments.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes that were made, and the rationale for making them. The test plan is described well, and shows the tests that were carried out.  However, the screenshot is too large.  It should have been separated by test, and the conditions tested for should have been enumerated and summarized.  Other than that, the documentation meets its goal of explaining the code and the changes to it.

Feedback on project: There are a good amount of tests, but comments should be more precise.  Instead of "tests access to", it could be, "tests that the user can accesss ..."
Feedback on design doc:
The documentation thoroughly covers the testing processes for the answers tags and tag deployment controller, presenting a well-organized structure that addresses all pertinent points, including detailed descriptions of each test case and relevant references. Nonetheless, it would enhance the understanding to explain the rationale behind choosing Lynx. The screenshots included do not fit the page properly and vary in size.  Lists should be created with the itemization feature of MediaWiki, rather than being formatted as paragraphs beginning with an asterisk.

This is not a comment on the wiki page itself, but (1) videos absolutely need to have audio describing what they are showing; in this case the video is grainy enough to make the text quite hard to read, and (2) videos should be uploaded to a video service such as Vimeo or Youtube; if they are placed on student Google drives, they will be deleted when the student graduates.

Feedback on project:
Wrote 5 tests, 8 ... edge cases, got correct values, but when 0 is input, incorrect values are returned.  They did not find the problem with 0s. DRY priciples issue, They putted their code into a controller which are not expected. But  they were able to test their algorithm. They have a lot of code smells in their code. 
Since it was a testing project, why did they modify a controller?
And the controller calculates grades ... a serious DRY problem, since grades are calculated in a half-dozen other places in the system.  And in any case, grades should be calculated in the model, not in the controller.
Only one "expect" statement is included; this is not enough testing.
Feedback on design doc: The Wiki page is well-organized and offers comprehensive information about hamer algorithm and reputation web service, including the challenges and issues faced during its development and how these obstacles were overcome. However, the explanation of the test cases and the interpretation of their results could be improved for clearer understanding.  For example, the Object Creations are just listed, without a prose desciption of what is being created and why.  The "expected Hamer values" are listed without explaining what they connote.  It is not explained how the reimplementation of the algorithm differs from the previous implementation, or how it fixes the problems.

Project name: Fix 'Back' link on 'New Late Policy' page
Feedback on project: The team has worked on resolving the issues on the 'New late policy' page and has added comments to explain the changes they made in the code. They adhered to Ruby naming conventions, such as renaming the variable 'aid' to 'assignment_id' and the written code follows the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP), with no apparent violation of the DRY principle. They have provided a clear explanation of the issues and the workings of Expertiza after the issues have been resolved in the video. They have also written test cases to verify the logic of the fixed bug. However, they still need to write test cases to address the logic related to the models of the issue and resolve CodeClimate issues.
Feedback on design doc: The problem statement starts off with a list.  It would have been good to start off with an overall description of what the project is doing.  In the listing of issues, screenshots are juxtaposed without intervening text, forcing the reader to figure out how they are related.  Snippets should not be provided without commenting on what was done, and there should be text describing what each snippet shows.  Overall, there needs to be explanations of what lists show and how they are organized.

Feedback on project: The team has implemented the view for the results of bidding, written the logic to calculate the bidding percentage, and added comments to explain the code. They have also written test cases for the logic and provided a clear explanatory video on how to access the bidding view. However, they need to separate the bidding logic from the assignment controller and use more meaningful method names instead of "bidding_details". It's important to ensure that classes follow the Single Responsibility Principle and that the code adheres to the DRY principle in certain scenarios, such as setting the bid priority code. The bidding view needs to be modified to appear less cluttered. Lastly, Code Climate issues need to be addressed.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes made to the code. It explains the rationale for the changes, but the explanations could have been enhanced by providing a prose overview for each, as well as a list of steps.. In some places, code snippets are juxtaposed, so that dozens of lines of code are shown with no intervening description.  Changes like this could be better handled by linking to the Github commits that created them.  They would be much more readable.  The test plan is well organized, but again, a prose overview of the tests, and what conditions they test for, would have been much appreciated.

Feedback on project: The team has implemented a common sign-up code for both a student and an instructor, and they have reduced the number of lines in the 'signup_as_instructor_action' code, enhancing its understandability and adhering to the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle. However, there are issues with the code: some method names, such as 'delete_signup_common', need to be renamed for better clarity. This method, in particular, needs to be reworked to implement the Single Responsibility Principle. Additionally, more comments need to be added for better code understandability. Instead of using names like 'who_user' and 'due_date_obj', it would be better to use variable names that are more descriptive and meaningful.
Feedback on design doc: Good job of describing the changes made to several methods. I would have liked to see comments in the code changes.  After the prose description, the code is given without any method comments or blank lines.  In addition to the short comments at the end of lines, longer methods should have comments that explain the flow of the method.  There is no test plan.

Feedback on project: The team did pair programming and refactored methods in courses and the course_team model. They have added comments for every method and removed methods that are not being used. Some methods have been renamed to a more descriptive name. They have created a Teamcsvhandler to import/export teams to separate the concerns from the model. The methods in the tests are renamed to match those in the models. There are failing required tests: codeql and model tests. One method in the model is having HTML markup code, which is not a good practice.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page provides a well-structured and detailed documentation of the refactoring efforts undertaken by the team on the course.rb and course_team.rb models.  However, the changes are simply described, without any code excerpts being shown.  The reader would have a hard time finding them without much more explanation.  It would be better to link to the commits that implemented these changes.  A couple of screenshots are pasted in, but there is no explanation of what they show. While the documentation is generally detailed, it could benefit from more explanation of the improvements achieved through the refactoring and additional details on the testing approach and coverage for other refactored methods.

Feedback on project:
The focus was on addressing key issues to improve code quality and maintainability. Refactored functions like assign_reviewer_dynamically and add_reviewer. Corresponding changes were made to their respective tests. Additionally, efforts were made to improve code readability and understanding by correcting and adding comments. Method names were revised to better reflect their purposes. Code Climate issues were fixed. Some methods are so short as to be unnecessary though, such as find_assignment which results in 3 lines of code being added for a very self-explanatory single line of code. Some methods, like assign_reviewer, are quite lengthy and handle multiple responsibilities, including error checking, finding records, and redirecting. Extracting some of this inline code into separate, smaller methods could improve readability and maintainability. Too many comments lack insight - the top-level comments are helpful in places to explain what methods do in more detail, but many of the comments just reiterate the following line of code and only end up adding visual clutter. Some tests for the controller are failing which should be addressed.

In assign_reviewer_without_topic(assignment, reviewer), it seems that assigning the reviewer should be the same whether or not there are topics, though different logic would be used to figure out which submission to assign a reviewer to.  Could the assignment be factored out of this method and other assignment methods, to reduce DRY violations?
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the motivation for changes made to the code. The downside is that too much of the page consists of lists without any clear organization.  These lists are often formatted simply as paragraphs, without making use of the itemization or enumeration features of Mediawiki.  For documenting code changes, they could simply link to the commit. That allows the reader to display the change in whatever theme and font size is most readable. But a summary or narration on why those changes improve code quality could be added. The test plan only shows the skeleton.

Feedback on project: The team focused on improving code clarity and consistency. Refactored get_data_for_review_report to enhance readability with partials in views/reports, revamped color-related methods for clarity, and renamed methods starting with "get" to follow Ruby conventions. Some functions have wrong spellings (eg. retrive_data_for_review_report(assignment_id, reviewer_id, type)) which need to be fixed and refactored in other places accordingly. "subm_created_at" could indicate its purpose more clearly as submission_created_at. Additionally, fetch_link_updated_at might benefit from a more descriptive name to indicate its purpose. There are multiple unnecessary empty lines in the file. Some comments present in the file have unnecessary whitespaces spanning about 3 lines which should be addressed. They are yet to complete the remaining project requirements which they plan to finish in the final project. Test cases need to be added to improve the test coverage. Manual testing also needs to be performed.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page consists mainly of lists of items.  There is little prose to explain the items, or describe how they fit together.  There is not much information on what code changes were made and why.  It does not include a test plan. Although a background is given, . The code is documented through screenshots. They are on a dark background, which in this context makes it somewhat harder to read. It is better that for each change, to simply link to the commit that makes that change. That would allow the reader to display the change in whatever theme and font size is most readable.

Feedback on project: So far, the `display_volume_metric_chart` and `review_metrics` methods have been refactored, adding comments and fixing code climate issues. Although the wiki page was not added in the submission it is available on the website. However, the overall number of commits made is very minimal. This could be because of a prior broken functionality that hindered them from manually testing if any functionality is breaking while refactoring. This needs to be investigated further. There are multiple unnecessary empty lines in the file. Some comments present in the file have unnecessary whitespaces spanning about 3 lines which should be addressed. They created a test plan leveraging the test skeleton provided but are yet to write the test cases. A majority of the initial project requirements are yet to be met in the final project.
Feedback on design doc: The page covers a lot of deficiencies and changes to be made to this class.  My overarching recommendation would be to limit lists to no more than 5 elements; if there are any more items to describe, they should be divided into no more than 5 categories.  This lets the reader look them over and comprehend how they are related.  The existing page has unsorted lists of up to 34 elements, which no one could comprehend as a whole.  Additionally, several long lists are formatted as simple paragraphs, without using the itemization or enumeration mechanisms of MediaWiki.  This makes the text harder to read.  I would also like to see the team tackle bad namign (e.g., check_submission_state) as well as code changes.

Feedback on project: Features are working from the front end correctly as evident from the Youtube video. The TeamsUser was renamed as TeamsParticipant. Additionally, a "participant_id" column was added to the teams_participants table. A majority of the changes made to the files were a result of this refactoring. The view for student_teams was previously bloated, but it has now been segregated into partials. The team also tried to make the code DRY, an example of which is refactoring of fetching the AssignmentParticipant only once instead of twice by removing a redundant find query. Since the team introduced a new file teams_participants_controller.rb, it might be beneficial to add more comments. The create function is too long which could be split into a few more. There are still some other places violating DRY (In the send_invitations, accept, and decline methods, there is repeated code for updating the pair_programming_status attribute of users based on whether they are TeamsUser or TeamsParticipant. Similarly, there is duplication in the flash message logic across these methods). Furthermore, the existing test cases were modified so that they would pass for the new code which includes participant_id. A few tests are currently failing or canceled on GitHub actions obscuring the coverage count and they should be modified so that they are passing. Many other files need to be modified to factor in the renaming done in the project.
Feedback on design doc: I would have liked to see the page start off by explaining what student_teams_controller does.  The page enumerates changes, but lacks depth in explaining the rationale behind design decisions which could be included. The code is documented through screenshots. A few are on a white background, while others have a dark background, which makes it harder to read. However, the changes related to CRUD functionalities are described in detail.  In the listing of files changed, it should have explained why they were changed.  The test cases are described more completely, but even here, it would have been good to explain individual tests, instead of just summarizing the tests.

Feedback on project: 2 pull requests submitted, one of which changed 1002 files.  Some code in the mailer class seems to be misplaced, as it is too specific for a class that sends generic mail.   Some methods could have better names (esp. the one with "details"). A.custom data structure for all of the meetings for an assignment was created, instead of fetching and displaying meetings team by team.  Fixed mailer code from previous mentoring project.  Few tests.  See Github review for more details.
Feedback on design doc: In some places, there is a very good description of what was done, and how it was done.  For other changes, the code is shown, almost without any comments. It would have been helpful to have more detail on how the code was modified, e.g., which classes the new functions were placed in, and why. There is no test plan, and there should be.

Project name: Implementing and testing import & export controllers
Feedback on project: Changes to import_file_controller.rb appear very reasonable.  Most of the code seems right on the mark (I noted exceptions in my Github review).  Code has been written to import several elements, and other code is stubbed, to be written later.  A few of the changes are unclear, e.g., why was shared.js modified?
Feedback on design doc: This is a contrast to most of the wiki pages students create, which show lots of code excerpts with little explanation.  These authors have done a great job of describing the changes that were made, and the rationale for making them. But they provided no code excerpts to show, e.g., what changes were made to the import_file_controller.rb method, and how the tests were changed. The code is not described in prose, and it would have helped to have a link to the Github diffs for each file.

Project name: Allow reviewers to bid on what to review
Feedback on project: The code is concentrated in few files, which is good.  It simplifies authentication, and removes some class methods.  But concerns remain: first of all, does it work?  Does it really allow bids to be dragged and dropped?  No new tests are written. Second, the code is more difficult to understand than it should be.  That can be addressed in the final project.  I am also concerned that class methods have been turned into instance methods when they are not applicable to a single instance of the class.
Feedback on design doc: This is a good description of the changes that have been made, and the rationale for them. It would have been helpful to have more explanation of the code changes, e.g., prose description which methods were modified, and how they were implemented. You did this in Section 6.2 (action_allowed) but not in other places in the document.  For example, you said "below code is implemented to over come the DRY violation" but did not provide any explanation.

Slated to possibly be merged: Same as E2373. But definitely don't merge the front-end portion, which was optional.
Feedback on project: The team has successfully implemented Teams controller. In this they have implemented the CRUD operations in json format and tested through Swagger UI. The team had good dynamics and kept on asking questions regarding the project. They have also implemented the frontend UI for 'Create Teams' to demonstrate the teams controller. This team also took into the consideration of the assignment UI and created the tile like structure for 'assignment etc' tab which will be further used for the completion of new expertiza. Overall a great project.
Feedback on design doc: In the "Overall UI", it would have been very helpful to have a prose description of what one does to move from one screen to another, and what functionality is available on each screen. There are very short descriptions of methods in the "Functionality" section, but no explanations on any code snippets.  The Swagger UI is shown without any text describing it.  The controller tests are shown but not described.

Feedback on project: The team have successfully implemented teams user backend. In this they have implemented the CRUD operations in json format and tested through Swagger UI. The team were very proactive since the start of the project. They have also implemented the changes that were asked to do in the demo. Their wiki doc is also neat and clean. Overall a good project.
Feedback on design doc: The description of the code is quite readable.  Methods are described in appropriate detail.  Tests are described well too, but it would be better to juxtapose (or copy) the description of the test to right below or right above, the screenshot that shows them.

Project name: Create a Courses User Interface in ReactJS
Slated to possibly be merged: Nice UI, but used wrong set of widgets.
Feedback on project: The team has successfully implemented courses user interface using React JS in reimplementation frontend. They have added features like search and sort in UI for courses pages. Inside courses tree structure there are assignments. The user can easily create, duplicate, rename and delete the courses from the UI. The team was very proactive in working on this topic and made changes according to the requirements. The code is clean and easily readable for future developers. The team has also made changes in the frontend after the feedback. In the project, new icons needs to be added on the courses/assignment UI, which can be done later on. Overall a great project.
Feedback on design doc: The document first describes the UI, and then the design of the code that implements it.  It does not display any code, nor does it link to it (my preference would be that it link to the right place in the repository).  The description of the code is good at a high level, but it would be very helpful to also have a section that talks about each method.

Project name: Refactor user_controller.rb, user.rb and its child classes
Slated to possibly be merged: Same as E2359.
Feedback on project: The initial submission was a bit rough, but the suggested changes were implemented appropriately. The code includes clear comments and documentation. The tests utilize the test skeleton and appear to cover all the relevant methods. Overall, it's a good effort, and the code seems ready for merging.
Feedback on design doc: The project was to reimplement classes related to users.  Given that, I would expect a discussion of how each file was reimplemented.  But, except for the search_users method, they are not described.  In particular, the subclasses of user.rb are never mentioned.  Good description of using Swagger.  OTOH, the Rails tests are not described at all; code is just pasted in.

Feedback on project: The style issue - grading history link is being shown up to the right of save button that reduces the width of other columns has to be fixed. Everything else looks great,  all the comments from previous implementations were addressed.
Feedback on design doc: For reimplemented & modified files, it would have been more effective to show them in a 2-column table, rather than using insets with a fixed-width font.  Problems are listed, and then solutions.  It would have been more effective to juxtapose each problem with the corresponding solution.  If you were working with the code from E2337, I don't see why problems in E1934 were relevant.  Better yet, don't just modify the code from earlier projects; write your own, referring to theirs for help when you need it.  Manual testing is covered in detail, but automated testing is just mentioned, with readers encouraged to peruse the source file.

Feedback on project: Overall, a good refactor.  There are still methods whose names don't clearly indicate what they return, e.g., should_check_policy_name?, duplicate_name_check, check_for_duplicate_name.  Comments are missing but can be merged
Feedback on design doc: I'm a little unclear on the organization of this document.  It has 14 sections, none with subsections.  Section 13 is entitled, "Proposed solution," but most of the implemented changes have been described earlier in the document.  When showing changes to methods, it is better to juxtapose the old and new methods, rather than covering all the old methods, then all the new methods.  Even better, you could link to a Github commit that made the changes.

Feedback on project: They should have double checked their video before submitting. The lack of audio and wrong recorded screen at times did not help the demo. Some API endpoints were not working as expected, which was not their fault. They have reused components and libraries, which is a good pattern. Stuck to a common UI theme.
Feedback on design doc: Other than assignment.tsx, you don't show code for the files that were added.  It would have been useful to link to them in Github.  The Create Assignment popup is rather large, and I think it merits some prose discussion.  The test plan could be more detailed.

links:
https://github.com/expertiza/reimplementation-front-end/pull/23
https://wiki-expertiza.csc.ncsu.edu/index.php/CSC/ECE_517_Fall_2023_-_E2380._Reimplement_frontend_for_Courses
https://youtu.be/PUf7xAA9FoQ
 Short_Demo.mp4  [log in to Expertiza to view]
Slated to possibly be merged: Uses same widgets as other front-end pages, but implementation is wanting
Feedback on project: The modal over modal could have been avoided. Reused components and UI from other modules, which is a positive. Good comments. Validations provided is appreciated.
Feedback on design doc: Great description of functionality of new classes.  Each new file is linked to in the repo.  The description of testing is rather sparse, though.

Feedback on project: The project has clean code with good comments and plenty of test cases. The team has worked on the changes suggested. The token passing to every method in the authorization is a dry problem one solution is to use a global variable. For now the code looks clean and mergable.
Feedback on design doc: The logic of the previous code was very good, so there wasn't much to describe about changes. I would have liked to have seen more about how JWTs are used to replace the current authorization functionality.  Other than that, the document covers all of the bases.

Slated to possibly be merged: Close call
Feedback on project: A good project. They have tested the project very well in Postman meaning that they had a clear idea on the project, escpecially who and impersonate who. They had an idea about how the front end of this feature would work, so props to that. If they make the changes suggested, this can be merged.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the changes to be made. I would have liked to see more commentary about, e.g., what changes were made to the methods, and how they were implemented.  The test plan is not detailed enough. The description of the tests is quite terse, as individual tests are not described.

Slated to possibly be merged: Lost out because person doing the demo could not answer questions that his partner could've.
Feedback on project: The team has successfully reimplemented the student_quizzes_controller. They have also thoroughly tested out the controller and implemented the methods that were being used in the old system. However, there were a few things that the team could not explain during the demo and no comments were written to explain why it was done a certain way. Overall, a good project.
Feedback on design doc: The description of database setup is quite useful, and should help other teams.  So is the description of how to create and run a test.  I will try to remember to point next semester's teams to this design doc, because it will help them.  The downside is that the implementation of student_quizzes_controller is not described; rather the code has been pasted in without additional comments.

Project name: Refactor classes relating to signing up for topics
Merged?: Riya:  Approved and reviewed changes, pending merge after access
Feedback on project: This refactoring makes significant improvements in several classes, making names clearer and removing many ugly class methods.  Several improvements in naming were made after the demo.  The demo shows the instructor signing teams up for topics; we did not check that the functionality would work if the team signs themselves up for a topic.  Changes requested during demo have been made correctly.
Feedback on design doc: The rationale for the changes is described clearly.  So are the new methods that were introduced.  The code changes are, by and large, quite readable. However, documentation does not reflect the change in method names made after the demo.  Tests are shown, but are not described in prose.

Slated to possibly be merged: ... if we can remove the whitespace-only changes to hundreds of files.
Feedback on project: The team has successfully reimplemented the question hierarchy. The models for the questions were earlier returning html code which was not correct due to the new repo having a separate backend and frontend and now they return the correct json responses. Test cases have been written well and the test skeleton was made use of which is great. The pull request has a lot of files because of whitespace changes which makes it harder to merge. The team was proactive and scheduled meetings when they wanted to demo code or ask any questions. Overall, a good project.
Feedback on design doc: Good description of the rationale, but the explanation of code changes is lacking.  It consists of barely readable screenshots (would have been better to use links to Github diffs to show the changes) and there are no prose descriptions of what code was changed.  Testing is described only in overview; no individual tests are described.

Merged?: Not to be merged or redone
Slated to possibly be merged: Same as E2387.
Feedback on project: The project focused on refactoring rather than reimplementation. Few methods should have been in the model. Bad naming conventions. Only a few tests are good. The third teammate was absent when they had the idea to answer a few questions in the demo. Overall, it was a good try, but the project could be improved much better.
Feedback on design doc: The document clearly covers the changes made.  However, it lacks a prose description of changes.  Only a single line of prose describes each change. Some of the code screenshots have very small text, not particularly readable. It would be better to use Github diffs to show the changes made.

Project name: Reimplement QuizQuestion and its child classes
Slated to possibly be merged: Intended to be reimplementation, but done as refactoring
Feedback on project: The project pretty much does the refactoring as required. However, a lot of code is returning html that is incorrect. The reimplementation backend has a separate backend and frontend, and there should be a separation of concerns. The backend should only return the data that it needs to, and the frontend should do all rendering. On the other side, the team was also active and kept asking questions.Demo presentation was good. Overall, its a decent project.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable. It explains the changes well, and shows the code snippets that were changed. The test plan is well described.

Slated to possibly be merged: But remove redundant methods first.
Feedback on project: The team has successfully reimplemented the student_quizzes_controller. The CRUD operations for the quiz_questionnaires_controller has been implemented well and returns the correct json responses. Test cases have been written well and Swagger UI tests also work which is great. The team was stuck with an authentication issue when writing test cases and they wrote their own token generation method to add tokens to the test cases which was nice. The team was proactive and scheduled meetings when they wanted to demo code or ask any questions. Overall, a good project.
Feedback on design doc: Background & implementation discussions are good.  Screenshots show text unreadably small.  Would have been better to use narrower windows, since the right side of each window is blank.  Plus, it would have been helpful to describe in more detail what each screenshot shows.  Good description of test cases.  Would have been good to link each to a Github commit that created it.  Glad that you addressed design principles that you used.

Project name: Reimplement participants_controller.rb, participants.rb and its child classes
Merged?: Not to be merged or redone
Feedback on project: The demo did not provide the best coverage as it focused on documentation rather than the code. The project was intended to be a reimplementation, but it primarily involved refactoring. It would have been helpful to see a justification for keeping or removing certain methods, but this was not clearly articulated. Additionally, the comments could have better explained the functionality of each method. Overall, it's not a bad effort, but the code may not be readily mergeable.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the tests, and the rationale for each one. It explains them in a good amount of detail. However, some of the code screenshots have very small text, not particularly readable. It would be better to use Github diffs to show the changes made. The description of the three classes is rather shallow; it could explain participant.rb first, and then describe why it was subclassed.

Project name: Reimplement assignment model and assignment controller
Feedback on project: The code looks great. There are methods in the controller that just call the model methods to check the value of the attributes of the assignment model. One way to improve this is to implement a single method to get all the assignment attributes. The new method can be implemented, the method has_topics needs better comments, and the method num_reviews_greater can be simplified more. The group has made the suggested changes.
Feedback on design doc: Great job!  Good description of the reason behind all of the changes.  The only suggestion I would have is to augment the screenshots of code changes with links to the Github commits that made them.  That mitigates the readability problems with some screeshots showing tiny code.

Project name: Create a page to edit an Assignment's due date in ReactJS
Slated to possibly be merged: ... but check to be sure that due dates can really be edited (don't take Kartiki's word for it).
Feedback on project: The team has created a Due dates page where we display all the assignments with their corresponding due dates. They were successful in implementing the required changes in the new reimplementation front end.The team worked together on this, and were very proactive and kept asking me for feedback regarding the UI changes. This Due dates pages can be merged if the routes for assignment due dates are made correctly. They were also supposed to add 'edit' feature in the UI. The code looks clean with all the correct comments. The CSS is good and this UI will be required for reimplementing fronted. Overall, a good project.
Feedback on design doc: This is a good synopsis of the work done, but I would have liked to see more detail in why the changes were needed. Much of the "implementation" section consists of code pasted in without any comments.  The test plan is not described in any detail.  The changes that were made after the demo are not included in the document, which means that the document is somewhat misleading.

Project name: Test, and write tests for, bidding
Slated to possibly be merged: Concern about correctness of view of which teams have bid
Feedback on project: This project creates a view for bidding.  It provides functionality important for assuring that the bidding algorithm is working correctly.  We believe the code deserves to be merged into Expertiza, although there is a need for a better explanation of what the tables on the report screen signify.
Feedback on design doc: The document is quite readable, and the changes are clearly described.  The rationale for the changes is presented clearly. Some of the screenshots are shown with only "Change in ..." as a description of what they show.  "Phase2" should be "Phase 2", but that would change the URL and require a copy, which would lose the edit history.  Not worth it!

Feedback on project: The video looks fine, covering the code changes, bug fixes, and methods testing. Every method was tested using the test cases provided by Mustafa. The video demonstrates that the refactoring changes work, as shown by UI testing. The bugs fixed were assign reviewers, showing a walk back before saving the assignment, and the check for outstanding reviews if a participant has already completed the required reviews. The bug fixes can be explained more by adding comments. A few methods, such as check_outstanding_reviews, can be renamed. Also, some methods need better, valuable comments.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes made, and the rationale for making them.  However, some of the screenshots have very small text, not particularly readable. It would be better to use Github diffs to show the changes made. Another approach that might have helped would be to crop the screenshots on the right, and expand them vertically, so that the code would appear larger.

Merged?: Riya:  Approved and reviewed changes, pending merge after access
Slated to possibly be merged: Not sure if the team made the cosmetic changes requested (search term in search bar, etc.)
Feedback on project: A few cosmetic changes need to be done: add all search bars in the same row, add the text of "what is being searched" inside the search bar itself and not outside. Great job on everything else.
Feedback on design doc: The document is quite readable. It describes the changes in great detail, and the screenshots will be a big help to anyone needing to make further changes to the functionality. I would pay attention to the readability of the code screenshots.  Some have very small text.  It would be better to replace them, or augment them, with links to specific Github commits that show the changes.

Feedback on project: Starting with the demo, as not all members were present and issues were divided between team members, they could not collectively explain everything. Moving onto the code, readability has certainly improved, and the added comments enhance clarity. The documentation looks okay for the most part. Some new tests were added, but a bit of manual testing needs to be performed. Overall, it's a good effort, and the code appears ready for merging.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable, and the changes are described in detail.  The rationale for changes is described quite well. However, some of the code screenshots have very small text, not particularly readable.  It would be better to use Github diffs to show the changes made.  The test plan is not described in much detail, and it would be much clearer if it were.

Project name: Finish mentor management for assignments without topics
Slated to possibly be merged: Refactor to use Factory method or Prototype to create teams
Feedback on project: This project accomplishes its goals by making mentor management work.  Course participants can be marked as mentors.  (However, mentors should not be able to submit or review by default.)  The coding is clean, except that MentoredTeam duplicates some code in the add_member method that could be inherited from the superclass.  As future work, team creation could be changed to use the Factory Method pattern, avoiding several checks for whether mentor management is in use.  Also, members of mentored teams could be excluded from the list of students that the mentor has "partnered with" during the semester.
Feedback on design doc: In general, this page is well organized.  Would have helped for each screenshot to have a one-sentence description, not just a number, which may have referred to the list of changes at the top, but couldn't be seen without scrolling all the way up. However the narrative description was helpful. Final-phase changes seem to be presented differently, and it is not clear why.  Tests could have been described in more detail.

Project name: Allow reviewers to bid on what to review
Feedback on project: Pros: 1. Follows the project details 2. Did not break any functionality while refactoring 3. Most method names follow ruby standards now 4. Added comments to make the code more understandable 5. Added few tests as well Cons: 1. The PR fails codeclimate checks 2. There could still be more tests for better code coverage 3. Newly added code lacks comments. PR is mergable
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of what was done.  It explains the changes well. The first issue that I notice is that the problem statement lists 10 changes that should be made, but does not organize or group them in a way that would be easy to understand.  The second issue is that screenshots of changes are provided, but the commentary does not explain what change has been made.  You have to read the code to find out.  And the code is quite small; you need to zoom in to read it.  And, being a screenshot, it is not searchable.  Finally, it is on a dark background, which in this context makes it harder to read.  I favor the approach of, for each change, simply linking to the commit that makes that change. That allows the reader to display the change in whatever theme and font size is most readable.  In the test plan, only manual testing is covered, and it is not shown that the tests pass.  Automated testing should also be included.

Project name: Finish mentor management for assignments without topics
Slated to possibly be merged: Refactor to use Factory method or Prototype to create teams
Feedback on project:
When I look through the code, the first thing that jumps out at me is how many additional classes have been modified with code on mentoring: participants_controller, student_teams_controller, teams_users_controller, participants_helper, assignment.rb, assignment_participant.rb, invitation.rb, participant.rb, team.rb.  This will make the code more difficult to understand.  In several places, a "duty" parameter is added to methods with no explanation.  Method names like add_member_mentor_check will not aid readability. Overall, it would be a big mistake to merge this code, because it makes the system considerably harder to understand.  Better comments would certainly help, but more attention should be devoted to how these changes can be made without affecting so many classes.  Also, the build did not pass.

However, the team implemented all tests in the test skeleton and added new scenarios.
Feedback on design doc: This writeup comprehensively describes the changes that were made.  The Problem Statement describes the changes to be made, but it is the 5th section of the document. To make the document more readable, a fix would be to move the Problem Statement to the top.  The screenshots of changes are quite useful. They would be even more useful with a caption describing what they show.  A simple listing of files to be changed is not very helpful without a prose description of the purpose of these changes.  Prose descriptions are provided BELOW the changes, but the readability would be enhanced if one could read the description before reading the text.  The next issue is that screenshots of changes are provided, but the commentary does not explain what change has been made.  You have to read the code to find out.  The screenshots are not very readable because of the small text and dark background, but fortunately they are backed up by links to the commit that makes that change. That allows the reader to display the change in whatever theme and font size is most readable.  In the test plan, only manual testing is covered, and it is not shown that the tests pass.  Automated testing should also be included.

Project name: Fix 'Back' link on 'New Late Policy' page
Feedback on project:
Pros: 1. Follows the project details 2. Did not break any functionality while refactoring 3. Added comments to make the code more understandable 4. Added few tests as well Cons: 1. The PR fails codeclimate checks 2.The PR has 1 failing test. 3. Readme, todo files and schema.rb has been changed, hence not mergable, 4. documentation is  poorly done; readable comments are lacking.

Test skeleton was not used for controller tests.
Feedback on design doc: The page describes the changes to be made, but does not explain HOW they were made, nor link to the code changes.  It is essentially no help in understanding the code.  The tests are described but not linked to.  It appears that what is described is the tests BEFORE the project was undertaken, not the code written by the students.

Project name: Further refactoring and improvement of review_mapping_helper
Feedback on project:
Pros: 1. Mostly follows the assignment 2. Did not break any functionality while refactoring 3. Most method names are more ruby-like now 4. Added comments to make the code more understandable Cons: 1. Some of the variable names are not readable (eg: feedback_response_maps_with_constant_assignment) 2. The PR fails codeclimate checks (although most failures are unrelated to the code introduced) 3. Code coverage could have been increased with at least 1 additional test.

Did not use provided test skeletons, did not increase test coverage.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of what was done. It explains the changes well. The first issue that I notice is that the problem statement lists 9 changes that should be made, but does not organize or group them in a way that would be easy to understand.  The changes should be listed and considered in the same order.  Changes 5 through 9 are described before changes 1 through 4.  Most of the changes are described in prose, which is good.  In most of the screenshots, the code is quite small; you need to zoom in to read it.  And, being a screenshot, it is not searchable.  Finally, it is on a dark background, which in this context makes it harder to read.  I favor the approach of, for each change, simply linking to the commit that makes that change. That allows the reader to display the change in whatever theme and font size is most readable.

There are three ways that this document could be improved.  (1) Move the screenshots to be adjacent to the functionality or changes that they demonstrate.  Right now, you would have to skip around in the document to get a good overview. (2) The code is not shown. The best way to show it is to provide a link to the individual commit in which the change was made. (3) Include a test plan, both for automated and manual testing, as appropriate.

Feedback on project: The team has implemented various improvements, including correcting comments, refining code readability, and optimizing structure. The introduction of meaningful variable names and the reduction of cyclomatic complexity reflect their dedication to enhancing code quality. The team has added useful comments for new and existing methods. However, upon reviewing the code related to the bug fix(out of the scope of the problem statement) in the check_outstanding_reviews method, there are concerns regarding the adequacy of the solution. It appears that the code may not sufficiently address the identified bug. The team has made use of the test cases as per the Test Skeletons provided, and there is an increase in the test coverage. Overall, the team has performed admirably.
Feedback on design doc: The document begins with a short, readable dscription. Following that, screenshots of changes are provided, but the commentary does not explain what change has been made. You have to read the code to find out. And occasionally the code is quite small; you need to zoom in to read it. Sometimes the same snippet is spread across multiple screenshots.  And, being screenshots, they are not searchable. Finally, it is on a dark background, which in this context makes it harder to read. I favor the approach of, for each change, simply linking to the commit that makes that change. That allows the reader to display the change in whatever theme and font size is most readable.  The test plan is very good, except that it does not say anything about the logic of the tests, which would be very helpful.  However, the document does give statistics on the tests, which is more than other design docs do.

Feedback on project: The team made valuable contributions to the Pull request, but there were some unnecessary files included. They've done well with adhering to clean code principles in naming variables and methods, and they've also corrected and added comments. However, there's a small oversight – a method was deleted, but the corresponding call to that method in one of the view pages was not updated. Additionally, some method names, like 'delete_signup_common,' could be improved for clarity. While they successfully adjusted the spec file to pass test cases for refactored methods, it's suggested they consider adding new test cases from the provided test skeleton for enhanced test coverage.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the changes made.  Good description of the code changes, and the rationale for them.  The code is displayed in several ways, by screenshots, by links to commits, and in inset boxes in wiki markup. In many cases, the changes are described clearly in prose.  I would have preferred it if each change had been shown in a separate commit. The organization of the page would have been improved if wiki headers had been used for each change.  Instead, most of the changes are in the Solutions section, with no clear indication of when the description of the next issue is starting.

Project name: Reimplement assignment model and assignment controller
Feedback on project: The team successfully performed the migrations required to associate assignments with existing models. They adhered to guidelines, ensuring each method served as a RESTful endpoint.  The controller methods are concise and efficiently leverage corresponding model methods. To enhance clarity, it's recommended to consolidate several migration files into a single file, reducing potential confusion. While the model methods underwent thorough testing, it's worth noting that the controller methods are yet to be tested through Rswag due to an authentication issue.
Feedback on design doc:
This documentation tells WHAT was done, but except for a few sentences on Assignment.rb, does not explain WHY it was done the way that it was.  That is important to understanding the design.  For example, why is destroy the only method that takes a parameter?  How is the code written in the various files?  There are no screenshots, or links, or anything describing the general thought process in structuring the code.

For the test cases, it would be better to make them headers than bullet points; it would make the structure more obvious. More detail should have been provided on why Postman was used for testing, and how it was used.  The screenshots are almost unreadable and thus are not helpful.

Project name: Reimplement duties controller.rb and badges controller.rb
Slated to possibly be merged: Team did not have a good idea of the functionality they were reimplementing.
Feedback on project: The team was successful in achieving the goals of this project which is to implement CRUD APIs for duties and badges. The model and controller code looks clean. They were able to address the issues the previous team faced while doing this project.
Feedback on design doc: The page contains good descriptions of the individual methods, but lacks an overview of what duties and badges are, and how they fit into Expertiza. The descriptions in the testing methodologies could have been more specific, e.g., when "containing all duties" is mentioned, you could have said that you were creating two duties and testing that each is correctly fetched (and testing 3 would've been better than testing 2).  The testing section included no headings for specific scenarios.  If it had, the flow would have been easier to follow.

Feedback on project: The team has taken extra effort to make the code really readable. They have added very proactive comments, good variable and function names, validation. The team was proactive in discussing their thoughts and went through with implementing every suggestions discussed in the weekly meetings.
Feedback on design doc: This is a good description of the code that was written.  It would have been better if the code had been described in more detail.  For example, where you say, "The original code has variables like 'P', 'D' and 'A'", you could have explained the lifecycle of a request: when created it is pending, and then it can be either accepted or declined.  Also, each method in the code should have at least one comment, and almost none of them do.  "check_team_status" is a bad name for a method that checks whether a team is full. The section on file changes should explain why the changes were made, and it doesn't.  The section on testing should say which tests were written and why.  Overall, with this document, you show components and expect the reader to figure out why you did what you did.  The point of documenting it is that you should explain what has been done and why.

Slated to possibly be merged: But remove redundant methods first.
Feedback on project: The team was proactive and set up meetings whenever they were facing an issue. They also asked appropriate questions and made sure they understood what the task was. The team has done a good job with the code and followed the guidelines to implement the controller methods. The tests the team has added are not adequate since they could not run the tests on their system. This needs to be worked on in the next program and tests cases but must be written for the controller.
Feedback on design doc: The document describes changes, but does not show, or point to, any code. This would make it quite hard to follow what you have done. The reader might not be sure where a particular change had been made. The test plan should say what was tested about each method. Nits: For headers of sections or paragraphs, please use something other than straight Roman text, e.g., boldface, italics, or headings, so that it's apprarent what's a heading.  Sometimes you underline the text, but that's not done consistently.  Also, italics or boldface is preferred to underlining.  Where you say, "1. Changed Function Names: The function names have been chosen to be more concise and descriptive. For example, the method originally named 'copy' is used to create a copy of a questionnaire, and this change makes the code more intuitive," you didn't say what you changed the name to.  It would help to cite the location (line numbers) of each change.

The team has also attempted to split course teams from assigment teams, but the course part is missing. One thing to note is that the team was initially a one member team
Feedback on design doc: The code is quite clear, but it would be better to have the description of what each method does juxtaposed with the code itself, rather than appearing before the code for each class.  I would suggest simply listing the names of the methods at the top and providing a hyperlink to the description, with the code immediately following the description.  The tests could have been described in much more detail: what are they designed to test, and how do the assertions test that?  Also, with respect to "bequeath_copy", yes, there could be a better name, but I still think that "bequeath" is a good name for a method in an assignment that grants its participants to the course that it is associated with.

Slated to possibly be merged: ... if we can remove the whitespace-only changes to hundreds of files.
Feedback on project: The team dynamics were good and members from the team made sure to ask questions and set up meetings when stuck with an issue. The team has tried to reimplement the question hierarchy but have committed unnecessary whitespace changes as part of the pull request which makes it difficult to look at the diff. All files having only whitespace changes should be excluded from the pull request. The team has also written test cases which are currently passing however it looks like they are trying to render partials in the model which is not correct. They have done a good job of implementing the test skeleton.  The team has to refactor the code to make sure that the appropriate json responses are returned instead of making use of html elements as done by the previous team.
Feedback on design doc: I like the way you describe the changes you intend to make.  However, simply listing the types of questions, without explaining them, and providing a long list of the files modified, is likely to leave readers bewildered.  The question types should be described in a single line.  The files should be grouped into several categories; then the category should be described, and it should be shown how each file falls into the category.  But the biggest need is to explain the changes that you did make, not just what you intended to do at the start of the project.

Merged?: Riya:  Approved and reviewed changes, pending merge after access
Feedback on project: The code is quite clean, although I have questions about a couple of the class methods.  Also, is assignment.rb the best place to drop all waitlisted teams?  What about signup_sheet?  There are places where the comments could be more complete (noted in my Github review).  Try to make clear why a topic is being reassigned, which team it's being reassigned to, and why it's being assigned to them.  The build did not pass because of one failing test.
Feedback on design doc: This is a good description of the way that you improved the code.  You could have shown the code changes better by putting them side by side, instead of several insets below each other.  In the code for deleting a signup, I think I may see a bug: it checks whether the signed-up team count is 1, not whether all slots are taken.  Suppose there are two slots for this topic; will the code still work?  Perhaps so, but this is an issue that should surely be explained in prose and is not.  On the test methods, there are long code segments without any prose description of what is being tested, or what assertions are being invoked.
