Feedback on design doc: This is a very good design document, and the intended changes are described in good detail. Unfortunately, there is no information on changes actually made in the code. The document should have been revised to reflect the implementation. The tests are described in suffiicient detail, but there should be links to the actual code. The page can be improved substantially by just linking to appropriate commits in the repo used for the pull request.

Slated to possibly be merged: Some changes are required, to make it working with the model which is done by another team. Naming convention was miscommunicated to the team so it needs to be changed. other than some minor changes and comments most of the code is usable.
Feedback on project:
The team did an excellent job in implementing the controller. I was impressed by the tests written by the team.
They reached out frequently for feedback and worked on the code review comments provided. 
Design doc is well organized, Good code comments.
Overall it is a project that can be merged.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable, and the rationale for changes is described in good detail. It would have been helpful to update to reflect the changes made in the code. There should have been more prose describing the code changes. The tests are shown as screenshots, but not described in detail, and it would have been better to describe them in more detail (e.g., what are the tests for)?

Slated to possibly be merged: Probably not. While there are improvements in design over the legacy version, too many code smells remain. Someone else should rewrite it, starting from scratch without the confusing class methods.
Feedback on project: The team has done a good job of implementing iterators and visitors to improve the design. This approach could likely be carried further to eliminate the need for methods like Response>>self.assessments_for_team, or the similar method that returns all assessments in a particular round (responses_for_team_round). In response_map.rb, the same issue is raised by methods metareview_response_maps and self_final_versions_from_reviewer. Ditto for teammate_review_response_map.rb>>self.teammate_response_report. Tests contain useful comments.
Feedback on design doc: The document is well structured and explains the requirements well. However, it does that by listing the changes to be made; it would have been more readable if those changes had been summarized in prose. The diagrams show the classes affected, but do not explain what was done to them. The code changes are described in more detail, and the motivation is clear. Rather than using excerpts from the changed methods, it would have been better to link to Github commits that show what code was changed.

Slated to possibly be merged: No, because of the confusing class methods and the large number of sort parameters on many methods.
Feedback on project: As noted during the demo, I have reservations about the class methods in the various node classes. Even if they work, the rationale for coding them this way is unclear, and would be unclear to other readers. The uses of sort are not clear either, and lack any comments that would explain them. In the reimplemented system, most sorting could be done in the front end, possibly removing the need for sort code in back-end classes. Other than that, the code is clean, but the lack of clarity in the aforementioned methods could confuse developers and make it a constant battle to avoid complicating the code. Many of the test methods have good comments.
Feedback on design doc: Very good description of changes to be made. Good motivation for making changes. It does not cover the code changes that were made, though. The document was not updated after the implementation was done. Tests should have been described in more detail, instead of just being listed.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, most code is clean, but not all.
Feedback on project: [Overwritten by mistake. Will be supplied later.]
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable, and the changes are described in a clear and readable way. But I missed the changes in self.get_all_review_comments; it seems like only the old version was shown. Also for Issues 3 and 5, the changes seem to be missing. Oh, now I see; the changes are down below. This would require the reader to refer back to the earlier sections to understand the changes. Better to cover the changes right after describing the problem. The description of the test plan should have been more detailed.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes.
Feedback on project:
The team dynamics were excellent and they did User Interface changes for Courses and Assignment. Implemented search and sort functionality on courses and Assignment which was pretty cool. Implemented Card UI type feature for the courses.Some of the icons on the expertiza needs to be changes, maybe we can work on them later on. 
Some of the icons on the expertiza needs to be changes, maybe we can work on them later on.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable, and the design decisions are well motivated. It shouldn't be necessary to describe React, because many other parts of the system also use it. The code changes are described without any code being shown. While showing all the Javascript would be too verbose, it would have been helpful to link to specific Github commits to show particular functions. There should be text describing how screenshots are related to each other, rather than just being juxtaposed without any intervening text.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, this new implementation of the course controller is needed for the new version of expertiza. They did a great job at creating the REST endpoints and tested it well. Overall , a great job!
Feedback on project: They did an excellent job at implementation of Courses model and controller. They showed variety of http requests. They worked really hard on debugging test cases and the hard work really paid off. It is a really good project which can be merged and reused. The code is clean and readable.They had really good team dynamics and they kept me updated with every change. They were told to add few comments on the tests. And they did add them later on.
Feedback on design doc: The document is quite readable, and it is easy to undersand the design. However, it says next to nothing about the implementation, which should have been described in detail. The test plan is just a list of tests. Though it is pretty readable, it would have been helpful to have a sentence or two describing how the tests are related. It is easy for the reader to see what is being tested. However, the test plan should have been described in more detail, and I would have liked to see more detail on how the tests work.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, the implementation of the model and controller is of high quality, with thorough testing and code coverage that adheres to established guidelines. All required endpoints have been implemented and the code is well-structured and independent. Overall, the implementation is of excellent quality.
Feedback on project:
I would like to take a moment to express my sincere appreciation for the excellent work that you have done on the reimplementation of the Account Request module. I am truly impressed with the quality of your work, your dedication, and your commitment to delivering a top-quality code.

Your code is clean, well-organized, and follows all the guidelines that were mentioned in the project description. Your tests are thorough and cover the code to almost 100%, which is a remarkable achievement. I can see that you have put a lot of effort into resolving the pull request comments that I made, and the code is now ready to be merged.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable. It describes the changes well, and explains the rationale for them. However, several screenshots are juxtaposed without intervening text to indicate how they are related. The screenshot of models was not very readable; it was too dark and fuzzy. Then there should have been a description of what the Swagger screenshot shows. It would have been good to have a narration of how the various requests are used, instead of just a list of them. Also, I would have liked to see more explanation of the tests, e.g., how they work, and why they test what they test.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project:
I was pleased to see that you addressed all of the review comments we discussed during our mentor meetings and pull request reviews.
The code you produced is not only clean and readable, but it also met our high standards for quality and maintainability. Your commitment to resolving all of the review comments helped to ensure that the project met all of our objectives and was ready to be merged.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable. It explains the functionality well, and gives a good idea of what was done. It does describe the code, but in single sentences, not paragraphs. Probably it would be more readable to put them in a table. The code snippets are rather long. It might be more readable to show them as links to Github commits. Also, the text should describe how the code works. The test descriptions are good, but it would have been better to describe the screenshots in prose.

Slated to possibly be merged:
Lacks comments and minor changes required for the method names. 
The grading history page doesnt show the assignment name and the group/user that it is correctly displaying. It needs some additional changes for it to be in a working state.
Can be a good place to start for the next team working on this.
Feedback on project:
The project had a slow start in the first phase of the project. They picked up speed and finished all the requirements of the project in the second phase.
The comments on the demo were addressed and fixed today. 
I think the tests are not enough and no new tests were added to fix it.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable, and the changes are described in detail. Could have done more to explain the code snippets that were changed, e.g., in the grading_history_info.rb file, or in the view template. The screenshots show clearly what the project has implemented. It would have been even better if prose described the salient features of the screens, e.g., the dropdown to choose a report type, or the reason that different reviews on the review report are colored different colors. The tests are described well. And now, one nit: The page is named "Grading audit trail(Project 4)" without a space between "trail" and the parenthesis. In prose, you always need to leave a space before a parenthesis. I wanted to change it myself, but I couldn't do so without copying the content to a new page and losing the edit history.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project:
The team did a great job of completing the main part of the project, which involved moving from user to team_participant. It's worth noting that they continued from their previous open-source software (OSS) project, which is impressive.

All the issues were fixed, and while there were a few areas where more comments could have been added, the team's comments in the important migration file were helpful. Additionally, the team showed initiative in moving the views to partial to improve the code's cleanliness.

Overall, the team's efforts were successful in completing the project and addressing all issues. Their dedication to enhancing code quality is evident in their actions to include comments and improve the code's cleanliness. Great job!
Feedback on design doc: Good job of describing the changes to be made, and explaining why they were made. Would have been helpful to have more detail on the code changes, e.g., what was changed, and why. It would be better to link to the code in Github, where it would be easier to see what was changed. Also, it would have been good to have a summary of what was done, rather than just a list of changes.

Project name: Fix "Back" link on “New Late Policy” page
Slated to possibly be merged: Probably yes, some minor changes and this should be good to go.
Feedback on project:
The team did a great job fixing the bugs related to the new late policy and extending the previous project. However, there are some suggestions to improve the code further.

Firstly, it's important to keep the pull request (PR) focused on the changes made to the code, and to avoid including README updates in the PR.

Secondly, abstracting some methods to resolve DRY issues was a good move, and the team may want to consider making new helper functions private functions.

Lastly, the team's addition of sufficient test cases and comments in the test cases is appreciated, as it shows a commitment to quality assurance and maintainability of the codebase.

Overall, the team has done well in updating and improving the project
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable, and the changes are described in detail. In the "Problems Resolved" section, several screenshots are juxtaposed with no intervening code. There should be a line or two of prose between them, to explain how the screenshots are related. The code changes are clearly described, and they are described with sufficient detail. However, the screenshots are not very readable. It would have been better to link to the Github diff view to show the code that has been changed. Also, The tests are described well, though succinctly.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project:
The team successfully implemented and fixed the edit/view advice button for the questionnaire. The route was able to go to the edit page and edit the advice before redisplaying it, which is excellent.

All the edge cases were handled, and the team demonstrated them during the demo. They also made sure not to show advice for questionnaires that do not have the edit advice option, which is a good design choice.

The code's test cases are passing, which indicates good quality assurance. However, the team made some changes to the codeclimate yml file, but it was not explained why this was done.

While there could be more comments for some of the methods, the team did create a separate function for set_questionnaire_parameters, which shows good design principles. Inside save_new_questions, there is a variable named q that could be made more meaningful.

I appreciate the team's initiative in creating QUESTION_MAP for mapping the questionnaire name to the appropriate model, which is a great design choice.

Overall, the team did an excellent job in implementing and fixing the edit/view advice button for the questionnaire. They also demonstrated a good understanding of design principles and made sure to handle all the edge cases. The code quality is good. Great work!
Feedback on design doc: Good description of changes. The table of changes implemented is very good. For the sample of code changes, the bullet points don't tell enough about the purpose of the change. 1 or 2 sentences of prose would be welcome. Also, the test plan is not described in detail. Prose descriptions of the tests, especially in comments, would be helpful.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project: This team refactored the review_mapping class. The team mainly work on cut down the LOC but died not work on the logic of the code that much. All current test cases passed, but no new tests were added.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable. It explains the changes well. The first half of the document makes good use of text images to accompany the descriptions. But later in the document, the text images grow less readable, and need to be expanded considerably in order to be read. In the test plan, the tests just presented one after another in a list, and the organization of the list is not clear. The screenshots should have been more legible, and some prose should have explained why those specific methods needed to be tested.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, finally we have code for this that is readable.
Feedback on project:
The view looks very nice!
There is a link on the View Submissions page to the metrics for each team.
You can toggle Github metrics on & off on the main Edit Assignment page.
Comments appear to be very good!
A lot of logic is in the controller, though; wouldn't it be better in the model? Parsing methods, for example.
metrics_controller is too long, and contains methods specific to github. That is not scalable; these methods should be in individual model classes for the different metrics.
Support for charts is in metrics_helper.rb
There is a model file, metric.rb, which is specialized to Github. Better to rename it github_metric.rb. It contains only class methods, so its design can be improved.
I am also concerned about addition of metrics methods to grades_helper.rb; couldn't there be a github_helper?
From auth_controller.rb, "when "github2021" # due to github h" could be removed.
Comments are not very good in the tests, though. They should say what the test is trying to detemrine.
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable, and the changes are clearly described. However, the code changes are described in bullet points, and it would have been better to begin with a prose summary. Code changes are shown reasonably well, but links to Github commits in Github diff view would have been a bit clearer. The code sequences of the refactored methods in metrics_controller.rb are a bit long, and it might have helped to have them grouped into subheadings. Notwithstanding, this is a good description of the code changes and an excellent presentation of the UI improvements.

Project Grade: 95 / 10 for those who did no work
Feedback on project: The team of students did a good job in working on the project, but there are some areas that need to be addressed. It's important to ensure that commented out code is not left in the final project to avoid confusion. On the positive side, the changes made are good and well-commented, making it easier for others to understand the code, despite some grammatical mistakes. However, there is an issue with the find_current_stage method, as it appears to be returning the due date instead of working as intended. Overall, the team did well, but addressing these issues is crucial to ensure a high-quality project.
Feedback on design doc: Good job of explaining refactoring, but I think you could have done more to show the code changes.  For example, only the check_condition refactoring changes were shown in code.  A submission_allowed method was shown, but it was not clear whether that was the new version.  Also, the tests were not described in prose, which is one of the most important needs for programmers.

Project name: Refactor Questionnaire View to display Bookmark Rating
Feedback on project: The team did a good job in fixing the issues mentioned in the document. Relevant comments were added to the code. Their code comments are very comprehensive and clearly communicate the changes. The team was enthusiastic with working on the project since the start and asked questions whenever they faced an issue. Overall a good job in refactoring!
Feedback on design doc: The refactorings are shown mainly in two screenshots, that are difficult to read because the text is so small and the contrast is not high.  The best way I have found for showing changes is to link to individual commits in Github, where partciular implementation changes have been made.  There are no descriptions of the test cases, just screenshots complete with warning messages from when they were run.

Feedback on project: The team is doing great. They were very proactive and asked a lot of questions early on. They have successfully re-implemented most of the Questionnaire & Questions Controller and showed me working REST API endpoints. They also worked on RSpec tests for the controller and fixed several issues with the user interface. For example, they addressed the problem of editing the questionnaire without being able to edit the related spec like name. Overall, the team is taking ownership of their work and demonstrating a strong work ethic.
Feedback on design doc: There is a good list of code snippets that were discarded, and a good reason why. The new code is not shown so well.  There is a single, 123-line long snippet for QuestionnairesController, and a 93-line snippet for QuestionsController.  In both cases, the code is pasted in as a single sequence, whereas it would've been much more readable if it had been separted into pieces, with explanations of changes juxtaposed with those changes.  Very little was said about testing.

Feedback on project: The team of students working on the project did well, but there are some areas where improvements can be made. There seems to be confusion around the need for a create questionnaire method when there is already a create method in the controller. Additionally, there is a problem with dryness in the Create and Update methods, and the team should rewrite them to update the design and make them more efficient. They can also consider adding a new question controller and moving the methods from the questionnaire controller, using a polymorphism method to check the types of the questions type. It's important to note that the team should rewrite the code and not just copy from the old project, and it's advisable to add more comments to the code so that people with no knowledge who are reading it can easily understand what is going on. Lastly, while the tests written are pretty fine, it would be beneficial to have more tests testing the edge cases as well. Overall, the team did well, but there is always room for improvement, and the suggestions above can help take the project to the next level.
Feedback on design doc: Good job of describing the changes to be made.  I would have liked to see more detail on why the changes were made.  For example, the sentence starting, "Other refactoring changes" just says what kinds of things were updated, but does not point to them or describe why the changes were made.  Where you said, "Another refactoring change we worked on was adding correct comments  ..." I would have liked to see an example of a comment that was updated and an explanation of why.  There is very little on testing; it doesn't explain what tests were written, or why they test everything that might malfunction.

Project Grade: 92 / 20 for those who did little work
Feedback on project: The team started a little late. Sanket and Amisha missed a couple of meetings. Dibya was present at all meetings and was the only one to complete expertiza setup on her machine. She has contributed majorly in the reimplementation code and has done a fairly decent job with coding all independently.  Nit: has_true_false_questions should be has_true_false_questions? because it returns a boolean.
Feedback on design doc: This is an exemplary description of the rationale behind each of the changes, and behind each of the tests.  In all cases, the descriptions indicate an understanding of what the code is doing and explain why each change has been made. The only improvement that I could suggest is more readable screenshots.  This could be done by providing direct links to commits that have implemented each of the described changes.

Feedback on project: The team started early enough on the code and showed me the code as they were progressing. However, the test file implementation started very late and the team was somehow not clear on the testing part till the first submission. Later, they picked it up and delivered test cases.The team did a good job with the reimplementation. Methods have been implemented as REST end points and are returning JSON Objects. The design document specifications have been met. More work is needed to match the requirement of independent backend and frontend.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page clearly describes the purpose of all methods.  I think it is a very good wiki page to refer to for front-end implementation.  The test plan has good descriptions of the tests, but does not show any code for the tests.  Ideally, the descriptions would be included in the code as comments at the beginning of each test.

Feedback on project: The team performed very well. They asked good questions during meetings and also asked about any blockers that they faced. They have done a good job reimplementing the participants model. Method comments should be provided for all non-obvious methods, and they should tell what the paramteter(s) are for.  The name "maps" for a variable is confusing; does it relate to a response_map? The code is meeting the design document requirements. The wiki page is also good. It has a good explanation.
Feedback on design doc: This was a reimplementation project, but the description seems to suggest that it was a refactoring project.  What is important here is why methods were chosen for the class, not just why you didn't want to directly copy methods from the old implementation.  The test plan is unusually good in that the code comments do say what is being tested.

Feedback on project: This is a controller reimplementation and the team first started with looking at the code even before the requirements for the reimplementation controllers were provided. They did some changes which they had to scrap because of our change to introduce a REST API. They came up with a design that splits the controller into 2 controllers to have separation of concerns of sign_up_team and sign_up_topic. They managed to finish sign_up_teams controller with some tests added. They were able to take feedback from mentor meetings and 1st round reviews to update their code. Documentation is on point, code comments are good. The team had little time to implement it and if given more time can fix minor issues and work on the other controller and the front-end.  The names should be changed so that "signup" as a noun or adjective is spelled as a single word, whereas the phrasal verb "sign up" is spelled as two words.  This should be done before the class is merged.
Feedback on design doc: Excellent description of the design decisions. The writeup is quite readable, but it could have been improved by including code snippets from the pull request.  Also, the test plan does not describe how the tests work.

Feedback on project: The team started early, could understand the requirements, and worked on the reimplementation of the models. They could finish one model with tests to validate the working of the methods. They tried to avoid as many class methods as possible. The team still needs to work on waitlist functionality and the related methods. The team has worked on separate models and divided the responsibility equally. The code is well commented and follows appropriate design principles.  The names should be changed so that "signup" as a noun or adjective is spelled as a single word, whereas the phrasal verb "sign up" is spelled as two words.  This should be done before the class is merged.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page describes the issues well.  The tables of method names, unfortunately, give very shallow descriptions, little more than could be inferred from the names themselves. They should clearly explain what the method does, e.g., instead of "update the waitlist and release topics" it could say what "release a topic" means and how the waitlist changes when that happens. The tests could have comments describing the condition being tested, and this information should be included as a comment in the code.

Feedback on project: The code seems to exhibit generally good style, except that there are way too many class methods.  Why is latest_feedback a class method? Doesn't it refer to latest feedback on a particular response map?  It could probably be named and implemented better.  It is not safe to assume that an assignment has 3 rounds.  It is also not appropriate to use an IF statement to append a variable to a structure.  Ditto for feedback_response_report; it's a report for a particular map, not for all maps in general.  It also seems that sending mail from response_map and its subclasses is a violation of the SRP.  response.rb also includes only class methods, which is troubling.  The response_map hierarchy is in general implemented well, but again it has class methods.  Since the methods are operating only on this instance of the review_response_map, it is difficult to see why they are class methods.  I have similar reaction to the other class methods in this class.  Tests look good, but without comments, it's hard to figure out what they do.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very good description of the changes that will be made, and the rationale for making them.    The test section described the tests that were made and then showed code snippets.  It would have been so much more useful if the test descriptions had been added as comments at appropriate places in the test files themselves.

Feedback on project: This is a good attempt at implementing the functionality, but I wish you had discussed the code with me before writing it.  I could have pointed out ways to improve the coding, particularly to simplify method names and avoid excessive use of class methods.  In assignment.rb, num_review_rounds is set to return a constant 2.  If you are going to use this temporarily as a stub, there should be a comment that clearly identifies it as such.  self.get_all_questions_with_comments_available is a long name, and a class method.  The design here is very unclear.  Response.rb consists almost entirely of class methods, which is not good design. self.get_all_review_comments is hard to understand, and moreover, returns a custom data structure, which is bad style.  aggregate_questionnaire_score: I thought this method was going to be implemented in a mixin.  The tests are hard to read; they should have comments explaining what they test.  gemfile.lock should not be committed.
Feedback on design doc: This is a good description of the need for a simpler implementation.  It is written, though, like it described a refactoring project, not a reimplementation project.  I would like to have seen some description of the way functionality was divided between classes, rather than simply from the standpoint of what was changed.  The testing section gave detailed information on the tests that were written.  Ideally, that information would have been included in comments within the tests themselves.

Project name: Reimplement QuizQuestion and its child classes
Feedback on project: This team did an excellent job of reimplementing QuizQuestion and its child classes. They created a complete UML diagram for these classes, including their attributes, methods, and class methods. Additionally, they identified and extracted duplicate code and consolidated it into the highest-level class. Furthermore, they conducted thorough testing of the QuizQuestion class. However, given our decision to use React as the frontend framework, this implementation may not be suitable for the new Expertiza. Nonetheless, the team performed well on this project.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the need for changes and the changes made.  The test plan is well described too; however, some of the steps should have been described in comments in the test files as well as on the wiki page.  The description on the wiki page is just the kind of comments I would like to see in the test files themselves.  Given the use of HTML in the project classes, it would have been good to see some screenshots.  Still, overall, very good work.

Feedback on project: This team has re-implemented the answer model and refactored all class methods to use the ActiveRecord API. They have also implemented a new 'answers_by_response' method that returns answers for each response. Additionally, the team has added a considerable number of tests for the answer model, which allowed them to meet the project requirements. However, the introduction of new gems has necessitated several updates to other gems, which could potentially introduce dependency problems in other projects.
Feedback on design doc: This document does a good job of describing the objectives of the project, but it contains very little description of how changes were made.  Were the code snippets newly written?  What existing code was removed to accommodate them?  The purpose of the tests should have been described, rather than just displaying the code.  Also, the title of the document should include the project name, not just its number.

Project name: Refactoring Node model and its subclasses
Feedback on project: The team initially faced some issues in setting up the environment, but resolved it quickly. The team was proactive and enthusiastic with working on the project. They have made necessary improvements in the node file and all of its sub class files. They have added relevant comments wherever necessary. There was also an issue for creating a method that returns True/False, but that needed a DB migrate, but still they have added a code for this and we can uncomment it and use this code. They have also added relevant test cases. Overall a great job!
Feedback on design doc: Excellent description of code changes.  Linking to actual diffs would have been even better.  Tests are covered well.  Repeated instances of warning messages could have been edited out for conciseness.

Feedback on project: The team has correctly refactored course.rb and course_team.rb. They have done a good job fixing all the issues that were mentioned in the problem statement. They have used better names for refactoring the code, and they have added informative comments wherever needed. All team members contributed equally. They were proactive and  kept asking questions early on. Relevant tests have been changed, the coverage has been increased and the build passes. Overall, a great job!
Feedback on design doc: The page does a great job of describing why changes are necessary and linking to individual commits to show how they were effected.  There was less narration in the testing section.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: This team did a great job with refactoring, they moved the methods where they belong, changed a good amount of class methods to instance methods and one operator overloading as well. They also did a good job covering the code with rspec test cases and improved the code coverage by significant amount. The pull request looks  good, the codeclimate issues are old and not present on the new build.
Feedback on design doc: The document does a pretty good job of explaining why changes were made.  There could have been more description of what each screenshot shows; it was clear to me as an expert, but would probably not have been clear to others.  There were no screenshots showing how deadlines work in staggered-deadline assignments, just a statement saying that the tests were repeated for them.

Project name: Refactor user_controller.rb, user.rb and its child classes
Feedback on project:
From the first meeting, the team seemed to be lazy, and I felt like they were only working just before the meetings. They didn't take a proactive approach and instead, relied on me for guidance at each point. Despite my suggestions, they only worked on the User model and didn't focus on related files.

Looking at their pull request, I only saw minor changes like adding comments and changing method names, with no significant design improvements. Moreover, the problems I mentioned in the descriptions were not addressed. It appears that the useful code changes they made were limited to what we discussed during meetings. The only good part was they added few test cases and improved some methods in User model.
Feedback on design doc: It is quite helpful to list your changes and then show diffs for them.  Two caveats: the listing of the changes does not seem to be in any order; it would be much easier to follow if they were in a logical sequence, or even better, divided into groups like "refactorings, bug fixes, rewrites" or "changes to model, changes to helpers".  Second, the ordering of the code screenshots is different from the ordering of the list.  Third, some of the text in screenshots is pretty small, and even after zooming in, it is hard to read.  A way to avoid this is to link directly to Github commits that make each modifcation; then it is easy to see the context for all changes.  The tests added should have been described in prose, instead of just showing the screenshots.

Feedback on project: The team was successful in rebasing the changes made by the previous team to the main branch. Minimal changes were made from the previous implementation and the comments on the past 2 implementations were not addressed. No additional tests were written by the team. Code review comments also were not addressed. The team started very late and could have done a better job at fixing known issues in the previous implementation and bringing it to a mergeable state.
Feedback on design doc: The description of changes is useful; however, I would have preferred that they copy from the previous team's web page so that their web page described all changes, not just the new ones.  Later on, there are (huge) screenshots juxtaposed with no text in between.  None of the screenshots actually show grading history.

Feedback on project: the teams_users_controller was renamed to teams_participants_controller, and TeamsUser was changed to TeamsParticipant. The majority of the changes made to the files were a result of this refactoring. Additionally, a participant Id column was added to the teams_participants table. However, when attempting to add migration to populate the participant_id, it was found that some rows were null as certain users did not have a row in the participant table for certain assignments. Due to this data mismatch, the dependency of user_id from the teams_participants table could not be completely removed, and as a result, the user_id column was not deleted from the table, as it would have a significant impact on the code. The view for student_teams was previously bloated, but it has now been segregated into partials. Furthermore, the existing test cases were modified so that they would pass for the new code which includes participant_id. I felt that issues realted to the db table and user_id could have been found earlier while implementing but the team discussed this issue in the very end. It was still a complex issue to backtrack and team spent sufficient time to debug it. Tests are failing so it's hard to be confident on the big PR. I don't know why the team edited previous migrations. (Talked to them - they changed it by mistake while refactoring using ruby mine, they will fix it in the final project). to change. the table name. This should not have happened.
Feedback on design doc: Excellent detail on the changes.  Readable narratives of what was done.  Analyses of the issues encountered.  The only thing that detracted from readability was the long list of files changed, without any indication of why they were affected.

Feedback on project: The team did a good job with the project requirements. They found good spots to make the code DRY.  They also added precise method comments. They also fixed some translations.  Moved some methods to model which seems correct. Test suite is also passing which makes it a good PR that can be merged. Small points - some method names like "parent_by_id" can be better like "retrieve_parent_by_id" or something else. This can also be something else "choose_copy_type"
Feedback on design doc: The writeup is quite readable; good job of describing each change in a sentence.  The test plan covers only 4 tests.  For these, it would have been better to link to the Github diff view, which would have shown the changes in more detail.  Also, the test plan should have described how the tests work (e.g., as would be done in extended code comments).

Feedback on project:
Overall great implementation and execution. Following were the contributions:-  #add_to_delayed_queue test failure in assignments_form_spec: simple fix, incorrectly referenced ‘mailers’ Sidekiq queue, needed to reference ‘jobs’ queue

Assignment_questionnaire method had two purposes so it was split into two methods. This was to preserve the single responsibility Assignment_default_questionnaire now returns a default assignment questionnaire while assignment_questionnaire finds and returns an existing assignment questionnaire. 

Added some unit test in spec/sidekiq_mail_worker_spec.rb that were earlier not written to test the individual functions that were written in the sidekiq_mail_worker

Updated Create method in Assignment controller to split function and make use of helper methods to make code more readable and modular. 

The issue with sidekiq queue failing some jobs were not fixed but it was out of the scope, but team provide some insights on why they are failing. Also tests are failing which might be an issue while merging the PR. There are some commented test cases which should be removed if not being used.
Feedback on design doc: Excellent presentation, showing changes in tabular format with links to individual commits so the changes can be clearly seen.  It would have helped to have had a narrative describing what kind of tests you wrote, rather than just screenshots of them running.  Manual test plan is detailed and effective.  Thanks for documenting what you commented out.

Feedback on project: This team has performed a good amount of refactoring on the existing codebase. They have reduced the number of lines of code by deleting unnecessary comments and removing redundant variables. Additionally, they have refactored some code logic, eliminating unnecessary loops. As a result of their efforts, the team successfully achieved the project goal. Although the biuild does not pass, the team claim is not becasue of the code they contributed.
Feedback on design doc: The team did quite a bit of work in characterizing the 14 changes they made to the code, as well as providing screenshots of 13 tests running.  The good part is the detail; the bad part is that there were just those two lists, and virtually no narration giving an overview.  Additionally, some of the code snippets were too large to fit on a single screen.  I would suggest pasting Github's diff view of the changes, side by side, or linking to individual commits in the repo, which would not only show the changes clearly, but would be text-searchable.

Feedback on project: Thank you for looking over earlier submissions and updating what past teams proposed.  What is the difference between github_login and custom_github_login? No comments explain this.  Controller has too many class methods; method exist is misnamed.  Method names in  metrics_controller.rb are confusing, and suggest that the design could be improved.
Feedback on design doc: The introduction is good.  As far as saying what changes have been made, the narration is not very readable.  It gives a list of 25 to 30 changes to the controller, without showing "before" and "after" code snippets, or even giving line numbers.  It would be quite difficult to learn anything from that.  After that, a single screenshot follows, but only one sentence explains what it shows.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.  It does not meet the specs & seems to contain pieces of several other projects.
Feedback on project: Most, but not all, of the code in this project has been borrowed from earlier pull requests.  The team was evidently judicious in what they borrowed, since outdated changes related to authentication were not included.  One of the features shown in the video, seeing the name and email address of reviewers, appears to be unrelated to the project specs.  On the other hand, the right panel in one view shows a two-dimensional display of "tags completed," which was part of a separate project in an earlier semester.  Also, in the heatgrid, the avatars shown for some reviewers seem to be from a separate project that was to allow the instructor to review projects submitted by all teams. There is no history provided for reviewing grades, and this was supposed to be included.  The presence of unrelated projects in the pull request would make it impossible to merge this project.
Feedback on design doc: The file did not describe the changes in enough detail.  The code changes were not described at all.  It would be good to have more than just a list of the changes that were made, so that the reader could see what was done and why.  It would have been helpful to have more detail on the tests, e.g., what they test for, and how they test it.

Project name: Calibration submissions should be copied along with calibration assignments assignments
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes!  Design is finally correct.
Feedback on project: Great job on writing clean code and good comments. This should be much more maintainable than previous versions.  The only pieces missing are copying submitted files (as well as links) and only invoking the method if "calibrate to" is checked for the assignment.
Feedback on design doc: Very good description of the changes made.  Most of them are described in prose.  However, the screenshots at the end are provided without much description.  I could follow them because I understand the system.  Others might have trouble.  Automated testing is not really described.  There is no discussion of tests that have been written, only of behaviors that should be verified.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes. The team did a good job at fixing all the issues raised in the project. Their code comments are very comprehensive and clearly communicate the changes. The team has updated the test cases and were also proactive in adding new test cases as required. They have even added comments to views where they were necessary which makes it easier to understand the intention behind their changes. As a bonus, they were diligent in going through the existing code and ensured that they made minimum changes to achieve their goals. They have reused existing code when possible following the DRY principle, which is commendable. All the checks are passing and their changes are safe to merge.
Feedback on project: The team did a good job at fixing all the issues raised in the project. Their code comments are very comprehensive and clearly communicate the changes. The team has updated the test cases and were also proactive in adding new test cases as required. They have even added comments to views where they were necessary which makes it easier to understand the intention behind their changes. As a bonus, they were diligent in going through the existing code and ensured that they made minimum changes to achieve their goals. They have reused existing code when possible following the DRY principle, which is commendable. The only place where I see an improvement is in the way the anonymized view was tested. The team could have gone through other places where the anonymized view is being used currently and tested it against their changes to ensure it is working as expected at all places.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the changes to be made. Good explanations of how the code works.  Useful to be able to mouseover the arrow a diagram to see what it is intended to show. "Heatgrid" and "heatmap" are used interchangeably; "heatgrid" is the more appropriate term.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, the team did a good job, however, there are some comments that the team needs to work on before it can be merged
Reuse: Probably not; there are cleaner ways to  implement waitlists than having a dedicated class.
Feedback on project: The team messed up with the architecture that the last team in Spring 22 worked on. The topics table was supposed to be connected with the AssignmentTeam table, but instead it was done through WaitlistTeam model was created, which was unnecessary.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing each of the changes that were made. Could have been improved by giving an overview  of all the changes, instead of just listing them in no particular order in the Our Work section.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes.  The code changes are clear improvements.  Several teams have worked on this project, and this is the best attempt.

Feedback on project:
The code changes seem neat, and good comments have been added.  "assignment.is_intelligent" has been corrected to "assignment.bid_for_topics", except that a view folder still has "is_intelligent" in its name.  In the project specs, some points have not been explicitly addressed (e.g., instance variables in update method, functionality of add_signup_topics vs. add_signup_topics_staggered).  

The video shows the assignment being seen (in a private browsing window) in one stage by a team that has chosen one topic, and in another stage by a team that has chosen another topic in a regular browsing window.  This seems correct, but to test it definitively you would have to show that each team could undertake the actions permitted to it in that stage (review, submit) and could not undertake the actions which it should not be able to. Similarly, the automated tests, while enhanced, do not test all of the staggered-deadline code.  So further testing would be needed before the project is merged.
Feedback on design doc: Very good job of describing the changes made.  I would have liked to see more of the code snippets, e.g., "Update method refactored by removing explicit update of every attribute of topic and instead performing this task through update_attributes function provided by rails"

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, they have added a plenty of meaningful comments and also increased test coverage

The team was able to enhance the project by adding major comments to the methods. Their code comments are really detailed and effectively clarify the changes. The methods have been correctly renamed to conform to rails norms. They also helped to beautify the controller and make it more intelligible and visible to readers. They also helped to improve the project's and controller's test coverage by proposing new negation test cases. To improve DRY, they refactored the send mail method to mailer and combined the Student view and general instructor view into a single file. The only area for improvement is the bundler issue; we need to replace the bundler, and they modified the Gemfile.lock, which should not have happened. Some of the identifier names are still not clear, e.g., notify_suggestion_approval. In tests, "it 'adds a participant is not successful' would be better stated as "is not succesful in adding a participant."  But overall, it does a good job of describing the changes that were made.

Slated to possibly be merged: Perhaps not, due to naming issues
Feedback on project:
The team was able to find places where the changes were supposed to be made. They have added comments in several places. They have also modifed peer_review_strategy method and tried to simplify it. They have also tried to change some route names and variables to reflect their real purpose. The tests had no comments describing what was being tested.  However, there seem to be several confusing names, and I wonder if the team has investigated the code thoroughly enough to understand its working.
Does time_create_last_review_mapping_record mean the time that the last review mapping record was created?  The variable should be given a clearer name.
Also, add_calibration_for_instructor, does that really mean add_calibration_by_instructor ?  That would be a clearer name.
Seems like add_reviewer_to_team should be add_reviewer_for_team, since the reviewer will not actually be on the team.
The name assign_reviewer_without_topic is confusing.  Reviewers do not have topics, although teams do.  A better name is needed.  The old code for assign_reviewer_dynamically is more readable.
"to create a metareviewer to a reviewer."  A metareviewer is not "created" (or "assigned") to a reviewer; a metareviewer is assigned for a review.
"Used: to remove reviewers not working on any reviews."  I think this comment is wrong too.  I don't think the reason for removing reviewers is because they aren't working on reviews.
"Used: to delete the meta review mapping from meta review response map" No, the metareview mapping IS given by the metareview response map.
def strategy_mapping_without_artifacts : This meaning of this name is quite unclear.

It would have been helpful to see the "before" and "after" code juxtaposed so it would be clear what changes were made. I would have liked to see the code that was moved to the teams.rb model class.  The test plan should have described the tests, and why they were changed.  But the screenshots were quite helpful.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project:
It is hard to figure out why some of the changes have been made in the code.  In particular, assignments_controller has been modified, and it wouldn't seem to have anything to do with sending email.  It seems like it might've been changed in the old version of the project, but the team should not have refactored the old, rejected project; they should have made their own changes, using the old project as a guide for what was needed.  One loop has been removed that evidently iterated over the questions in a questionnaire; this will likely create a bug.  Comments have been added, but most of them are very low level, reflecting a local knowledge of the code, but not helping to explain the purpose of methods or how the code fits together.
They have also added few tests and tried to increase the coverage.
Feedback on design doc: In the Problems & Solutions section, it is not clear whether the code that is shown is the old code or the new code.  For example, when it says, "Fix the naming convention of the calls," what changes were made, and why did these fix the failing tests?  (Oh, I see; that is in the next section of the document.  Well, it was not clear at first, and it would be better to juxtapose the new and old code so that the reader could easily see what was changed.) Also, the test plan should have been described in more detail.  It just says what to do to test it manually; it doesn't say (or show) what you should see when you do.

Merged?: No, but needs to be merged!
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: The team did a good job at fixing all the issues raised in the project. Their code comments are very comprehensive and clearly communicate the changes. The team has updated the test cases and were also proactive in adding new test cases as required. As a bonus, they were able to increase the code coverage of the files they touched, which is commendable. All the checks are passing and their changes are safe to merge.  We see one way to improve: Assure that all new methods have clear method comments, e.g., rebuild_role_cache.
Feedback on design doc: Wiki thoroughly mentions the scope of the project, and describes the changes. The one place that this Wiki really shines is the way they decided to discuss their changes. They have utilized a tabular format that describes the change, the reasoning behind the change, and has a commit link for that respective change. This makes it considerably easy to review and understand each and every change that has been made by the team. The only improvement I would suggest would be to add videos for manual testing steps.

Slated to possibly be merged: Redone as E2270, & that is mergeable.
Feedback on project:
The team did an excellent job of resolving and improving several issues in the class. They removed the if else statement from the suggestion controller and replaced it with a better code snippet. Moving the send email method from suggestion controller to Mailer class is part of the refactoring. In addition, the team added multiple tests to improve the application's testing and contributed to the application's smoothness by adding more test cases. They reduced readability by refactoring the notification method in the suggestion controller class (at the very least, it should have had additional comments), and the function approve suggestion and notify was created with the intention of doing multiple jobs, whereas a method should only do one. These are minor issues, but they contributed to the application's overall improvement.

On the other hand, the method comments that they added reflect only a knowledge of the immediately following code.  In several cases, they are actually wrong (users submit suggestions, not teams).  The new names for methods are not an improvement; it is still hard to figure out from the name alone what the method does. The checks for where a user is a Student are incorrect; they should check current_user_has_student_privileges; otherwise, TAs who are taking courses using Expertiza will not be able to perform these functions.
Feedback on design doc: This is a good list of changes made.  It would have helped to have some description of how the code was refactored, e.g., what changes were made to the notification method, and why.  The old version of the code is juxtaposed with the new version, but there is no narrative of why the new version is better.  For example, the name "send_email" is changed to "notify_suggestion_approval".  Why is the new name chosen?  What does it signify?  Who is being notified?  These issues could have been addressed in the narrative.  Similarly, in Problem 6, three tests are added, but you have to read the code to figure out what they do; there is no narrative description.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, although better tests need to be written. Very useful functionality, not much code changes. Merged.
Feedback on project:
A modest amount of code is written (95 lines), and the desired functionality is implemented very well. All the code is in very appropriate classes, and SRP violations are minimized. Unfortunately there are two places where bidding needs to be checked for in the view and appropriate text rendered if it is in use. In both cases, the then clause consists of only two lines, so it probably doesn't make sense to shunt it to a different partial. While the view does make active-record calls, it does so IN THE MIDDLE of a table line, so moving the calls out of the view wouldn't be easy.

The biggest deficiency is the shallow nature of the automated tests: they just check for the case where no bids have been entered. There are no tests that bids are listed properly.
Feedback on design doc: The description of the problem is generally good, although the bid-matching algorithm can't be called a "lottery" (before the matching algorithm was available, the system did use a lottery, and hence the references to "lottery" in the code). Unfortunately, the code changes are not described; one has to figure out the code by reading it. Also, the automated tests are not described at all (only the code listing is included).

Project name: Support for saying your team pair-programmed
Slated to possibly be merged:
Yes. Functionality is good. There are no bugs and the code is well written and designed. Merged.   With extra work, yes. 
1. There are changes in teams_users table, which is dropping support for usage of user_id and using participants_id instead. So, we have to migrate the usage of user_id to participant_id.

2. Team needs to add code comments to their changes. Almost all the code they wrote is without code comments.

3. Their "enum" implementation. Request status, team accepted pair program status) is weird, and they check the status with integer values 
(eg. Team.find(team.id).pair_programming_request == 2 ? "Yes": "No")

4. I'm unsure if this was conveyed or not but we really don't want backend operations done in the erb files.
Feedback on project:
The project was very well developed, with following things that could have been improved. 
1. Few DRY violations, but could have been easily fixed
2. Team needed to add code comments to their changes. Almost all the code they wrote is without code comments.
3. Their "enum" implementation. Request status, team accepted pair program status) was weird, and they check the status with integer values 
(eg. Team.find(team.id).pair_programming_request == 2 ? "Yes": "No")
4. Some backend operations (DB calls) were done in the erb files, which is an anti-pattern
Feedback on design doc: The rationale is described well, but the design document does not describe the code changes. It does describe the unit tests, but only in two sentences, which is pretty sparse when there are five tests.

Slated to possibly be merged:
Yes, with some refactoring (extra code comments).

Feedback on design doc: The project made changes to 44 files, but the design document covers only about 7 of them, and only a small fraction of the lines that are changed. It does make a good case, though, for the changes that the project has implemented.

Slated to possibly be merged:

Also will update my comments as I'm reserved on changing 
config/environments/development.rb, with precompiling the js files. This looks like it will compile these files anytime when application is loaded for everyone, which is something we do not desire. Not merged.
Feedback on project: The team dedicated a lot of efforts, and this can be seen in the project changes too. However, the project cannot be merged, the reason being follows: 1. UI testing the demo included was limited to rendering of views, and not over whether the elements in the tab worked as expected or not. 2. The pre-compilation bit of the js have side-effects. Feedback on design doc: The prose description of the issues is very good. For Issue 4, SRP violations, there should have been a text description of how it was violated and how your changes improved it. Stringing 5 or 6 screenshots together without any explanatory text is just unreadable.

Feedback on project: The team was able to solve the two open SQL injection security issues in Expertiza. They did so by specifying searches in two tables and improving some code in sign_up_sheet_controller. In addition, they added a test for the file. However, this test is not very intuitive and has contradictive strings. For example, it says it tests SQL Injections, but it’s not clear how. Also, it says it “Returns nothing” but is expecting a flash error to equal a message. The PR passes all tests on Github. This test may need to be changed a bit or removed before merging however.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page does a good job of explaining what the SQL Injection is and why it’s a problem. In the section on Running Tests, the code was provided with little explanation.  It should have been explained exactly what the tests were doing.

Slated to possibly be merged: Despite the relatively low score, we CAN consider merging this one.  It didn't do anything bad; it was just that it didn't improve as much as I would have liked to see.  If we commit it, we finally fix sign_up vs. signup, which has been a source of confusion for years.  So, yes, merge if tests pass.
Feedback on project: The team DRYed out code used to check for certain errors; however, that was done using an array of messages and then selecting one of them using a constant subscript, whereas it would have been better to pass the messages as parameters.  The compute_signup_topics method returns results by side-effects (in instance variables); probably this could have been done more cleanly.  Most of the changes involve regularizing use of "sign_up" vs. "signup"; this should ideally be done in a separate commit so it would be mergeable without merging the whole project.  My overall judgment is that some improvements have been made, but fewer than in most other refactoring projects.
Feedback on design doc: Very helpful to use links to commits to show code changes.  Unfortunately they do not open in a separate tab; that would be even better. Not only can one see the "before" and "after" code side by side, it is also searchable text.  It would have been better to juxtapose the issues with their corresponding solutions instead of putting them in two separate lists.  Given the large number of files modified, it would have been useful to include a summary of why each of them was included (e.g., which names were changed in them).

Project Grade: 96, or 98 if you remove dead code, 99 if you fix everything (Update: They fixed everything)
Feedback on project: The team did a decent job in identifying and breaking down the methods into smaller method. I also made them refactor the logic since the previous iteration of the project (merged into beta) was poorly written, and gave rise to lots of bugs. However, the team insted of removing changed code, they commented them out (which could be easily fixed). The code comments are also inconsistent, and are often not at the places where they should be. There are spelling mistakes in the code comments which I think could have been improved. I also believe they could have done a better job at "check_if_input_is_valid" function. Overall, I think after few changes, this project is mergable.
Feedback on design doc: The old and new code is described in different sections, which makes it hard to follow changes.  Using a Github diff view would have been better.  There should be more prose description of what each code snippet does.  There are a couple of lines about the shippets, but in most cases, these are not sufficient to explain the functionality.  Also, the difference between "New Code" and "Refactored Code" is not clear.  There are long bullteted lists of items that do not seem to be in any particular order; it would be better to explain the order that they are listed in.  For the tests, it would be better to explain how they work, not just what they are designed to show.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, assuming it is okay for brakemann to fail
Feedback on project: The team worked on refactoring the submitted_content_controller, and worked on all of the changes that were propsed in the writeup. The code climate analysis also shows a good status - Although it shows a warning  status for db related changes because they just removed an extra line in the schema file, which shouldn't be a problem. Since it's a refactoring project, testing is out of scope here (most of the reviewers asked them for unit tests), but the changes done are not breaking any existing tests. The documentation is well written, with a video demonstration, and a demonstration of manual testing that the team has done. Additionally, they have provided enough comments, and also made the code more readable by structuring it well and by making it more DRY than before. The code is also deployed on VCL, and it works as expected. The only issue the project has is with the brakeman build, which is failing, but I feel it is not an exploitable vulnerability.
Feedback on design doc: The team has tried to cover all the necessary things needed for a reviewer to understand, also provided a manual testing scenario and demonstration video. All of the changes are described in prose.  The descriptions are very readable and informative.  The error codes in submit_file could be more descriptive, e.g., "Authentication error" could be, "You are not authorized to submit to this project.  I would also suggest putting comments directly before code snippets they relate to (notify_reviewers is before the preceding code snippet).  The Issue 7 code snippet is much too long.  A diff view would've been much more readable.  Automated testing is not covered; was any code written?

Feedback on project: The team has done an amazing job in refactoring this controller. The code is very DRY, functions length is limited, and comments were VERY comprehensive. They have also followed ruby style guide is followed. They have also identified various anomalies and added future scope which we can get that working in future projects. Although I was present in the meeting where they demo-ed the working functionality, one of the peer reviews they received mentioned the app crashed while testing.This is something that we can aim to fix in E2228. Definitely mergable.
Feedback on design doc: One concern with many of these wiki pages is that they show code changes with little description of what has been done.  This page describes the changes in detail, but doesn't show any changes.  Arguably, though, the commit links are even better than pasting in code snippets, because they both show before and after views, and are searchable, which they would not be if snippets were pasted into the wiki page.  It would be nice, though, if they opened in a new tab.  One potential improvement would be to make clear why the changes were covered in the order they were covered on the page.

Slated to possibly be merged: Possibly, if the code works well.
Feedback on project: This project makes several advances over previous attempts.  This time, all data is evidently displayed in a single table, and the instructor can toggle on whatever (s)he wants to see.  Comments are pretty good, in contrast to existing code.  And the wiki page contains no screenshot of the output.  So I am not sure if the code works.  OTOH, calibrated assignments are excluded from the summary reports.  This is a heuristic that works for CSC 517 right now, but there should be a more flexible way of deciding which assignments not to include in the summary.  It is not clear to me why teammate reviews and meta-reviews are needed to show an aggregate score column.  I should think that grades for submitted work would also have an aggregate score (score for all the assignments this semester).  If any assignments have topics, evidently, topic columns are generated for all assignments, even those that have no topics. Nit: @ndash; should be used instead of hyphens for scores that have not been assigned.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page shows code changes in Github diff view, which is good, but it is not as readable as it could be because the changes are shown on a dark background and reduced in size to fit into a column, making it necessary to zoom in and scroll to see what was changed.  Another difficulty is that in each section, several code snippets are shown, and then the descriptions are all collected at the end.  It would be better to describe each screenshot by itself with the description preceding the code listing.  In the RSpec section, the changes are described, but no code snippets are shown; the reader would have to search for each code change, using search terms from the Test Plan section.

Slated to possibly be merged: Looks good, but affects so much functionality (reviewing, calibration, cake questions) that much manual testing would be required to confirm that it works.
Feedback on project: The changes from this project substantially improve response_controller.  Some of the ancillary methods have been moved to a new response_helper class.  However, no tests were written for response_helper.  Functionality that belongs in the model has been moved to 3 model classes: assignment_questionnaire.rb, awarded_badge.rb, and cake.rb.  Naming has been made more consistent, and some comments have been improved.  My concern with this project is that it touches many different functionalities, and the team would not have known enough about them to test them thoroughly.  So, a good effort, but testing is required before it is merged.
Feedback on design doc: Changes made are well described (except for G. Code Climate Issues) and are shown with Github diff view, which makes it easy to see how the code was changed.  I prefer the white-background views of changes D and G to the less-readable dark-background views for the other changes.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project: The team did a good job cleaning up messiness in the code, making it better structured and more readable.  Code was moved to the model (scored_question.rb) to avoid checking classes in the controller.  While the new code is much better structured, the build does not pass, and Github reports two serious security vulnerabilities (which, however, would likely have applied to the old code as well).  Had to fix a duplicate method name add_new_questions --> add_new_ScoredQuestion, meaning the team did not test a large part of the refactor and it's not safe to merge.
Feedback on design doc: This page describes 7 changes made during refactoring.  The changes are rather difficult to follow, because it's not clear which lines are changed, removed, or added during the modifications.  Using Github's diff view would have made it much easier to see what had been changed.

Feedback on project: Team has cleaned up the WET nature of input validation used in the create/update methods. However, most of the comments are too low level (just stating what any Rails programmer knows), and some of the code is not clear, and requires comments which were missing. If better comments had been present, it would be easier to understand. They did a migration but it seems to be failing due to existing issues in the existing code.
Feedback on design doc: Comprehensive, but could have mentioned details on how the code was modified along with pasting code snippets. Could have added  multiple instructor creds to manually test the feature changes, and more detail on exactly what to test. And how to reach all the related paths of the code.

Slated to possibly be merged: No, needs changes, but tell next team to keep the comments this team added.
Feedback on project: They divided a big method calculate_score into different methods which is good. I had told the team to figure out a way to move the method calculate_score elsewhere as it makes the controller too fat, which is not a good sign. They moved it to the helper but they should have refactored it such that redirection logic remains in the controller, not in the helper. All other points in the project description are covered
Feedback on design doc: This page contains a comprehensive list of changes that the team has made, and displays the comments that have been added to the code.  It is easily readable, but the reader would need to have another window open on the code, since context is not given on the wiki page.  A better way of showing the changes would have been via the Github diff view.  The team has recorded two videos, but since they contain neither audio nor captions, they are not likely to be useful to anyone, and they are uploaded to the Expertiza server, which doesn't have enough storage to host videos, rather than to a video server

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: The team did a great job identifying multiple places for refactoring. For eg, they created a method for identifying team type and saved it in session. They also created multiple methods to make the code more DRY. They also did changes with view which was corresponding to the controller and made improvements in the view code also which is really great. They also added a lots of test cases. Removed some of unnecessary  if-else which I suggested. Build is failed; they changed gemfile in a way that breaks Rubocop and Travis.
Feedback on design doc: Well organized presentation of the changes made, along with the rationale for making them.  In Refactor inherit and bequeath_all methods, the code segments are too long to be easily comprehensible.  Something like Github's diff view would have been clearer.  However, the comments are helpful.  When you discuss get_parent_from_child, it would have been helpful to know what parent & child are.  Teams? Users?

Feedback on project: [Not chosen]

Slated to possibly be merged: Not until the build passes.  Even then, someone should check that the correct values are being tested.
Feedback on project: This team overcame many obstacles just to get to the point where they could write tests.  They ended up with tests that ostensibly test whether the Hamer algorithm is correctly implemented ... except that there doesn't seem to be anywhere in the code or the wiki page where they actually demonstrate that the values they are testing against are the actual values that should be returned by the Hamer algorithm.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very readable description of what this team did to write tests. It is detailed enough to be a big help to the next team that tries to test the web service, after it is returning accurate results.  I fixed the typos (capitalied Hamer, and fixed another spelling error).

Feedback on project: The team has written good tests for the methods that are present in the files. Dead code was removed from the summary_helper.rb file. Some edge cases like the API throwing an error could have been mocked to test the "error path" of the code, despite the API not working. Have renamed a variable for better clarity in the test file
Feedback on design doc: Wiki thoroughly mentions the scope of the project, and describes the tests written by the team, explaining the functionality to be tested.  This is so much better than most wiki pages on testing projects!  Team has also documented the blockers that were encountered. The wiki page also includes a video of the tests being run.  The only shortcoming is that some lines in the code boxes extend far to the right of the boundary.  Line breaks should have been inserted.

Feedback on project: [Not chosen]

Really excellent work. identified unused code that we asked them to test and removed it. For the code that does get tested, the team does a great job covering edge cases. Removing dependencies will make the application run more smoothly.
Feedback on design doc: It was good that you described what the join_team_requests_helper does, but it would have been better to say what a JoinTeamRequest is.  It would also have been better to describe all tests (though you wouldn't have to have included the code for all) instead of just a sample of tests. However, overall, the prose descriptions were very helpful.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: The team was able to achieve good coverage on the two controllers with this PR. Comments and context strings describe what is happening clearly, and for many successful case tests there is a test for the failing case. All Github checks pass and the PR is available to be merged. As referenced in the wiki, the private method user_params is not tested since it isn’t used in the controller and rails convention is to not test private methods. This method could be removed as part of this PR. Also, a small change was made to submission_records_controller.rb, where action_allowed? now checks for TA and instructor privileges.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page contains information about missing tests and implemented coverage. The team achieved 100% coverage in the submission records controller and 95.83% coverage in the profile controller. The small dip in coverage of the latter is because they have “not implemented test case for the user_params method since it is no longer being used in the controller”.   The wiki page could have been improved in the following ways: It could have described the purpose of submissions_record_controller and profile_controller. It could have described all TESTs (while each test method had a sentence or two about it, sometimes they just described the function, not how the function was being tested).

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
