Feedback on project: The team tested a difficult controller that involves downloading files and performing actions on folders. The wiki notes that they have "27 implemented tests in 9 contexts, and 9 pending tests that could be implemented in the future". Their first PR was merged before they were done working on the project, which is why there is a second. The second has some notable changes (twice as long) so work may need to be done looking at the merge conflicts. The tests that exist are written well, though the file contains some comments from the team to themselves. Because of the size and complexity of this file, submitted_content_controller could use more work in a future project to finish its testing. This was a good foundation and start to its testing.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page is well written and outlines the methods tested in the controller well. It would have been more helpful if it described the different conditions being tested in methods like view and edit, where the tests were > 20 lines long.  It also includes a coverage report (44.32%, 51%) and suggests refactoring in the controller itself. They note that the remove_hyperlink method could be removed, as it does not appear to be in use. The only things missing appear to be descriptions on the methods used to test the file (downloading, folders), and the names of the students working on the project.

Feedback on project: Very well done, definitely merge, looks like very understandable code. Every possible condition is checked and checked very well.
Feedback on design doc: The tests themselves are described with prose, which is helpful.  It would have also been helpful to include a sentence or two on what the users_controller actually does.  And it would have been helpful to have some internal comments in some of the tests describing what they were doing ... tho, since the tests were short, that  is not an absolute necessity.

Feedback on project: More test code. Looks great and exactly like what we want. The code is very understandable. The tests implemented are deep and adequetely cover the code.
Feedback on design doc: The biggest concern with this page is that it just lists the tests for participants_controller, and does not describe them in any way.  This adds no value beyond pointing someone to a code listing.  On versions_controller, two of the methods are described, but the desciption of search does not really help understand it.  The documentation should also have included a sentence or two on what the controllers actually do.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: This project added over 200 lines of testing for these two controllers. The additions to markup_styles_controller_spec are especially notable. Comments have been added to the tests as well. A couple factories have been added to the code, which can help in future additions to these files. Every test case in Github passes. The PR can be immediately merged.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page contains information about what needed to be tested in these files and outlined the additions made in the PR.  It should have included a sentence or two on what the markup_styles_controller and lock_controller actually do.  The code confuses "instructor" with "instructure" (the company that markets the Canvas LMS).  Although the tests are relatively short, it would still help to have some internal comments (or external narration) describing how they test what they test.  Test coverage of 90.91% is stated, and the team admits edge cases were not explored entirely.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project: The team has two pull requests. One has many files changed, but includes additions to eula_controller_spec. The other has only courses_controller_spec changes. The video shows courses_controller_spec passing 8 tests, but this is outdated since their PR has 12-14 tests in it. The eula_controller_spec was shown to pass 9 tests, which is accurate with the code changes. One of the courses_controller_spec tests is commented out, which may need to be removed also. The team was warned about problems with their PR multiple times but did not make any changes after initial commits. Neither of the PRs can be merged in their current state. The code quality of tests is good at first glance however, and their changes can likely be merged eventually after some work.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page is well done and includes details on the missing tests along with their added test framework. It should have included a sentence or two on what the eula_controller and courses_controller actually do.  It is missing the test coverage percentage and concedes that edge cases were not added. Info about the team working on the project is also missing.

Slated to possibly be merged: yes, after changes in names of the test cases
Feedback on project: Overall test coverage was great, lots of test cases were written including edge cases. Multiple test cases in BadgesController have the same uninformative name - “allows <person> to perform certain action”. Certain action does not give any information about which actions is being performed. This was raised during the mentor meeting as well.
Feedback on design doc: Wiki page is well written and all the test cases are explained. Could have added more explanation for test cases instead of single-liners.  Would also have been helpful to describe what badges are, or link to a page that described them.  When you say "allows ... to perform certain action", it would have been very useful to state which actions this applies to.  E.g., which actions should an instructor be able to perform?  It would be helpful to have comments inside the tests indicating why they were performing the actions they do perform.

Feedback on project: Test code looks comprehensive and bugs were addressed. Build is failing due to Gem issue
Feedback on design doc: The page includes helpful prose descriptions of the purpose of each test.  Not clear why the code for  'when questionnaires related to an assignment are deleted' is commented out.  It would be helpful to have comments inside the tests indicating why they were performing the actions they do perform.  The conclusion paragraph is too long and ponderous; it should be broken up into steps or perhaps a bulleted list.

Feedback on project: They added better and more suggestive variable names for the methods, code is slightly more DRY,  functions length is limited, comments are present, ruby style guide is followed. They also identified bugs in the advice_controller and fixed them. Their test plan looks comprehensive and I believe it tests all the necessary methods. They also worked on adding tests for participants_helper, which is an added bonus.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page gave an incorrect description of what advice is.  It is not comments given by a user, but rather guidance given by the instructor (or, by the rubric creator) about what characteristics of the submitted work merit each score level.  I have corrected the description.  I do not understand why the number of "advices" should depend on score.  And I don't understand how an instance of advice could "equal" a score.  When the test "allows certain action" or "refuses certain action", you should state what that action is.  It would be much clearer if the tests described what their purpose was, rather than just describing the low-level steps they took.  The description of partcipants_helper tests is somewhat better, but still describes the tests at a low level that would not help a reader understand what the controller is actually doing.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, it is a high-coverage testing project that has been done well. There are many cases in each of the spec files, and the team even added some factories for other teams to use in the future.
Feedback on project: In addition to the tests, a few lines here and there were changed in the app, and there is no explanation as to why, or any indication whether they may have been caused by another concurrent project. The tests appear to be extensive, but they are quite difficult to understand. Without any comments or description on the wiki page, someone would have to read the code and try to figure out why it tested what it did.
Feedback on design doc: The description of tests does a good job of explaining wht the methods do that are being tested. It would be good if it also explained what the tests tested and how they worked. "Currently the implementation of this [questionnaire] method makes it impossible to test, so no test has been written." This surprises me; I don't know why it would not be testable.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes.
Feedback on project: This testing project was able to accomplish complete coverage on their two test files. In addition, a couple bugs were found and fixed in model files. Unfortunately, this project also did not have enough comments to explain the tests. Factories are missing comments as well. Specifically, the 18 lines at the beginning of tag_prompt_deployment_spec.rb should have comments describing what is happening, along with the rest of the file.
Feedback on design doc: The design doc has a detailed project design and test plan. To some extent, it helps explain the lack of comments in the test cases. The descriptions of the use cases and edge cases in particular are a very good addition to this wiki page. There are some formatting inconsistencies however, and including actual code snippets would have been a welcome addition.

Slated to possibly be merged: This project is not ready for merging yet. Code need more comments to make it clear, discribe what the code exactly testing, even though the code looks well writen and readable.
Feedback on project:
This testing seems pretty useful, as far as it goes. More comments on the tests would have been useful. Without the web service running, it was impossible to check that the correct reputation values were being calculated.
The Hamer algorithm is referred to as "hammer". I suppose it is just a matter of correcting the parameter to "hamer". The send of this command is commented out (because it can't be sent to the web service). Because of this, it's not clear if the rest of the call is set up correctly. So these tests are a good beginning, but need to be enhanced to something that is truly useful.
Feedback on design doc: The document describes the two reputation algorithms that have been implemented in Expertiza, and it shows what objects have been created to test with. It would have been very beneficial to have an explanation of why the objects are set up the way they are. However, most of the test descriptions do tell what the tests are testing.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, it is a purely testing project and adds good coverage to response files.
Feedback on project: This team did a really decent job on this project, it is a relatively difficult topic comparing to other teams' topic. The demo video is bit confusing, after the teaching stuffs re-investigate the codes, we think this project does a good job. The video can try to explain the code and what they are testing instead of discussion large amount of the result.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very clear description of the dozens of tests that have been written. The only suggestion I would have is to explain how the conditions tested (via expect) in the tests relate to what the test is testing. For example, the document should explain what "expect(result.status).to eq(302)" means instead of leaving it to the reviewer to figure out.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, as the functionality seems to be working and enough tests available for the code.
Feedback on project: High coverage to multiple test files added was the focus of this project, and the team was able to deliver. It was not a perfect project, as the demo was sometimes hard to follow, some tests are not documented well, and the wiki page highlighted this. After the demo, it appears a couple commits were added which include more comments on test cases. After these commits, the project was merged into beta.
Feedback on design doc: In the list of relevant methods, it would have been good to include a one-line description of what the methods do. This information is provided below, but there would still be an advantage in a summary. It would also be very helpful to describe what the tests are testing, so that the reader didn't have to study the code. That is provided for some functions, but not the ones at the beginning of the wiki page. Despite these glitches, this is still a very comprehensive documentation of the tests written by this project.

Slated to possibly be merged: No way. They create only one new metric, which makes no sense, and the only way to create additional metrics is to modify large classes (like assignment.rb).
Feedback on project: The teammate review heatgrid has been improved which serves the intended functionality completely. Also tests are there to verify the working of the function.
Feedback on design doc: The design document clearly shows the updates made into UI with screenshots and provides almost all required informaton to understand the project. There are a couple of ways it could be improved. First, it could use mediawiki markup to make separate issues into separate sections in the ToC. For example, "F.6 Removed the following code as it corresponds to the deleted column" is just ordinary text, so it does not appear in the ToC. Second, screenshots of Github diff views would have been easier to read than the code in boxes, since some lines are much longer and require scrolling far to the right to read them.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, as the functionality is working fine as well as tests. Also, since this is just refactor project, we can merge the code.
Feedback on project:
The demo video showed the substitution of the metric "Verbose Comment Count" for metric-1. They also added a toggle for the column in the heatgrid in case it does not need to be viewed. The example they picked for a metric was a count of how many review responses for a particular rubric item contained more than 10 words in the comment. This metric would not be of much interest to most users. However, a bigger issue is the fact that each time a new metric is added, two view files would need to be edited: assignments/edit/_general.html.erb and grades/view_team.html.erb, the latter in two places. These files have little to do with metrics, so requiring them to change introduces higher coupling than desirable. Most of the tests are also closely tied to this metric, which suggests that if new metrics are added, new tests would also have to be written. A further issue is that the new code contains no comments.

The actual purpose of this project was to write tests for students being able to review their own team, and to rename the metric-1 column with a toggle. It doesn't appear this first issue was addressed, although there are some tests for the new Verbose Comment Count metric. Despite their work on the metric problem, there is a bug with the round review display. To get reviews from multiple rounds to show up in the heatgrid, it is necessary to check the box, "Rubric varies by round." This means that first-round reviews cannot be shown if the rubric is the same in Round 1 and Round 2. And if the checkbox is checked, then Round 2 reviews are shown twice. The team noted that they could not fix Issue #2109 because a new anonymized db was not provided until after the due date for the project. This is true, but they could still have fixed the other bug.
Feedback on design doc: The document does a good job of describing all of the functionality of this project, except for the tests, where only a one-line sentence is provided to describe all of the tests in each of the files. The document explains exactly how to add new metrics, and provides numerous screenshots to show how the new functionality works.

Slated to possibly be merged: No. Code changes have not been tested.
Feedback on project:
The waitlisting functionality is working fine now. The code has been combined in Waitlist.rb file. The purpose of problem statement is served. 

However, the waitlist class has no instance methods. It is not written in an o-o way. Something outside of the waitlist class actually creates the waitlists. And more tests should be written.
Feedback on design doc: The descriptions in the document are clear. The refactoring could have been explained in more detail. Aside from the control-flow diagram, few details are given. Manual testing is described with many screenshots, but automated testing is not addressed.

Project name: Further refactoring and improvement of review_mapping_helper
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes! Assuming that it works as well as it looks like it does. There are some messages that need to be changed, but the functionality is fine.
Feedback on project:
The team showed a report view that appears to be working, along with a review of a team's work that also appeared without error. They come close to matching, but their report shows that ALL teams with completed assgts. have given permission for their submission to be shared.

Nothing during the demo touched the code in ReviewChartHelper, which was one of the largest items they refactored. It seems like they changed how links work in review_mapping_helper in a confusing way that may not work. The other changes seem simple and are mostly method renames. The only edits to spec files were to rename a few variables.

In summary, most of the changes were name changes with a text editor, and much of the code was not tested.
Feedback on design doc: The document clearly explains the changes made during the project. The flowchart is a bit unusual, as it shows steps that the team took while working on the project, not the flow of information in application. The document is very readable.

Project name: Merge code for role-based reviewing with code for topic-specific rubrics
Slated to possibly be merged: The functionality looks fine. A bit worry about how extensive this framework is for the future work. Might be able to merge if the code is adjusted in a more managed way.
Feedback on project:
This project merged two previous projects, and did so in an elegant way. The code appears to be very well written.

There were some rough edges: "Is role-based reviewing" is awkward; reword. Other items on the page need to be similarly reworded. The message displayed for role-based reviewing says "Duty-..."; that needs to be fixed.

There were not enough comments in the tests, but they were in the design doc, so that's not a big issue.
In the demo, we couldn't see the dropdowns except for the choices made. So it's not clear that the user's choices are constrained like they should be.
Feedback on design doc: Because the projects that were merged are described on their own wiki pages, this document is almost entirely focused on testing. Overall, it does a great job of describing the tests that were implemented. The sections relating to the 5 spec files should have been subsections of a New Test FIles section. In general, the tests are described well, but I would have liked to see some discussion of what the expect statements are checking for.

Project name: Implementing and testing import & export controllers
Slated to possibly be merged: I think it can be merged if no conflicts is there, the feature is good and tests are good.
Feedback on project: This team did a great job on the given task, the functions are fully implemented. Even though not all old code has been migrated, the existing migrations show that the import feature is working as expect. The commented code and missing comments are added to the code are added after noticing. Most code are fine, there are few inconsistency in the code might be caused by integrating code between different team members. Overall, this team provides a high quality work.
Feedback on design doc: Code changes are shown in great detail, but there is not much prose description of what has been changed. Typically there is one line of explanation above a textbox containing dozens of lines of text. For example, when you say, "Course_team is is also changed to use the newly implemented #import functionality," you could describe how it is changed (what lines of code are moved or replaced). In the test plan, it is not clear how the 6 scenarios relate to the blocks of code shown below.

Slated to possibly be merged: Not so sure, beta is not working so they made the changes on master, if we are to merge then merge it to master branch
Feedback on project: implemented language translation of Expertiza into Hindi. If student do not have a preference, course default setting is displayed. If student have a preference, then pages are displayed in user's preference. The goal of the project is well accomplished. Tests are solid as well. At leas this is the best project I have seen this semester.
Feedback on design doc: The visuals illustrate the problem well. However, I think it would be better to explain language selection earlier in the document. Also, the whole scheme should be described in the same place. There shouldn't be a page of code before we are told what happens if a student hasn't set a language preference and is on a page not belonging to a course with a lang. preference. The code should be described in more detail, e.g., what does "I18n" mean? (Actually, it does say this, but only later on the page.) The discussion of alternate approaches is very useful. The discussion of design patterns and principles is also good. In summary, I would say that there are many very good elements on this page, but it would be more readable if reorganized so that definitions occurred the first time that concepts were referred to.

Slated to possibly be merged: I think so. Doubtful about the failing build.
Feedback on project: Features are done well and UI looks intuitive, it's not the team's problem or a design problem, and they are not to be punished for thing that they cannot control. The code structure is good. Parts that cannot be verified are either due to things that are broken in beta branch. This could actually be merged into Master branch without a second thought. But we would need someone to create a pull request to master, and in the 6 days since the demo, no one has. Without that, we can't really even check the code.
Feedback on design doc: The changes made are clearly described, except that the document promises a description of the code and the automated tests, but these are not included. Good visuals are included. (I do think grading_history should be called "grade_record", since when you assign a grade, you create a record of that grade and not a whole grading history.)

Slated to possibly be merged: No, although functionality is good, there should be better identifier naming, more comments, and automated tests
Feedback on project: The team did a good job in this final project. The issues with the back button redirecting to a random page was corrected. New comments were added to the code which is welcomed. The team added 16 new test cases (there were no test cases when the test started to work on the project). All tests passed for model and controller. The team faced the same issues as other teams where the build was failing. The code coverage increased. Overall, happy with the work the team did.
Feedback on design doc: This design documents describes the bug fixes and tests in considerable detail. Screenshots describe the changes in detail.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, but I am concerned that this will cause trouble for team-based reviewing (E1973).
Feedback on project:
This project fixes the extant bugs, but I have some questions about the style:
"Failed to save" should flash an error, not a note.
@metareview_true is not a good name; @metareviews_in_use would be better.
In _review_strategy.html.erb, num_metareviews_allowed has been changed to num_metarviews_required. This must be wrong ... both variables should play a role.
Similarly, changing @num_metareviews_completed to @num_metarviews_total makes the code harder to understand.
Also, no automated tests were written.
Feedback on design doc: The team does a very good job of describing a problem and then showing how it was solved. They also have a good description of manual testing for each issue. However, the automated tests are not described (they just say they are borrowing testing code from another project, but not how they are using it).

Project name: Calibration submissions should be copied along with calibration assignments
Slated to possibly be merged: It has good functionality, but we need to decide whether to merge this + their first OSS project, as they are in the same repo. Problems with this project include duplication of code for searching, and shallow tests (only test the page elements).
Feedback on project: This project implements the functionality very well, yet there are aspects of the code that are difficult to understand. The main concern is that it removes a lot of code from Project E1973, Team-Based Reviewing. That project would have to be re-merged, and since the person doing it would not have written either that project or E2155, that could be very difficult. Beyond that, there do not seem to be enough comments in the code they have written. Methods with confusing names (e.g., newreviewresp) have no method comments. Class method "createnewteam" has a name that does not follow convention, and since it is "with respect to the old team", why isn't it an instance method with that team as receiver? Long sequences of code have no comments to indicate what they are doing, e.g., dict1 = Hash[oldreviewrespids.zip newreviewrespids] (why is a dictionary used here?).
Feedback on design doc: The document describes the changes to be made, and then shows screenshots of the old version of the system. This is followed by a list of files modified and screenshots of the changes to the code. What would have made it more useful is if there was a prose description of how each of the files were changed.

Slated to possibly be merged:
Not as it is now. They have a lot of code artifacts from a previous team that they merged into beta that should be removed. They have changed too many files that are unrelated to their project. If these issues could be cleaned up, either by this team or a future one, this would be a very useful project to merge. More comments could be made in their rspec tests. The team does not know coverage of individual files, and they looked a bit sparse at first glance, considering how many methods this project added. 

I walked through the changed files and made all these comments to the team in our final meeting, but they have not fixed them before the demo.
Feedback on project:
The functionality of this project is quite good, better than any previous attempt. We have some questions about whether the code is as readable as it should be.
The appearance of the search pages is now uniform, fixing a problem from the previous project attempt. However, code is still duplicated, and should be DRYed out.
Tests "are just testing the keyword." ??
In the tests, the it clauses say, "allows certain action" or "refuses certain action". They should be more specific!
Re. the code, there are a lot of changes to big .jsx files that may prove confusing to refactor. In tree_display.jsx, the _this variable is removed; this seems to be an overlapping edit that will have to be resolved.
It's in the same repo with their 1st OSS project, which could be a problem. However, that project was highly rated and should probably be merged too.
Feedback on design doc: The page describes all of the search functionality that has been implemented. It would help readability a lot if the description of how to specify a search was directly before the relevant screenshots. As it is now, the reader needs to scroll way down to see what the search forms look like. I would also suggest increasing the size so that the search options can be more clearly seen. It would be fine to crop the screenshot to allow this. There is a long code snippet that is pasted in with no real explanation. It would be better to just use a link to the repository. But actually, it would have been even better to describe in prose what the tests are testing.

Slated to possibly be merged: Probably, though I'm a little hesitant to merge something that still has bad code from a previous project, like all the class methods.
Feedback on project:
There are actually two E2152 pull requests in Expertiza right now - the PR we saw in the demo has less recent commits than the other. And the PR we did not see has less files changed as well. They started with last year's project, so the beta they started with was the beta from last year. The changes since then will show up as merge conflicts if this project is merged.

The functionality of this project seems to work well and would be a valuable addition to Expertiza, but it cannot be merged in its current state. There are many artifacts in their PR from an old version of beta. This is because the team merged the previous teams' code into current beta, but did not remove the differences unrelated to their project. The team knew of these problems before the demo, but did not fix them.

More comments can be made in rspec tests as well. It is unclear what the coverage is of the individual tests. The file revision_plan_team_map_test.rb has nothing substantial in it.
Feedback on design doc: The design document does a great job of explaining the functionality of this project. There are flow charts and screenshots of how it functions, and walks through each of the steps in creating a revision plan. There were some code snippets showing important changes. However, the test plan is lacking, and only has a list of files changed in the project. It is not clear why a list of files modified was provided, since it is just a list, and does not figure in any explanation. Some sentences in the doc are hard to understand.

Project name: Allow reviewers to bid on what to review
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, the code was written with proper documentation and all the functionality works properly except the scrambled order of comments Q and A in the review metric feedback table.
Feedback on project:
This was a difficult project, but the team was able to get the functionality working at an impressive level. The code and testing overall was of high quality as well.

There were a number of small problems and questions with the project that will likely be worked on by a future team. These include the possibility of adding flags to say how many students have submitted their bids, or when students should submit bids by. What happens to students who did not submit a bid by the time the algorithm is run? Once the alg is run, maybe it should be able to be ran again? Could get_topic_bg_color_review_bids be shared with topic bidding? Why are methods in review_bid.rb class methods? Why is code for showing # of required reviews duplicated? Review_bids_other_work has a DRY violation. In the wiki, there are edge cases that have not been exhaustively tested.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very well organized and readable document. It explains the changes made in enough detail to allow the reader to understand them without poring through the code. Some discussion of manual testing, as illustrated in the video, would have been helpful. The one shortcoming I can see is that several lists have a dozen or more items. This is likely to bewilder the reader. Better to group the items into categories; the categories would be more likely to be remembered, and the reader could see that each item belongs in the category to which it was assigned.

Slated to possibly be merged: Not this time, need to be heavy refactored.
Feedback on project: The work done by the team in terms of functionality seems to be pretty good. Hard coded tooltip text and API call url were moved to config file. Refactoring of API call methods was done to remove code duplication. Added tooltip (Q and A) beside the comment number in review feedback table that shows the comment text and question. The functionality seems to be implemented well except the comments in review feedback table seem to be scrambled due to which this project cannot be merged. Also faces the failing build issue.
Feedback on design doc: This document describes the code changes well. I think the proposed solution could be better described. There are issues in three separate numbered lists, and it's not clear how the first one (numbered criteria) is addressed. I thought that testing should have been described in more detail: what would you have liked to have tested if the web services were readily accessible?

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes! All features are implemented very well and easy to navigate
Feedback on project: 44 files changed, because this includes all of Github metrics in Expertiza (including previous Github metrics projects). Unfortunately, all parsing is done in the controller, which leads to 350 lines in the controller. Add the functionality to turn on and turn off the GitHub usage function. Really need more test cases and a heavy refactor to reach the standard to be merged. The test is too shallow and simple.
Feedback on design doc: I question whether a new table should be added only to record whether a particular metric is used in an assignment. It might be good to have a table to record WHICH metrics are used in which assignments. Each method is described in prose before the code is shown, which is good. Screenshots are helpful, excpt that "use github metric" [sic] seems to have been pasted into the screenshot. Good description of OAuth interface.

Feedback on project: There needs to be some explanation regarding whether the calculate average functionality is actally required. If there are existing functions, why not using it. Somehow based on my recollection there are some significant difference between what's there to calculate the average and what's implemented. The documentations are done well. Unfortuantely, the code for calculating author-feedback averages is the same as the code needed for other kinds of rubrics, so it should not be rewritten. It is not clear what the method self.prepare_final_feedback_versions is doing.
Feedback on design doc: This document does a good job of describing the changes made to allow author feedback to be viewed. (I'm not sure how it's a 'Completion/Progress" view, but that's a problem with the project description, not the implementation.) It would have been useful to describe the code changes you made, and also to use the wiki markup language to implement itemized lists, instead of hardcoding "1.", "2.", etc. Other than that, it is a commendable effort.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, the test are testing what was asked in the question
Feedback on project: The new version seems much better than the old.  For the most part, changes are limited to the files that need to be changed.  Functionality seems to work.  I do think that adding 107 lines to _rubrics.html.erb is too much, and that a better design would have been to split this partial into multple partials.  Also, I am concerned about the number of lines modified that don't have anything directly to do with duties.  Three checks for is_duty_based_assignement in student_teams/view.html.erb is a bit concerning, though I don't see a straightforward way to avoid it.  Tests could be more extensive (e.g., do the limits on how many team members can choose a duty work, does a student get the rubric for the correct duty when reviewing a team member?).  Nonetheless, this appears to be a valuable contribution.
Feedback on design doc: Overall, a good description of what was done.  I think you should have covered the distinction between "role" as used in the code (type of user) and "role" as used in the UI ("duty").  The screenshots effectively illustrate the changes.  The role table seems too wide.  Also, a better heading would be, "Use role-based reviewing?"  Ditto for "Maximum member limit" --> "Max number in this role".  The tests in the spec file should have been described here.

Project name: Introduce a Student View for instructors
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project:
This is a UI related project. This group did a really good job on implementing the feature. Their implementation seems able to avoid many edge case error.
This implementation is based on modifying some yml configuration file, however, these changes seem necessary. The code is easy to understand, lot of descriptive comments are added.
They also designed many test cases to cover the changes they've made.
Feedback on design doc:
This is one of the best wiki pages I've seen.  In addition to the requirements for the wiki page, they also added a video record to demostrate their work. They also discuss how this project can be further improved.  Code changes are clearly described, as well as the reason these changes were made.

It would have improved readability if the steps in the Implementation section had been shown as an enumerated or bulleted list. It would also have been good to put code in another font, such as <tt>.

Project name: OSS Project Beige: UI features related to revision time
Slated to possibly be merged: No.  This project creates a new review_status table, which is completely superfluous, since one can determine whether reviews have been started or completed by (a) the existence of the Response object and (b) the Submitted flag.
Feedback on project:
This project is UI related. This project add a new feature of the review status. This team implemented this feature in a simple way, they create a new object class to store the review status.
Their implementation result in PR showing that many files are changed, many of these files are migration file and schema file. Some rb file is also changed, but that is a single line modification which allows the new feature to be added.
Feedback on design doc:
The wiki page is well design, it is clear and informative. The problem statement and the suggest solution is given.
A diagram is attached to explain the action flows of this newly added feature. They showed the changes they've made for this project, with description step by step. Both Rspec test and Capybara test are added. And there is also a manual testing introduction for this project.

The title of the page should have included "UI Features Related to Revision Time", since "Beige" is not very descriptive of what was done.

The code sequences for "ready', "started", and "completed" are pretty long.  More complete prose descriptions of what they are doing would have been helpful.

Slated to possibly be merged: If the single build error can be fixed, and perhaps more comments added to methods where they are lacking, it is a good merge candidate.
Feedback on project: This project used the Sidekiq gem to asynchronously handle email tasks, which is sort of similar to E2135. Sidekiq was partially merged before, but this project changes the queue setup slightly. The refactor of methods in assignment_form.rb is significant, and several methods were moved to due_date.rb. It also adds reminder functionality to mail_worker, which also conflicts with E2135. Significant spec additions have been made from what exists in beta. Overall, code looks appropriate and well-written. Sidekiq needs to be started in the background while Expertiza is running, but since Sidekiq was already partially merged, I think this should be expected. After viewing the peer reviews and newest Travis run, this appears almost ready to merge. Peer reviewers believe it is a quality project, but note that several methods lack method comments. The travis build has a single small error in models (assignment_form_spec.rb).
Feedback on design doc:
The page has everything required, including a project background, issues, test plan, and implementation. Screenshots are included of Sidekiq working, and scheduled jobs appearing as expected. I wish a reminder email screenshot had been included, since that functionality is key.

Long quotes, such as in the Problem Statement, should be set off in some way, e.g., by indenting or italicization.  When a quote spans multiple paragraphs, it is hard to see where it ends.

In the ""Implementing Test Plan"" section, it would have been good to add a prose description of what each test did, rather than expecting the reader to figure it out from the code.  The manual testing description assumes that the user is using a de-identified version of the production db; it would be better if it did not refer to specific student IDs, which might not exist if the tester uses a different db.

But overall, this is a very clear and professional description, among the best I have seen.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, but after E2144 is merged; this will require some refactoring of E2142.
Feedback on design doc:
"Issue1" should be spelled "Issue 1", etc.  These are not identifiers.  The issue of sending emails after the review deadline DOES exist.  For example, in the Final Project (and Design Doc) assignment, after the review period is over, I typically re-enable submission to allow students to submit their code, video, and final design doc.  In this situation, when students upload their final project, all reviewers will be emailed about it, even though they cannot review it again.  This would arise for any assignment where students are allowed to submit final versions after peer review (especially common when instructors use only one round of review).

The description of this issue is followed by excerpts from two files, assignment.rb and due_date.rb.  I'm not sure why these excerpts are included; there is no explanation of why.

In the description of the third issue, the link provided to the mail recipient is specified as follows: "The ID of this object is the query parameter located at the end of the relevant link."  Where/what is the relevant link?  You might be able to figure this out from studying the code, but it is not obvious.

The test plan lists various steps, but screenshots of at least some of the steps would be helpful.

Slated to possibly be merged: borderline - tend to merge; mailer function cannot be tested, so they commented it out in their code
Feedback on project: There are 3 different tasks mentioned in this project, 1 universities should be ordered alphabeatically when creatinga a course, that's been done; 2, System prompts a error when creating an instructor and an institution at the same time, this one is a little questionable, 3. when managing instuctor users, we need to show institutions associated with that instructor, that is done. Regarding problem 2, they did not have a mail server so they couldn't verify if an email could trully be sent. Tests are sufficient for this task
Feedback on design doc: Overall, the page does give a good idea of what changes have been made.  But, headers like "Task1" are not helpful.  They should state what the task is, e.g., "Sort issue list alphabetically."  Also, there should be a space between "Task" and "1", since "Task1" is not an identifier.  It sounds like you said that Task 2 was resolved by commenting out needed functionality.  Shouldn't the bug have been fixed instead?  Oh, I see that later you said you reverted that.  But still the bug has not been fixed.  The test for whether the institution column was in use should have checked that there was a value in it, not just that the header was printed.

Project name: Create new late policy successfully and fixing Back link ""
Feedback on project: Fixed three bugs first then add plenty of test cases. The team achieved what is required to be done for this project. Video is provided to help better understadning the test process. Have plenty of commits and contributions. The test coveage increased by 0.5%
Feedback on design doc:
The page is misnamed ("Bank link" instead of "back link"), which might cause someone to have trouble finding it. (It's not possible to edit the title without copying the page and obscuring the edit history.) For Problem 2, the solution was to insert this code: flash[:error] = exception.record.errors.full_messages.join("
").html_safe. But what is actually shown on the screen when the error occurs? The documentation should say, but does not. For Problem 3, the solution was to "improve" the code, but the documentation needs to describe how this was done. Code improvements are not described at all; instead, un-annotated code is just copied into the wiki page. The testing code should surely have been shown in more detail. Instead of showing or describing any of the testing code, the page just tells how to run the tests.

Project name: Remove multiple topics at a time (Issue #1409)
Feedback on project: This project is regarding testing the functionality of deleting multiple project topics while creating the assignment. The team has added upto 18 new test cases to automatically test the functionality and provided a video explaining that the functionality is now working in various test scenarios.
Feedback on design doc: The tests are divided into six cases, based on the attributes of Private, Staggered, and Microtask assignments, each of which may be true or false.  All combinations of these attributes are tested, EXCEPT {false, false, false} and {true, true, true}.  It is not clear why these two combinations are omitted.  Looking at the functionality, it certainly makes sense to test different values of Staggered and Microtask flags.  But whether or not the assignment is private would seem to be irrelevant to deleting multiple topics.  IFF the assignment is private, other instructors cannot see it.  This doesn't really have anything to do with deleting topics, so eliminating the Private variable would reduce 6 test cases to 4, simplifying the logic.  Other than that, the code seems fairly clear.  I would suggest adding comments before each block of statements (after each blank line) to indicate what the next group is doing.  As far as the writeup is concerned, it is fairly clear, but I and to copy all of the 6 cases over to another page before I could get an overall view of what is being tested.  The explanation could be simplified to avoid repeating the same verbiage at the beginning of all 6 (or 4) cases.  It is good that a video has been created.

Project name: Auto-generate submission directory names based on assignment names
Slated to possibly be merged: It is worth testing the build to see if it can be made to work; if so, code is clean so project can be merged.
Feedback on project: This project creates unique submission directories automatically based on the assignment name. Code is solid, and testing is in-depth and well done. The previous time this project was worked on, it was mentioned that they had worked on unrelated tests and code - this team does not appear to have had this issue. It is contained to the project and doesn't add anything unneccessary. The assignments_controller was fleshed out and contains better variable names and fleshed out error handling. There is a useless comment on line 29 of assignments_controller.rb, and a duplicate line (138) in assignments_controller_spec.rb however. After viewing the peer reviews and newest Travis run, it appears their testing does not work. All four Travis builds fail, and they have problems in multiple spec files. However, I think this is the only problem remaining with this project - it appears the actual functionality does work as intended according to peer reviews.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki is well done and includes every necessary component to understand the project. The assignments_controller.rb changes would have been clearer if shown in a Github diff view instead of lineare code.  Since the changes were not described in prose, the reader would have to go through the code line by line to see the changes.  The same issue arises when showing the RSpec tests.  Screenshots are included to show the project working, and even includes screenshots of the error handling in the case an assignment is tried to be saved when the name exists already. I think the rspec changes could have been explained, instead of just including the code changes. The issues solved that were key to the project are detailed in the wiki as well.

Slated to possibly be merged: Borderline no, unless the review grades column could be automatically hiddent when there are no values there; (double check if badges are done in the same way)
Feedback on project: This project wanted students to: 1. move the task box to the left instead of above the list of homework, which is done; and 2, remove the badge column and hide columns that are not empty. The pull request is based on a old one which makes reviewing what has been changed somewhat difficult; While I did figure it out with the commit IDs; the issue is that review grades and submission grades are, yes techinically not empty anymore, but filled with N/A. Yes that way you don't have to hide it but I'm not sure whether this is what the project is asking for. They did test key features required by this fix
Feedback on design doc: The table of contents has major sections only.  It would have been helpful to have subsections, as most other wiki pages do.  The page starts with a problem statement, omitting irrelevant preliminaries such as what Expertiza is about.  This is refreshing after reading so much redundant content on other pages.  Description of changes is good, though could be better formatted using section headers.  Columns are shown for submission and review grades, but all grades are "N/A", which doesn't give me confidence that the functionality works.  In the one test, it is not clear why the submission grade should be 98.4.  There is certainly more that can be tested about these changes.

Project name: Track the time students look at other submissions
Email notification to reviewers and instructors
Slated to possibly be merged: No.  After viewing the peer reviews, there are apparently more problems. Multiple students reported that they are not actually getting reminder emails. Some reviewers believe test cases are not done well and don't cover edge cases. One reviewer noted that there were three failures for undefined methods. They did not run Travis after the class was asked to on the latest commits.  However, a team member asserts that the mailer does work correctly.  We do not know what to make of this.  Could merit more checking.
Feedback on project: Their project was to create an asynchronous deadline system for reminder emails. The code for it seems well-written with descriptive comments that help explain what is happening. They have added a couple new tests to due_date_spec which cover 2 of the 7? new methods they added to due_date.rb. There are two instances of blocks of useless comments, including changes to seeds.rb which should not have been included. A line was also added to the README, which also seem unneccessary. They made two changes to migrate files, with the reasoning that DelayedJobs needed an extra parameter to get the code working. An existing migrate file was changed to include a :queue string, but the format of all other lines was updated as well (not sure what to make of this change). A backend server is also needed to get this asynchronous code working - I am not sure if this is the right approach, but it would add more steps into the Expertiza setup (details can be seen in their wiki).  Also, a migration file is edited.  That's not right; the change needs to be made by creating a new migration file.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page is descriptive in most parts, especially in the implementation approach. The screenshots of the reminder selection working are helpful, but they did not actually include any screenshots of them receiving a reminder email, so I can't be sure it actually works. (Actually, that would have required installing a mailer on the testing platform, so this is understandable.) The modified files section is not accurate. The problem statement is concise, but specific kinds of tests issues that were needed should have been mentioned.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: The team did what was asked for them in the project problem statement. They made the unit tests for the admin_controller.rb. They tested 7 methods and had cases for each. They added a foreign key assingment in the institution model to better test the institution controller. There were failures in the Travis CI build but according to other devs, this was known issue they had no control over.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page was well documented. The team listed certain functions that were tested, but they did not give a comprehensive list, or describe HOW those functions were tested.  Rather, they just displayed hundreds of lines of code in monochrome.  A link to the Github view would be more helpful, and also a prose description of the various steps in the tests.  They provided videos of running the tests.

Feedback on project:
It is a test-related topic. This team added many new testcase to the existing rspec file. This testcase are easy to read, and they also increase the total test coverage.
The Travis Cl is not fully passed, but it is due to some existing issue of the expertiza, there are more than one groups raised this issue. One error is that the self_review_popup test assumes that the maximum item score is 5.  In fact, the maximum score is whatever max_question_score is set to in the rubric (ReviewQuestionnaire). Comments are missing for the code in the rspec file, but code is explained in the documentation
Feedback on design doc:
The wiki page is well documented; they mentioned the files they were working with. They also discussed what methods in the controller need to be tested.
The code of the testcase they created is attached in the wiki page. The descriptions of test cases, though, do not clearly describe what is being tested.  For example, saying something is "fetched" does not describe how it needs to be returned, or why these items are fetched together. They report the test coverage after installing the new tests.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes, after we figure out whether the sole line changed in the helper file is correct.
Feedback on project: This team did what was required to fullfil this problem. They added test cases to eight of the methods in the review mapping helper.rb. And were able to increase the coverage by over 0.4%! They were able to have all of their test pass the Travis CI build however, there were known failures prior to their work and that is why their branch is "technically" failing. They were very consistent with their variable name choices in their unit test that leads to easy reading and following.  The sole change to the app is in review_mapping_helper.rb, where an if condition has been commented out, without any explanation as to why.  It looks like some of the test code is duplicated, wheras it might've been able to call it multiple times instead.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page contained good prose descriptions of each of the methods tested. The team provided details on the background of the problem. It seems that they added new tests, instead of augmenting existing tests, but this was not stated. The code was displayed in detail, but (i) it would have been more readable in Github diff view than in monochrome, and (ii) it would have benefited from more embedded comments.  E.g., when a series of objects are created, what purpose are they created for?  To submit an assignment?  They also provided details on how to run the specific tests locally, without having to wait for the Travis build. This team did an excellent job describing their test plan on how they were going to handle the problem and went into details on why they choose those solutions. Also, the team showed the coverage change in a screenshot to visualize their effort on the code base. Lastly, the team provided a video of the the test running.

Feedback on project: The functionality does seem to work -- except that Peer Score does not seem to show up for most assignments.  This may be a score-calculation issue, which is not the fault of this project.  all_students_all_reviews is an 85-line method, and should certainly have been broken down into smaller units.  It's not clear why it needs to use instance variables; temporary variables should suffice.  If there are no topics in an assignment, the topic column is still displayed, but with all dashes in it.  It would have been better to suppress the column entirely.  Ditto for Teammate Count; there should be a checkbox controlling whether this column is displayed (and it should be suppressed if there are no team assignments ... but that's extra functionality for a later day).  Columns can be sorted, but the arrows that sort them don't show up in the initial view; you have to click on one arrow before the arrows for other columns are seen. That said, it is good to have this project finally done correctly.
Feedback on design doc: The changes are motivated and described with adequate detail.  Long code sequences are pasted into the page with no annotation; it would be better to view a Github diff.  Automated test cases are not described; it wold be very useful to be able to see without reading the code exactly which tests have been created.

Slated to possibly be merged: Some of the changes seem to improve the style, but a similar number make it worse.  There is no advantage in merging this code, so we should not.
Feedback on project: The team worked on submitted_content_controller were they had to resolve issues like some methods being too long which needed to be broken down, a few methods needed better naming and a few that were no longer needed. The team was able to cover the requirements. Longer methods were shortened. However, they changed the action_allowed method to remove the call to authorization utility current_user_has_student_privileges, and substitute lower-level code that is not clear. The Travis CI build gave an error. The team reported that the test file is missing. Overall the team did a good work in this project.
Feedback on design doc: It would be good to use section headers for the various issues, and the name of the issue should be included in the header, not just "Problem k".  It seems that the action_allowed method was changed to require different privileges for different operations; this should be described.  Code snippets should be shown where changes have been made, e.g., "Comment on line #19 removed."  For the log_info method, it is not clear what the advantage is.  It just replaces a one-line call to the ExpertizaLogger with a one-line call to log_info that is almost as long.  For Problem 5, I do not understand "# Note: This is not used yet in the view until we all decide to do so”  Where functions have been moved, e.g., Problem 7, we need to see "before" and "after" views to see the changes made.  Indeed, it would be helpful to have a Github diff view for all changes.  Testing should be described better: what is tested by the automated tests?

Slated to possibly be merged: I would suggest not to merge the project directly without detailed and thorough testing covering each change made, even though the changes made here are quite simple and striaghtforward.  Moreover, more than 30,000 LoC have been added or deleted, likely because the pull request was created from the wrong branch.  It is possible to take the changes they made to the two controllers they were refactoring, and re-make them in the beta branch.
Feedback on project: Tasks for this project were to add comments to methods, provide better and meaningful identifier and method naming, and improve the language of error messages in the password_retrieval controller.rb file. While in the auth_controller.rb file, the team was supposed to turn the identifier names into the ones with american spellings, explain conjunctions using comments, and make changes to logger calls. The team  finished all the given tasks mentioned in the description. A comment like, "Checking if both places have the same parameters" basically just repeats what the code says without saying WHY the check is there; comments should explain that. Regarding the tests for these changes, since existing tests cover all these changes, no new tests were to be written. Also, the Travis CI build was failing for this project which isn't good. That said, overall performance of the team was good except in case of failing build.  If the code is to be merged, "authorised" should first be changed to the American spelling.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page documents the changes made, and the github difference screenshots make it really easy to find the code difference in terms of where the changes were made. However, in the password_retrieval_controller, only lines deleted are shown, not lines added.  The functionality inside the filters should have been described in prose, instead of just listing the code. Other than that, the test plan is adequately documented, but it would have been good to describe the tests that have been run. There are screenshots used to show the UI aspects of changes, which is good. Thus, in overall sense, the wiki page is quite detailed and well structured describing the process of accomplishing the refactoring tasks.

Slated to possibly be merged: I would suggest not to merge the project directly without detailed and thorough testing covering each change made, even though the changes made here are quite simple and striaghtforward.
Feedback on project: The tasks for this refactoring project were removal of duplicated code and improving identifier naming in the late_policies_controller.rb file while error messages and method comments had to be updated in the student_quizzes_controller.rb file. These tasks were accomplished by the team. While some tasks (such as refactoring of calculate_score method) were not done by the team, the ones removed after discussion with Dr. Gehringer. Other than that, the Travis CI build of the whole project is failing. Also, the team hasn't provided any new tests with respect to the changes made, but since the issues to be fixed were covered by existing tests, new tests weren't needed. Thus, overall performance of the team was good except in aspect of failing build.
Feedback on design doc:
The wiki page documents the changes made, but it is difficult to find the code difference in terms of where the changes were made at places where the code is long. It would have been better if the team might have placed screenshots of github file changes made section where it color-codes the changes made with respect to old file. It is more helpful to show changes in context than showing one line at a time.

Section headers should give the name of the problem being addressed, not just "Issue 1", "Issue 2", which mean nothing as one peruses the table of contents.
Other than that, the testing plan though short, but is ok. There are screenshots used to show the UI aspects of changes, which is good. Thus, in overall sense, the wiki page is quite straightforward describing the process of accomplishing the refactoring tasks. Though the code changes could have been shown in a better manner.`

The test plan is not adequately described.  It should say what kind of automated changes are being run.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.  Most of changes make the code more obscure, not clearer.  If the changes had not been obscured by whitespace changes, I would have given them an 88, but I did not want to decrease their score later.
Feedback on project:
The team worked on refactoring teams_controller which primarily handles the team creation, deletion and other behaviors. Most of the methods are from instructors view. The code was well written and passed test cases. However, some of the method names are long and not very clear. For some reason, the Github diff shows many more changes than there actually were.  Could this be due to whitespace changes? Although no new test cases were added, the existing test cases seems to be sufficient. Logic in import_team_members has been changed, and a comment indicates that the programmer does not know if it will work! The Travis CI build is failing. The code coverage increased. Overall the team did a good job in refactoring the code.  

Later: The problem with the randomize_all_by_parent method is that you have refactored the create_teams method of teams_controller, renaming it to random_teams, but it calls a create_teams method in Team.rb.  The Team.rb method in turn calls randomize_all_by_parent, but now the association with random team creation is obscured because it's in another class.  If you had named Team>>create_teams Team>>random_teams instead, it would have been much clearer.

Then in get_parent_and_check_if_exists, it is not clear what the parent is.  I am not sure of what the parent of a Team is; is it the assignment that it is participating in?  Then the method should be called get_assignment.  As mentioned in class, a method name that includes a conjunction suggests that a method has two responsibilities, when really it should have only one.

Adding the method new flash_and_redirect_on_update_or_create_error seems to make the code more obscure, because the name contains a conjunction, and it just moves two statements from a method where their purpose is clear to a new method whose name is confusing.

In self.assign_topic_to_first_in_waitlist_post_team_deletion (signed_up_team, signups), the name is very hard to understand, and also seems to imply two responsibilities.  Moreover, why is it a class method, when it takes a signed_up_team as a parameter?  Since the method is in signed_up_team.rb, why isn't the signed_up_team just the receiver?

Then self.copy_assignment does not copy an assignment, but just the teams from the assignment.  So the method name is misleading.
Feedback on design doc: The wiki page was well written. It shows changes in the code, but since the changed lines are not highlighted, it is not easy to see what changes were made.  A Github diff view would have been better. For some of the changes, e.g., delete and create methods, the changes are not describe in prose.  The changes to the inherit method, though, are described more fully.  Automated tests are described well.

Slated to possibly be merged: Well, the build would need to pass first.  Otherwise, seems good to merge.
Feedback on project: The team worked on refactoring the account_request_controller. This file allows admins to manage the approval process for new users. The task was mainly to work on longer methods. These tasks were accomplished by the team. The code seems to be well written. Although the Travis CI build is failing for the team. Also, no new test cases were added by the team. Might need to take a look at the test coverage.
Feedback on design doc: Overall, the wiki page is well written. Could have better in that it claims to show changes in the code, but it only shows the new code, not how it was changed. For create_approved_user, even though before and after versions are shown, it is not easy to pick out the changes.  Could have used screenshots from github to show the changes. Changes to create_requested_user_record are described more fully than changes to earlier files. This is good.  It seems that only automated testing was done.  Was that because users could not be created without causing errors?  Could you have gotten around that by temporarily commenting out the lines of code that sent email?

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project: This team did a good job of refactoring get_team_color and it corresponding method. But does not provide enough valid test cases, plus the Travis CI failed on building the whole project. Some of the old tests are deleted without enough explaination. This project should not be merged since no new tests are provided and old tests are deleted.
Feedback on design doc: In the description of the change to get_team_color, it says, "The original code will not return the correct color, because when it is checking the grade for the reviewer, it is not checking the correct variable."  But it does not identify what variable was incorrect, and what it has been changed to. In fact, it is difficult to see what has been changed in all methods, because no diffs are shown, nor are the changes identified in any other way.  The manual testing plan should provide more detail.

Slated to possibly be merged: This project should not be merged, since not enough solid tests are provided.
Feedback on project: This project asks refactor the long methods in review_mapping_controller.rb, rename variable names such as student_review_num, submission_review_num, calibrated_artifacts_num, participants_hash to convey what they are actually used for, replace switch statements with subclasses methods, create models for the subclasses, remove hardcoded parameters. This team achieved most of these goals, but similar works has been done by previous team. "zero_review" and "one_review" constants are more trouble than just using 0 and 1. This team does not provide enough new tests to the previous team work. More comments on the code modified are needed.
Feedback on design doc: This wiki page is very clear. It mentions all the changes that have been made in this project. Plenty of screenshots are included to explain how the project works and which part of the code base is modified. Testing plan is clear. screenshot show that the Travis CI build is passed and the code coverage increased by 0.04%.  Heading for Section 7.4 is too long, should have been shortened to, "Files modified only due to name changes".  Should have used bulleted lists instead of sentences beginning with an asterisk.  And you CAN create student accounts in the project you have (unless there is a bug; please clarify)

Slated to possibly be merged: This refactoring has affected much functionality, and I have no confidence that it is all tested automatically.  So extensive manual testing would be required.  In the course of testing, the low-level style errors mentioned in my feedback comments could be corrected.
Feedback on project:
First bit of functionality, checking for duplicate topics, does work. Prevents duplicate topic names, but not duplicate topic numbers (IDs). Deleting topics does not, and it apparently did before, as verified by the tests written by E2139. Line 132 of signup_sheet_controller does not begin with a legal comment character.  If condition in Line 270 shoud be written backwards from the way that it is written.  flash1, flash2, flash3 could be given more descriptive names.  Many files are changed, but just to regularize the naming convention between "signup" and "sign_up".  This is a good change.  Change at line 96 of spec file for this controller is suspect, changes a staggered-topic check to a non-staggered check.  Half of reviewers say build does not pass.

In general, the team accomplished what they were asked to, but some of the code style could be improved at the micro level.
Feedback on design doc: Describes the changes made, however, describes them monochromatically, with no highlighting, and is thus less readable than a Github diff.  Changes to code are described in 2-3 sentences, which is better than a lot of pages, but less extensive explanation than the best pages.

Feedback on project: Fairly simple refactorings were done, e.g., changing the form of if statements.  The requirements were met without making many changes to the controller file.  The added tests seem to be reasonable.
Feedback on design doc: Description of changes is not very helpful because it does not highlight or describe what has been changed.  Going to the pull request and pulling up a diff would be more useful than reading the wiki page.  When you show the code for added tests, you should describe what the tests are doing.  Again, the user would have to read the code to figure it out, would be just as easy to look at the diff view.  Not clear why student7 to student10 could not be impersonated.  It seems to work in the production system.

Slated to possibly be merged: READY TO MERGE NOW
Feedback on project: The logic of the notification method is not really simplified; the only change is to change the call to create_new_team.  I'm afraid that "create_new_team" is not an appropriate name in the AssignmentTeam class, because it is creating the team and signing it up for a topic at the same time.  A better name would be create_team_for_signup_topic.  approve_suggestion has not been refactored, as requested in the project description.  70 lines of test code have been added, but it is not clear what they are testing.  It does not seem that the tests are very deep (e.g., add_comment and reject_suggestion just check to see if the appropriate notification is given, without checking that the db is changed appropriately).
Feedback on design doc: Generally a good job of describing the changes made.  However, solutions could be better documented.  For example, when you moved create_new_team to AssignmentTeam, what did the resulting code look like?  Were you able to move the code as is, or did it need to be refactored in some way?  The solution to Problem 3 does not appear, it just says "new code is coming soon".  The solution to Problem 4 should show the confirmation that appears when a notification is sent.  The page says how to run the new automated tests, but doesn't describe what functionality they test.  It should.

Slated to possibly be merged: No.
Feedback on project: We appreciate the effort, but many of the changes the team made do not seem to be useful. This team separated out peer grade calculation into a single method, but peer grade calculation should not be done in this file. It is more appropriate to be done in a model, and anyway, it should call the code that the mentor has recently written in AssignmentTeam.  It's not clear what fetch_peer_reviews does.  The only query it seems to do is for a reviewee_id.  There is a new class, KeyMapping, that is not documented on the wiki page or in the code.  We are not sure what peer-grade data needs to be encrypted. The added tests seem quite shallow, e.g., the test for calculating quiz scores just checks that the returned scores are not nil.  It does not attempt to check that the scores are correct.
Feedback on design doc: Generally a good job of describing the changes made.  It's not clear what some of the comments mean (e.g., "encrypting the peer review grade data")--exactly what kind of data is being encrypted?  But most of the confusion is due to confusion with the code, not with the documentation describing the code.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project: The changes are very difficult to understand.  There is a method find_by_type that has been substituted for find in many different classes, but there are no comments or documentation as to what it does.  The calls to this method have resulted in changes to many files, 31 in all. Readers of the client classes would understand "find" calls, but not necessarily "find_by" calls. Files rubric.rb and rubric_spec.rb were deleted.  They think it is not being used, but did not verify that.  Removing classes was not part of the project. There are DISPLAY_TYPE constants declared; I have forgotten why this was done, and there are no comments explaining it.  The documentation does address it, but from the documentation, it is not clear why this is an improvement.  In general, I think that the code is more difficult to read after the refactoring, which is the opposite of what we wanted.
Feedback on design doc: This is a very short page.  To the extent that changes are described, they are described in one or two lines.  The page contains no code snippets or explanations of why changes were made to the code, such as the replacement of find with find_by.

Project name: Mentor management for assignments without topics
Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: A) Project focus method (evaluate() in BackEnd.java) which was originally 178 lines has been refactored into six smaller methods, though one method is still 70+ lines.  Overall design is good, and refactored implementation provides same functionality as previous larger method. B) After some uncertainty as to whether there would be enough time for team to take on testing work, team agreed to implement some JUnit testing for the new evaluate() and other related methods.  Multiple issues prevented submitted test file from executing as is in standard project environment - test class and method were not public, test code included hard-coded paths referring to local team environment, and additional libraries were used that were not previously in standard environment.  Even with these issues resolved, some tests failed due to other apparent differences between standard environment and team's local environment.  There was no discussion of code coverage or other general indication of thoroughness of testing.     General comments: team started late (at least 10 days after teams assigned) and did not make significant progress until final week.  Few questions were asked until the last few days. Examination of given repository suggests that one team member did most to all of the technical work, though some discussion and design may have been done with all team members.
Feedback on design doc: The project is well described.  The refactoring of evaluate() was not illustrated, and could have been shown well by cutting and pasting a Github diff view.  The added methods were shown, and they seem to contain a reasonable number of comments.  However, Dr. Wagner felt that the page could better explain what code decisions were made.  Testing was explained a little better. The page could have benefited from more screenshots showing the results from evaluate.

Slated to possibly be merged: Yes
Feedback on project: We like the changes to the view.  They will facilitate grading reviews more accurately and in less time. The two issues that were not addressed is grade calculation (not part of the project) and testing (but this is a view project, so not many tests are necessary).  Scores could also be shown with bar graphs, but maybe there should be a project just on the graphs, since several projects have modified this functionality in ways that have corrupted earlier changes.
Feedback on design doc: Very good description of design strategy, and changes are nicely described and illustrated with screenshots.

Slated to possibly be merged: No
Feedback on project:
On the one hand, this project adds useful functionality to Expertiza.  On the other hand, there are a few rough edges.  The capability to give instant feedback to students is very important.  However, if that feedback is not quick, students are likely to skip requesting it.  At the moment, it is too slow.  This project could be merged in the expectation that it will be improved, but another alternative is to wait until later to merge, and in the interim to concentrate on removing the rough edges in the project.  

Two in particular should be fixed: The criteria are numbered in the view, and those numbers do not correspond to anything on the rubric form.  So if the rubric is long, it would be quite difficult for the reviewer to figure out what automated feedback referred to which comment.
